Sample Outputs: gpt-5.2

− Iteration 1 — Avg Score: 83.8
+ Classic sci-fi: The Azra Gambit — Score: 83.0
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi (Author style: Asimov) The Azra Gambit Colonial mars is being mined by corporations who take leases on indentured labourers. The thing they are mining is Azra, a recently discovered exotic metal which accelerates radioactive decay to such a rate that it is greatly sought after for interstellar drives and weapons alike. This has created both a gold rush and an arms race as various interests vie for control and endeavour to unlock Azra's secrets. The story follows Arthur Neegan, a first generation settler and mining engineer. Upon discovering that his unassuming plot sits atop an immense Azra vein, he is subjected to a flurry of interest and scrutiny. Write the next chapter in this story, in which an armed retinue descends on Arthur's home and politely but forcefully invites him to a meeting with some unknown party off-world. The insignia look like that of the Antares diplomatic corp -- diplomatic in name only. Arthur finds himself in the centre of a political tug of war. The chapter involves a meeting with this unknown party, who makes Arthur an offer. The scene should be primarily dialogue, interspersed with vivid description & scene setting. It should sow hints of the larger intrigue, stakes & dangers. Include Asimov's trademark big-and-small-picture world building and retrofuturistic classic scifi vibe. The chapter begins with Arthur aboard the transfer vessel, wondering just what he's gotten involved in. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The transfer vessel's air filtration system hums with a persistent mechanical drone. Arthur Neegan had long ago learned to measure a machine by its noises. A good pump had a reassuring cough. A bad compressor had a whine like a guilty conscience. The hum surrounding him now was neither; it was the indifferent sound of a device doing exactly what it had been built to do, and doing it for someone else's benefit. It made him feel—absurdly—like a contaminant. He sat in a narrow acceleration couch that tried to convince the human spine it belonged in a different century. A web of straps crossed his chest and thighs. The fabric had been scrubbed clean of dust, yet Arthur could still smell Mars in it: iron, peroxide cleanser, and the faint metallic tang that got into everything and never left. The cabin light was a steady amber, chosen, no doubt, to soften faces and hard facts alike. Across from him, a man in a slate uniform watched him with professional patience. On the man's left breast was an insignia: a five-point star with a sweeping arc, stylized as though it were the trail of a ship. Antares Diplomatic Corps. Diplomatic in name only. Arthur glanced, not for the first time, at the weapon on the man's hip. It was not the crude, overbuilt pistol the corporate security men on Mars favored—those were designed to work in dust and panic. This was a compact, clean-lined thing that looked like it had been conceived on a drafting table, in a quiet office, by someone who hated surprises. Arthur said, "Are you going to tell me where we're going?" The man replied, "You were informed you are being taken to a meeting, Mister Neegan." "Informed," Arthur echoed. He shifted against the restraints. "At gunpoint, in my kitchen. Very formal." The man did not react, which itself was a reaction. "You were not harmed." "My tea was," Arthur said. "I liked that cup." A flicker—almost amusement—touched the man's eyes and vanished. "We will compensate you for any property damage." Arthur let out a short laugh that had no humor in it. "You don't even know what you damaged." The man tilted his head a fraction. "You refer to the Azra claim." Arthur went still. It was always said so casually, as though it were a mineral like any other, something you could weigh in a balance and argue over in a surveyor's office. But Azra was not like any other. Azra made radioactive atoms hurry toward their graves. That was what they said in the popular pamphlets, anyway: *accelerates decay*. If you held a chunk of it close to a piece of spent thorium fuel, the thorium would shed its dangerous appetite for time as though ashamed of how long it meant to linger. That made Azra priceless. It turned years into minutes, waste into heat, heat into thrust. It made interstellar drives practical and weapons obscene. Arthur said carefully, "I refer to my life. Until three days ago, my greatest worry was that the sump pumps on rig fourteen would seize because corporate sent me a shipment of bearings that were three microns off spec." The man nodded, as if Arthur had confirmed a data point. "That was before the assay results were transmitted." "Transmitted," Arthur repeated again, tasting the word. He could see it: a thin packet of numbers and chemical signatures and spectral lines, popping up on a corporate console in Olympus Station, then copied, sold, stolen, whispered, accelerated through the invisible arteries that bound Mars to Earth and the Belt and the far moons. It did not take long for a secret to become a commodity. "Who sent you?" Arthur asked. The man said, "The Antares Diplomatic Corps." "And who sent the Antares Diplomatic Corps?" A pause. A shift so slight it might have been the movement of the ship itself. "The Corps acts in the interests of the Antares Combine," the man said at last. Arthur watched his face. It had the calm, symmetrical look of someone who had been selected for this kind of work: noncommittal features, a voice trained not to rise, and eyes that did not give away the mind behind them. "The Combine doesn't have jurisdiction on Mars," Arthur said. "It has influence," the man replied. "And interests." Arthur leaned his head back against the couch. The straps creaked. "Of course it does." Mars, for all the romanticism in the recruitment posters, was not a world; it was an agreement. It existed because Earth governments had decided it was cheaper to let corporations build domes than to build them themselves, and because the corporations had decided it was cheaper to import bodies under indenture than to pay free labor. Mars was a ledger with red dust between its pages. Azra had made the ledger catch fire. Arthur said, "What does 'meeting' mean?" "It means you will speak with a representative," the man said. "Off-world." "Off-world" could mean a hundred places. Phobos, with its crowded docks and cheap air. Deimos, with its quiet men and quieter deals. A private station with no registry and a reactor that ran too hot. Arthur said, "What if I refuse to speak?" The man looked at him a moment longer than necessary. "Refusal is unlikely to be productive." Arthur's jaw tightened. "Because you would shoot me?" "Because others would," the man said. There was the larger picture, then, slipping through the cracks of polite language. Arthur felt a chill that had nothing to do with the ship's recycled air. "Others," he repeated. "Corporate security," the man said, "does not appreciate complications. Nor do the Free Belters. Nor do the Martian Interim Authority. Nor—" He stopped himself with a sort of disciplined restraint. "Nor certain parties whose names you do not know." Arthur stared. "You make it sound like my land claim is a war." The man said, "It may become one." For a moment the ship's hum seemed louder, as though it approved of that statement. Arthur imagined his little plot of regolith and basalt, the survey pins he'd hammered in himself, the drilling rig he'd coaxed to life with improvised gaskets and stubbornness. Beneath it, a vein of Azra thick enough to turn empires hungry. He said softly, "I didn't ask for this." "No," the man agreed. "You discovered it." The ship shifted—an almost imperceptible change in the vibration through the couch as the transfer vessel matched vectors with something larger. A muted clang sounded through the hull. Docking. A panel in the bulkhead flashed from amber to white. The air hummed. Somewhere, a lock cycled with a sound like a sigh. The man unstrapped himself with practiced efficiency and stood. "This way, Mister Neegan." Arthur remained seated a moment longer. "If I stand up, will that be taken as consent?" "It will be taken as cooperation," the man said. "Consent is not a term we will be using." Arthur rose. His legs were unsteady, not from acceleration but from the surreal normality of it all. He followed the man through a narrow corridor whose walls were the color of old bone. There were no windows. There were no signs. A ship without identity, or a ship that did not care to advertise it. At the end of the corridor, the man keyed a hatch. It opened soundlessly. The room beyond was larger than Arthur expected and arranged with a deliberate austerity: a table bolted to the deck, three chairs, a wall screen currently blank. The air smelled faintly of ozone and expensive sterilization. A single overhead light cast no shadow; it made everyone equally visible. A woman stood at the far side of the table. She was tall, with dark hair pulled back in a severe knot and a uniform that looked like Antares at first glance, until Arthur noticed the difference. Her insignia had the same star and arc, but beneath it was a thin bar of iridescent metal—a strip that caught the light and broke it into colors. Azra, Arthur realized, or a clever imitation. She smiled, and it was not a warm expression so much as a calculated one. "Mister Neegan." Arthur stopped just inside the hatch. "Who are you?" She gestured to the chair opposite hers. "Director Salin Voss. Antares Diplomatic Corps." "You people keep saying that like it explains things." "It explains enough," Voss said. "Please sit." Arthur sat. The chair was comfortable in a way that made him suspicious. The guard remained by the hatch, hands folded, weapon visible. Voss took her own seat with measured grace. She placed a small folder on the table. It was paper. Arthur blinked. "Paper?" Voss watched him notice. "It is harder to intercept." He said, "So is not kidnapping engineers." "Engineers are often intercepted," Voss replied. "It is one of your occupational hazards. You build the tools that move history." Arthur's fingers twitched toward the folder but did not touch it. "What do you want?" Voss leaned back slightly. "You have something on your claim, Mister Neegan. Something you do not yet fully understand." "I understand it's Azra." "You understand the label," Voss said. "Not the implications." Arthur said, "It accelerates decay. That's the implication." Voss's eyes sharpened. "It accelerates decay in a way that violates several comfortable assumptions about how matter behaves. It is not merely a catalyst. It appears to—" She stopped, as if considering what to reveal. "It appears to persuade the nucleus that time is optional." Arthur felt his throat go dry. "That's poetry." "It's policy," Voss said. "The Antares Combine cannot allow a substance like that to become an unregulated commodity." Arthur snorted. "You mean you can't allow anyone else to have it." Voss's smile returned, thinner. "You are a practical man, Mister Neegan. I respect that. Yes. We prefer to control the supply chain." Arthur leaned forward. "My lease is with HelioDyne. Their contract—" "Is a corporate fiction upheld by a Martian authority that survives on tariffs and fear," Voss said. "Contracts are honored until they are inconvenient. You know this. You have repaired too many machines with parts that were promised and never delivered." Arthur's hands curled on the table. "So what is this? A buyout? A threat?" "An offer," Voss said, and tapped the folder once. "A generous one." Arthur did not open it. "Generous to me, or generous to your conscience?" Voss's gaze held his. "To your survival." There was silence then, filled only by the ship's steady breathing through its filters. Arthur became abruptly aware that this room, this ship, this moment—was a sealed system. He could say yes, no, scream, laugh. The air would keep humming. The Combine would keep moving. Voss spoke again, softer. "Mister Neegan, you are currently the axis of a tug-of-war you did not volunteer for. HelioDyne will claim your find under the indenture statutes. The Martian Interim Authority will claim it under emergency resource provisions. Certain Belter factions will claim it under the oldest law in the Belt: take what you can hold. And there are Earthside committees already debating whether your claim constitutes a strategic threat." Arthur swallowed. "And Antares?" Voss spread her hands, palms up, as if she were offering something benign. "Antares offers you a way to step out of the line of fire. We will relocate you. We will pay you. We will give you a position. You will help us extract the Azra properly, with safeguards. You will be protected." Arthur said, "Protected by the people who brought a gun to my kitchen." Voss's eyes did not flicker. "Protected by the people who can keep larger guns away." Arthur looked down at the folder. It sat there like a small, flat door. On the edge of it, he could see a watermark—again that iridescent strip, again the suggestion of Azra. He asked, "And if I refuse?" Voss's expression did not change, but the room seemed to tighten around the question. "Then you return to Mars," she said. "And you will discover how quickly a man becomes a footnote when he stands between powers." Arthur let out a slow breath. "You said I would speak with a representative." "I am speaking," Voss said. "You're not the one who wants this," Arthur said quietly. "You're the one sent to get it." Voss regarded him for a long moment. Then she nodded once, as if acknowledging a competent diagnosis. "There are those above me who do not enjoy meetings. They enjoy results." Arthur's mouth tasted of recycled air and old fear. "So what's the catch?" Voss slid the folder an inch toward him. "You sign. You agree to exclusive technical consultancy under Antares charter. You relinquish your claim in exchange for compensation and relocation. And you tell us everything you know about the vein—its depth, its spread, the assay method, the way your instruments behaved when you first hit it." Arthur stared. "My instruments behaved?" Voss's eyes glinted. "You did not think we only intercepted your assay numbers, did you? We intercepted your rig telemetry. Your drill head temperature dropped by twelve degrees when it touched the Azra seam. Your radiation counters spiked and then—impossibly—flattened. That should not happen." Arthur felt a prickle along his arms. He remembered that moment: the drill biting into something that did not feel like rock, the sudden hush in the Geiger chatter, like a crowd holding its breath. He whispered, "It ate the radiation." Voss said, "Or redirected it. Or converted it. We do not know. That is why you are here." Arthur looked up. "And if I help you, you'll keep it from becoming a weapon." Voss's smile returned, and this time it was almost pitying. "Mister Neegan," she said, "it is already a weapon. The only question is who holds it first." The hum of the air filters continued, patient and mechanical, as though time itself were merely another system to be regulated—unless Azra decided otherwise.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical competence in emulating Asimov's style while crafting a compelling sci-fi narrative. The author successfully captures the retrofuturistic atmosphere through careful attention to mechanical details and corporate-political intrigue that feels authentically Asimovian. The worldbuilding is particularly effective, presenting Mars as "a ledger with red dust between its pages" - a vivid metaphor that encapsulates the corporate exploitation theme. The concept of Azra as a substance that "persuades the nucleus that time is optional" strikes the right balance between scientific plausibility and wonder that characterizes classic sci-fi. Arthur Neegan emerges as a well-realized protagonist - practical, observant, and maintaining his dignity under pressure. His engineering background informs his perspective naturally, from assessing machines by their sounds to understanding the implications of instrument readings. The dialogue feels authentic to his character, with dry humor ("My tea was. I liked that cup") that provides levity without undermining tension. Director Voss is effectively portrayed as a competent antagonist - not evil, but representing institutional power with chilling efficiency. Her measured responses and calculated revelations create genuine menace. The dialogue between them crackles with subtext, particularly in exchanges about "consent" versus "cooperation." The prose maintains consistent quality throughout, with memorable phrases like "a weapon that looked like it had been conceived on a drafting table, in a quiet office, by someone who hated surprises." The pacing builds tension effectively, revealing information strategically while maintaining Arthur's agency as a character who asks probing questions. The piece successfully establishes the larger political stakes without overwhelming the personal story. The revelation about the instrument readings adds genuine intrigue and suggests deeper mysteries about Azra's properties. The ending maintains appropriate darkness - Arthur faces an impossible choice between various forms of exploitation, with no clear heroic path forward. Minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the prose becomes slightly overwrought ("time itself were merely another system to be regulated") and some dialogue that edges toward exposition, though this remains within genre conventions. The piece could have benefited from slightly more sensory detail about the ship environments. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 6 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 6.0, Overwrought: 5.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Contemporary romance: Darkroom Revelations — Score: 88.2
Prompt:
Darkroom Revelations Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of Dani, a 25-year-old assertive art student known for her bold style and take-charge attitude in relationships. For the past semester, she's been quietly fascinated by Elliot (he/him), a 19-year-old boy in her experimental photography class. Dani has been intrigued by his unconventional masculinity: killer thrift-shop-nu-goth style, soft demeanour and quiet intellect. When they're paired for a final project requiring late nights in the darkroom, Elliot tentatively shares that he's been questioning his gender identity and expression. Set during one of these intimate darkroom sessions where the red light creates a confessional atmosphere. Explore Dani's complex attraction—her usual assertiveness complicated by her desire to protect Elliot's vulnerability, her excitement at witnessing his self-discovery, and her confusion about what this means for her own identity as someone typically attracted to more defined gender presentations. The narrative should capture the tender awkwardness of their conversations, Dani's internal struggle between taking charge and wanting to give Elliot agency, and the unexpected chemistry that develops as both find themselves in uncharted territory. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The darkroom door sticks the way it always does, like it wants to make you prove you belong here. I shoulder it open anyway, hip first, because that’s how I do most things—decisive contact, no hesitation—then let it thunk shut behind us. Red light swells in the small space, turning Elliot’s face into something carved from wine-dark wax. The safelight makes everyone look guilty, like they’ve been caught thinking too hard. He lingers by the sink, hands in the sleeves of his oversized black sweater like he’s trying to disappear into it. His thrift-store nu-goth thing is always immaculate in a deliberate, careless way—mesh underlayer peeking at the collarbone, a chain that might be a necklace or might be a leash if you squint, pants that hang just right off his hips. Tonight his hair’s damp at the ends, like he came straight from the rain. I set my tote on the counter and start lining up trays, developer to stop bath to fixer, like muscle memory is a spell. “Okay,” I say, because silence in here can turn into pressure. “We’ve got… what, twelve more prints to get through?” Elliot nods. His voice is soft, always like he’s afraid of taking up too much space in the air. “If we want the series to feel consistent, yeah.” I like that he says “feel.” Most people in this class talk about concept like it’s a thesis statement. Elliot talks like he’s listening to the photos themselves. He steps closer to the enlarger. We’re supposed to be a team, but the truth is I’ve been a satellite around him all semester: watching the way he composes without swagger, the way he critiques without cruelty. Fascinated, quietly, because fascination is safer than wanting. Wanting makes you reckless. Wanting makes you obvious. Still, here we are. Alone. Late. The building emptied out hours ago except for janitorial carts rolling down distant hallways like ghosts with keys. I adjust the enlarger head, check the negative carrier. “Your frames are good,” I say, meaning it. “You got that… in-between thing. Like your subject is about to say something but doesn’t.” His mouth tugs, not quite a smile. “That’s kind of how I feel most of the time.” I look at him over my shoulder. In the red light his eyes are darker, his lashes a shadowed fringe. “Yeah?” I keep my tone casual on purpose, like I’m not suddenly very aware of my own pulse. “How do you feel most of the time?” He shifts, weight rocking heel-to-toe. “Like I’m… performing. Even when I’m not trying to.” That lands somewhere tender in my chest, and my instinct is to grab it, name it, make it manageable. That’s what I do. I make things manageable. I take charge. I solve. But Elliot isn’t a problem to solve. I turn back to the enlarger, focusing on the small square of projected light. “We’re all performing,” I say, then regret it immediately because it sounds too neat, too dismissive. I add, quieter, “But I know what you mean.” He’s silent for a beat. The only sound is the faint hum of the ventilation fan and, beyond that, the distant drip of a faucet that never turns off all the way. Then he says it, not like a grand announcement, but like he’s placing something fragile on the counter between us. “I’ve been… questioning my gender. Like, for a while.” My hand pauses on the timer button. The room feels smaller, not in a claustrophobic way but in a focused way, like the red light tightens its grip around the moment. I’ve slept with enough men and women to know how I’m supposed to respond to vulnerability: hold eye contact, speak softly, don’t make it about you. I’m good at that. People assume “assertive” means “insensitive,” but that’s lazy. Assertive just means I don’t pretend I don’t want things. What I don’t know is what I want right now. I turn toward him fully. “Thank you for telling me,” I say. It comes out firm, sincere. “Do you want to talk about what that means for you? Or do you want to just… say it out loud and let it exist?” His shoulders drop a fraction, like he didn’t realize he was holding them up. “Both? Maybe?” He huffs a tiny laugh, embarrassed. “Sorry. I don’t know how to do this.” “Don’t apologize.” I step closer, keeping a respectful distance. In the red light, the edges of him blur, but the reality of him doesn’t. “You don’t have to have a script.” He looks down at his hands. “I don’t think I’m… a man in the way people expect.” He swallows. “But I also don’t know if I’m not. It’s like—sometimes when someone calls me ‘he’ it feels fine, and sometimes it feels like wearing the wrong jacket all day.” That metaphor hits me because he really does look like a person made of jackets: layers chosen with intent, armor that’s also fashion. I nod slowly. “So it’s not that everything feels wrong. It’s that some days it’s right, and some days it’s not.” “Yeah.” His voice is thinner now, stretched tight with honesty. “And I’ve been messing around with how I look because it’s the only part I can control without having to… announce anything.” Something warm and electric runs under my skin at the thought: him experimenting, claiming space in small ways. It’s attractive in a way I wasn’t prepared for. Not because he looks like a boy playing dress-up, but because he looks like a person in motion. My brain tries to categorize him—boy, man, not-man, something else—and stalls. I’ve always liked my attractions clean, like bold lines in a poster design: masculine women, feminine men, defined edges. Elliot is all gradation and shadow, like a print that only reveals itself if you stand still long enough. Maybe that’s why I can’t stop looking. I clear my throat, buying myself time. “What… do you want me to do with that information?” I ask. My voice is steady, but inside I’m hovering between impulses: take his hand, tell him I’ve got him, tell him he can be whatever he is. Or shut up and give him room. He lifts his gaze to mine, and for a second I can’t tell if he’s bracing for rejection or hoping for something. “Nothing,” he says quickly, then corrects himself. “I mean—maybe just… don’t make jokes. Don’t make it a thing.” “I won’t,” I say immediately. “And Elliot?” “Yeah?” “If you ever want different words—different pronouns, whatever—you can tell me. No pressure. I’ll follow your lead.” His expression shifts, subtle but real. Relief, maybe. Or the weird kind of gratitude that comes when someone doesn’t try to steer you. I’m proud of myself for saying the right thing. That’s a dangerous feeling. Pride can slide into control without you noticing. To keep my hands busy, I slide a sheet of photo paper out of the box, careful to keep it angled away from any stray light. “Okay,” I say, voice lighter. “Let’s make some art before we spiral into existentialism.” He snorts softly, a sound that feels like a reward. We work in a rhythm: I focus the image, he adjusts the contrast filter, I set the timer, he lays the paper on the easel. Our fingers get close without touching, the kind of almost-contact that’s louder than actual touch. Every time our hands brush accidentally, I feel it in my stomach, like my body is taking notes even if my head is confused. Between prints, we talk—carefully, haltingly. He tells me about trying on his sister’s eyeliner once and not hating his face for the first time in a week. I tell him about the first time I shaved my head at nineteen and how my mother cried like I’d joined a cult. He laughs, then asks, “Did you feel… powerful?” “I felt like myself,” I say, and it’s true. “And also like people were going to project whatever they wanted onto me anyway, so I might as well give them something to work with.” He considers that. “That’s kind of… genius.” “It’s kind of exhausting,” I admit, and the confession surprises me. I’m not used to admitting exhaustion. I’m used to being the person other people lean on, not the one who says, hey, I’m heavy too. Elliot’s gaze softens. “You don’t seem exhausted.” “That’s because I’m good at my brand,” I say, and his smile is real this time. We’re in the middle of setting up the next exposure when it happens. Elliot reaches past me for the contrast filters, and his sleeve catches the edge of the paper box. The lid flips up. In the same second, my elbow bumps the darkroom door latch—because of course it does, because of course the universe chooses this moment—and the door cracks open with a thin wedge of hallway light spilling in, bright and brutal. “Shit,” I say, too loud. Elliot freezes, eyes wide. For half a heartbeat, no one moves, like movement itself might make the damage worse. The white light hits the stack of photo paper like a slap. I lunge for the door, slam it shut, and press my palm against it as if I can press time backward. My chest is tight. My brain is already doing the math: how many sheets, how much money, how much time. Elliot’s voice comes small. “I’m sorry. I didn’t—” “Hey.” I turn, and the sharpness in my own voice startles me. I force it down, because I can see the way his shoulders climb toward his ears, the way his whole body prepares to be blamed. “No. Don’t. It’s paper.” He looks at the box like it’s a crime scene. “But it’s… the whole stack.” I walk over and peer inside. The top sheets are definitely ruined—gray-fogged already, a faint bruise of exposure. Maybe the bottom ones are salvageable, maybe not. It feels like a metaphor I didn’t ask for: a careless moment, light where there shouldn’t be light, something fragile made unusable. I exhale slowly. “Okay,” I say, because okay is my way of making space around panic. “We can problem-solve. We’ve got some paper in my locker. And worst case, we adjust. We print smaller. We change the sequence.” Elliot’s eyes flick up to me. “You’re not mad?” “I’m annoyed at the universe,” I say. “Not at you.” He swallows. The red light makes his throat look like a pulse. “I just… I feel like I ruin things.” The words hang there, heavier than the ruined paper. My instinct is to step in and contradict him, to tell him he’s wrong, to wrap him in certainty like a blanket. But certainty isn’t always kindness. Sometimes it’s just noise. So instead, I ask, “Do you want me to fix this, or do you want to fix it together?” He blinks, like he didn’t expect options. Like he didn’t expect his preference to matter. “Together,” he says, and his voice has a little more shape to it now. “If that’s okay.” “It’s more than okay.” I reach out, then stop myself half an inch from touching his wrist. I’m suddenly aware of how touch can be a kind of claim. “Can I—?” He looks at my hand, then back at my face. “Yeah,” he says, barely audible. “You can.” I let my fingers settle lightly around his wrist, not pulling, just anchoring. His skin is cool. He doesn’t flinch. He doesn’t melt either. He just stays, present, letting me be there without taking him over. The contact sends a quiet thrill through me, but it’s braided with something else: a tenderness that makes my usual confidence feel too loud, like heels on a library floor. We stand like that for a second, in the red light, two people with too many questions and not enough language. Then I let go and start opening cabinets, moving with purpose. Elliot moves with me, grabbing trays, checking the timer, taking direction when I give it and offering his own when he has it. It’s not me leading and him following. It’s us making a new rhythm in the dark, adjusting to the fact that the rules we thought we understood—about paper, about light, about boys, about desire—can change in a single careless second. While we work, my mind keeps circling the thing he told me. Questioning. Not knowing. Trying things on like jackets. I realize my confusion isn’t just about him. It’s about me, too—about how much of my attraction has been tied to certainty, to labels that make my own desire feel legible. Elliot’s uncertainty should make him feel distant. Instead it pulls me closer, because there’s something in his openness that makes me want to be braver. Not braver in the way I’m used to—bolder lipstick, sharper words, taking the first move. Braver in the way that requires patience. Listening. Letting someone else set the pace. I glance at him as he slides a fresh sheet onto the easel—one of my stash, saved from my locker like a backup life. He bites his lip in concentration, and the red light catches the curve of it. “What?” he asks, sensing my stare. “Nothing,” I say, then decide to be honest in the smallest safe way. “Just… I’m glad you’re here.” His ears go a shade darker under the safelight. “I’m glad you’re here too.” And in that moment, with our hands stained by chemistry and our project half-ruined and half-rescued, the darkroom feels less like a place where images are forced to appear and more like a place where you’re allowed to become something slowly. Not in a flash of white light. In red, soft, and careful.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical craft and emotional intelligence in handling a delicate subject matter. The author successfully creates an intimate, atmospheric setting in the darkroom that serves both as literal workspace and metaphorical space for vulnerability and self-discovery. The characterization is particularly well-executed. Dani's voice feels authentic - her assertiveness comes through naturally without being heavy-handed, and her internal conflict between wanting to take charge and respecting Elliot's agency creates compelling tension. The author skillfully shows her usual confidence being complicated by unfamiliar territory. Elliot's vulnerability is portrayed with sensitivity, avoiding stereotypes while making his questioning feel genuine and relatable. The prose quality is consistently high, with evocative imagery that serves the story rather than overwhelming it. Descriptions like "Red light swells in the small space, turning Elliot's face into something carved from wine-dark wax" create atmosphere without being purple. The darkroom setting is used effectively both literally and symbolically. The dialogue feels natural and serves character development well. Conversations flow organically, particularly the tentative way Elliot shares his questioning and Dani's careful responses. The author avoids exposition-heavy dialogue while still conveying necessary information about both characters' internal states. The emotional complexity is handled with maturity. Dani's attraction isn't simplified - the author explores how her usual preferences are challenged and complicated by Elliot's fluidity. The piece doesn't rush toward easy answers or transformations, instead sitting comfortably in uncertainty and gradual understanding. The incident with the ruined photo paper serves as an effective plot device that doesn't feel contrived. It creates a moment of crisis that reveals character while advancing the emotional arc. The resolution feels earned rather than forced. The pacing is well-controlled, building intimacy gradually without rushing the emotional beats. The ending strikes an appropriate note - hopeful but not overly optimistic, suggesting possibility without guaranteeing outcomes. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the internal monologue becomes slightly repetitive, and a few instances where metaphors feel slightly strained. However, these don't significantly detract from the overall quality. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18

+ Contemporary romance / drama: Stolen Moments in Roma — Score: 78.4
Prompt:
Contemporary Romance / Drama: Stolen Moments in Roma. Write a series of interconnected short scenes and dialogues that span a single day in modern-day Rome, in narrative form. This will form the beginning of a larger story. Alessandra, a fiery, independent Roman woman who works as a motorcycle courier, nearly collides with Ben, a somewhat clumsy, overly polite British academic on sabbatical, who is engrossed in a guidebook near the Trevi Fountain. The initial encounter is a clash of cultures and personalities – Alessandra is all sharp wit and rapid-fire Italian, while Ben is flustered apologies and awkward attempts at speaking the language. However, as they sort out the near-miss, a spark of unexpected humor and connection emerges. Alessandra, it quickly becomes clear, is a whirlwind of energy and mischief. She's a self-admitted troublemaker with a secret penchant for kleptomania, a detail she doesn't explicitly reveal, but which manifests in subtle, daring acts throughout the day. She impulsively decides to take Ben on a wild, unsanctioned tour of Rome, dragging him in some specific instances far outside his comfort zone. Ben, despite his initial apprehension and inherent politeness, finds himself utterly captivated by Alessandra's unapologetic spirit and zest for life. He is drawn into her orbit, a willing participant in increasingly outlandish situations, a quiet rebellion brewing beneath his scholarly exterior. The narrative should primarily consist of short, vivid scenes and dialogue exchanges, revealing their contrasting personalities and backgrounds, and the growing, ambiguous tension between them. Ben is captivated by Alessandra's energy and the thrill of breaking free from his routine. There's a clear sense that Alessandra is toying with Ben, pushing his boundaries and enjoying his reactions, but her own feelings remain somewhat enigmatic. The day should be a rollercoaster of exhilarating, slightly dangerous, and humorous moments, leaving Ben completely disoriented but utterly smitten. Explore the underlying tension & chemistry between them, culminating in some payoff as they part ways (or not -- your choice). Include this detail: Write in narrative prose, using immersive storytelling. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The Trevi Fountain was already crowded at nine in the morning, a glittering bowl of coins and cameras and sun-splashed stone. Ben stood one step back from the tide, holding his guidebook open like a shield. He’d underlined three sentences about Bernini the night before. He was trying to find the exact angle from which the guidebook’s photo had been taken, to compare light and shadow like it mattered, like it was research and not merely a way of keeping himself occupied in a foreign city. He turned a page. A horn snapped through the air like a whip. Ben looked up, too late. A red-and-black motorcycle cut across the cobblestones with a confidence that bordered on criminal. The rider leaned in, knee almost kissing stone, and for one unsteady second Ben saw only a visor and the flash of dark hair escaping beneath a helmet. He stepped back instinctively—straight into a tourist with a gelato. “Mi prendi in giro?” came a voice, sharp as a thrown coin. The bike stopped so close the heat from the engine brushed Ben’s shins. He could see the front fender: a bright, childish dent painted over with swirls of turquoise and yellow, like someone had tried to turn a wound into art. It didn’t look accidental. It looked like a souvenir. The rider lifted her visor. She was not smiling. “You—uh—sorry,” Ben said quickly, hands up, guidebook clutched. “I’m terribly sorry. I didn’t—” “Non hai visto niente, eh?” She tipped her head toward the guidebook, then the fountain, then Ben, like she was cataloging his entire existence in three glances. “You read. You die.” Ben blinked. “I—what?” She sighed as if he’d failed a basic exam. “Britannico.” “How did you—” “Those shoes,” she said in English now, clipped and amused. “And that face you do. Like you are always apologizing to the air.” Ben’s ears warmed. “It’s—habit. Also you almost ran me over.” “I did not.” Her mouth curved just enough to suggest she enjoyed the argument. “I almost educated you. Different.” Around them, Rome flowed as if nothing had happened. Coins flicked into water. A street vendor called out prices with lazy desperation. The fountain roared, indifferent. Ben tried Italian, because he was here to learn, because embarrassment made him reckless. “Mi… dispiace. Ma—eh—lei… guida… molto… veloce.” She stared at him for a beat, then laughed, a short burst like a match struck. “Madonna. You are adorable.” Ben straightened, unsure if he’d been insulted or praised. “I’m not sure that’s—” “I’m Alessandra.” She nodded at the motorcycle like it was an extension of her body. “And you are… Professor?” “No,” Ben said automatically, then realized that was what he was, technically. “Ben. Ben Carter. I’m—on sabbatical.” “Sabbatical.” She rolled the word in her mouth as if tasting it. “So you are here to be lost.” “I’m not lost,” he said, too quickly. Alessandra glanced at the guidebook again. “You are holding a map like a drowning man.” “I just like to understand—” “Understand.” She pulled the key from the ignition, then—without any warning—reached past him and plucked something from the fountain’s edge. Ben’s eyes followed her hand. A small brass coin lay in her palm. Not a Euro. Something older. It glinted with a worn profile. “Did you just—” Ben lowered his voice. “You can’t take that.” Alessandra tucked it into her jacket pocket with the smoothness of someone who’d practiced being careless. “It was out. On the stone. Not in the water.” “That’s not the point.” “The point,” she said, stepping off the bike, “is you are too stiff. You will crack. Like—how you say—biscotti.” Ben tried to gather himself. “I’m perfectly capable of enjoying Rome in a—lawful manner.” She looked him up and down again. “Lawful is boring. Come.” “Come where?” She started walking, helmet under her arm, not waiting to see if he followed. She moved like she owned the street, like the city’s chaos was choreographed for her. Ben hesitated. He had plans: the Pantheon, then a quiet lunch, then reading in the shade. He could almost see his day neatly stacked like books. Alessandra stopped and looked back. “Professor Ben.” “I said I wasn’t—” “You want to see Rome or you want to read about Rome?” The question hit him in a place he hadn’t known was tender. He closed the guidebook, then—before he could talk himself out of it—fell into step beside her. --- By late morning they were in Trastevere, the streets narrowing into a maze of laundry lines and scooter exhaust. Alessandra walked fast, pointing without explanation. “That church,” she said, jabbing a finger. “Pretty. Too many weddings. That bar—bad coffee, good gossip. That window—” She paused, eyes narrowing at a second-floor balcony where basil spilled from terracotta pots. “That is where my cousin threw a plate at her boyfriend.” Ben tried to keep up. “Why?” “He deserved.” Alessandra said it as if it were universal logic. Then she glanced at Ben’s careful steps on the uneven stones and slowed, just slightly. “You are afraid of falling?” “I’m not afraid,” Ben lied. “I’m cautious.” “Same thing with better suit.” Ben huffed a laugh despite himself. “You’re very… direct.” “I am Roman,” she said. “We don’t have time for soft words.” At a small piazza, Alessandra stopped at a market stall crowded with scarves and leather bracelets. The vendor greeted her like family. She leaned in, said something rapid in Italian, and the vendor’s grin widened. Ben hovered behind her, hands in his pockets, trying to look relaxed. Alessandra picked up a narrow strip of leather—simple, dark, with a metal clasp. She held it against Ben’s wrist. “No,” Ben said reflexively. “I don’t—” “Shh.” She fastened it before he could pull away. Her fingers were quick, warm against his skin. “Now you look less like a lost child.” Ben stared down. The bracelet was understated, almost scholarly. The absurd affection in the gesture made his throat tighten. “That’s very kind,” he said. Alessandra waved him off, already moving. “It is nothing.” Ben turned to thank the vendor, but Alessandra was blocking his view—and the vendor’s hand moved, exchanging cash that Ben didn’t see. When they were a few steps away, Ben glanced back. The vendor was still smiling. Alessandra was whistling, innocent as a saint. Ben’s eyes fell to her jacket pocket, where the outline of something small made a little bump. He said nothing, because he was not certain. Because calling her out would end whatever this was. Because, disturbingly, he didn’t want it to end. --- They crossed the Tiber at noon, the river a slow ribbon under the bridges. Alessandra stopped beside a street musician playing a battered accordion. Without asking, she took Ben’s hand and placed a coin in his palm. “Give.” Ben looked at the coin. It wasn’t Euro. It was old, brass, worn. “Alessandra,” he said quietly. “What?” Her eyes were bright, challenging. “This—where did you—” She stepped closer, crowding his space until he could smell something clean under the city: soap, maybe, and lemon. “Professor,” she murmured, voice low enough to be private. “Sometimes you have to borrow luck.” Ben swallowed. The musician’s song wove around them. People passed, brushing shoulders, not noticing. Ben dropped the coin into the musician’s open case. The accordionist nodded in thanks. Alessandra watched Ben’s face as if she’d just pushed him off a ledge and was waiting to see if he’d fly. Ben exhaled, shaky. “This day is going to get me arrested.” Alessandra’s smile finally arrived fully, wicked and delighted. “No. I will get you arrested. You just come.” --- In the afternoon heat, Alessandra led him to a courtyard behind a building he couldn’t identify. The gate was ajar. Inside, sunlight slanted over a patch of wild flowers and a cracked marble statue missing its hands. “This is private property,” Ben said. Alessandra lifted her eyebrows. “Now you can read signs.” “There’s a lock,” Ben pointed out. “Broken,” she corrected, pushing it open with a finger. “Come.” Ben followed, heart thumping. It felt ridiculous—trespassing like a teenager—yet the thrill was undeniable. His usual internal narration, the endless caution, had quieted to a stunned whisper. In the courtyard, Alessandra climbed onto a low wall and sat with her legs dangling. Ben stood awkwardly below her. “Why are you doing this?” he asked. “Doing what?” “Dragging me around. You don’t know me.” Alessandra looked at him for a long moment. In the sudden stillness, her mischief softened into something harder to read. “You looked sad at Trevi,” she said finally, almost matter-of-fact. “Not sad-sad. More like—stuck.” Ben’s chest tightened. “I’m not stuck.” “Sure.” She swung her boot against the wall. “And I am not trouble.” Ben surprised himself by stepping closer. “Are you trouble?” Her eyes flicked to his mouth, then back to his eyes. “Yes.” “Should I be worried?” Alessandra leaned forward, close enough now that Ben could see a faint freckle near her cheekbone, a small imperfection that made her feel more real. “You are already worried,” she said. “But you are still here.” Ben let out a breath he didn’t know he’d been holding. “I don’t usually do things like this.” “Like what?” she asked, voice softer. “Follow a stranger,” Ben said. “Trespass. Skip my plans. Let someone—” He glanced down at his wrist, at the bracelet. “—decide my day.” Alessandra’s gaze lingered on his wrist too. “You like it.” Ben met her eyes. “Yes.” The confession hung between them, bright and dangerous. Alessandra slipped off the wall. She landed close, boots scraping stone, and for a heartbeat Ben thought she might kiss him—thought he might actually tilt forward and meet her halfway, forget every rule he’d ever rehearsed. Instead she reached past him, plucked a small white flower from the wild patch, and tucked it behind his ear with exaggerated care. “There,” she said, stepping back to admire her work. “Now you are ridiculous.” Ben touched the flower, half laughing, half stunned. “You’re impossible.” Alessandra’s grin flashed. “And you are—how you say—smitten.” Ben’s laugh died on his tongue. He didn’t deny it. --- Near sunset, they returned to where it had started. The Trevi Fountain was even more crowded now, the water tinted gold. Alessandra’s motorcycle waited at the edge of the street like a poised animal. The colorful dent caught the last light, bright as a bruise made beautiful. Ben stood beside her, reluctant in a way that surprised him. It had been one day. It felt like a crack in his life had opened and let oxygen in. Alessandra swung her helmet onto her head, then paused. Her hands hovered at her chin strap. She looked at Ben as if measuring something. “This is where you go back to your hotel,” she said. Ben nodded slowly. “And you go back to… causing havoc.” “Work,” Alessandra corrected, though her eyes said yes, havoc. “I deliver packages. Sometimes I deliver people from their boredom.” Ben swallowed. “Will I see you again?” Alessandra tilted her head. “You want?” “Yes,” Ben said, too honest. “I think so.” She stepped closer. In the roar of the fountain, her voice was a private line drawn straight into him. “Then you come tomorrow,” she said, “at ten, same place. No book.” Ben tried to smile, but it came out shaky. “That sounds… terrifying.” “Bene.” Alessandra reached into her jacket pocket. Ben’s pulse jumped—expecting a coin, a stolen trinket, proof. She pulled out something else: a tiny keyring shaped like the Colosseum, cheap and glittery, the kind tourists bought in bulk. She pressed it into Ben’s palm. Her fingers closed around his for a second, firm. Ben stared at it. “Is this—” “A souvenir,” Alessandra said quickly, too quickly. “You need something to remember you survived.” Ben looked up. “Did you steal this?” Alessandra’s eyes sparked. “No.” He waited. She sighed, exasperated, then leaned in and kissed him—fast, warm, unapologetic. It wasn’t gentle. It was a dare. When she pulled back, Ben was still trying to breathe. Alessandra tapped the guidebook sticking out of his bag like an accusation. “Tomorrow,” she repeated. “No book.” Then she swung onto the motorcycle in one fluid motion. The engine growled. The colorful dent flashed again, a bright mark of some past adventure Ben could only guess at. As she pulled away, she called over her shoulder, “And, Professor—try not to die.” Ben stood with a ridiculous flower in his hair, a cheap keyring in his hand, and a bracelet snug on his wrist, watching her disappear into Roman traffic. He realized—too late, and with a startled, delighted dread—that he was already planning his entire life around ten o’clock tomorrow.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution and adherence to the prompt's requirements. The author successfully creates two distinct characters - Alessandra, the fiery Roman motorcycle courier with kleptomaniac tendencies, and Ben, the polite British academic - and develops their contrasting personalities through well-crafted dialogue and action. The narrative structure works effectively, using interconnected scenes that span a single day as requested. The progression from their near-collision at Trevi Fountain through various Roman locations feels natural and purposeful. The author skillfully weaves in Alessandra's kleptomania through subtle actions rather than explicit revelation, showing restraint and sophistication in character development. The dialogue captures the cultural and personality differences convincingly. Alessandra's directness ("You read. You die") contrasts sharply with Ben's apologetic nature, and their verbal sparring feels authentic. The author handles the language barrier elements well, showing Ben's awkward Italian attempts without overdoing the linguistic comedy. The prose quality is generally high, with vivid imagery that brings Rome to life. Descriptions like "a red-and-black motorcycle cut across the cobblestones with a confidence that bordered on criminal" and "the fountain roared, indifferent" create strong visual impressions without becoming overwrought. However, the piece occasionally veers toward predictable romantic comedy territory. Ben's transformation from cautious academic to willing rule-breaker, while believable, follows familiar patterns. The ending, with its kiss and promise of future meetings, feels somewhat conventional for the genre. The emotional complexity is present but could be deeper. While we see Ben's growing attraction and Alessandra's playful manipulation, her motivations remain somewhat surface-level beyond enjoying his reactions. The piece succeeds in creating romantic tension but doesn't fully explore the psychological depths hinted at in both characters. The pacing is well-controlled, moving through the day without feeling rushed or dragging. The author maintains narrative momentum while allowing for character development moments. The writing voice remains consistent throughout, balancing literary quality with accessibility. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 14 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 6 Unearned Transformations: 7 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 15.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 14.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8.0, Amateurish: 4.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 6.0, Unearned Transformations: 7.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Cozy sci-fi: The Last Outpost — Score: 79.5
Prompt:
Cozy sci-fi The Last Outpost Nettle (or Nets to her friends) bartends at The Last Outpost -- a lazy hub for miners and merchants in an asteroid belt on the Andromeda outer rim. Escaping from her past life, Nets found a home here at the Outpost. They have, thus far, tolerated Net's flaws which she tries to keep in equilibrium with her assortment of talents. Her evenings involve chatting with patrons, negotiating the drama, intrigue, problems & love lives of the diverse crowd that filter through the Outpost. Tonight is no different, at least, until a frazzled looking stranger, tentacled dreads askew, quietly plops down at the bar: "Vega whisky, neat. Better make that a double." Write a chapter in this story. Establish conflict for narrative interest. Don't resolve the conflict within this chapter. Aim for about 60% dialogue. First person, present tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The bell over the airlock door doesn’t jingle here—no point, not with the pressure seals and the hiss of cycling atmosphere—but the Outpost has its own tells. A certain change in the room, like the asteroid belt itself shifts and everyone feels it in their bones. Tonight it’s the usual low-gravity lull. Miners fresh off a rock run crowd the long tables, boots still dusted with gray grit. Merchants sit in their careful little islands of quiet, drinks untouched while they calculate margins in their heads. Someone’s got a hand of cards going near the heater vent, the slap of polymer chips punctuating a slow ballad drifting from the wall speakers. I’m polishing glasses that don’t need polishing because it gives my hands something honest to do. “Three more Rimshots, Nets,” Jori calls from booth six, waving a credit chit like a flag. His beard’s still braided with cable ties from his shift. “Put it on my tab, and don’t you make that face like I won’t pay.” “I don’t make faces,” I say. “I curate expressions.” “Same thing,” he says, grinning. I pour the Rimshots—half citrus synth, half spark liquor, topped with a fizz that tastes like a dare—and slide them down the bar to the runner drone. The drone zips off, its little stabilizers whining. The Outpost isn’t fancy, but it’s efficient in the ways that matter. Kesh leans an elbow on the bar, her jacket half-unzipped, hair shaved on one side and braided on the other. She watches me like she’s watching a moonrise. “You’re quiet,” she says. “I’m always quiet,” I lie. Kesh hums. “You’re quiet in a way that says you’re listening for something.” I keep my eyes on the bottles lined up in their brackets. Vega whisky. Drifter gin. Fermented kelp brandy that tastes like regret and ocean storms. “Maybe I just like the music.” “Mm-hm.” She taps the bar once, an old habit from when she used to run comms and thought everything could be signaled in code. “You hear from your… friend?” My throat tightens. “No.” She doesn’t push. That’s why Kesh lasts longer than most people in a place like this. “If they show up,” she says instead, “I’ll be right here.” “Yeah,” I say, and force my hands to keep moving. “Where else would you be?” The airlock hisses. I feel it before I see it: a hush in the room’s attention, a subtle recalibration. The Outpost is a lazy hub, sure, but lazy doesn’t mean blind. People survive out here by noticing the difference between routine and trouble. The stranger steps in like they’ve forgotten how to be inside. Tall—taller than most humans, though the stoop makes it hard to tell. Skin the color of deep tea under station lights. Their hair isn’t hair; it’s tentacled dreads, thick cords that curl and knot and look like they’ve been slept on for three days. Their coat is too thin for the rim, patched at the elbows, a heat strip hanging dead along the collar. They scan the room once, quick, and then they choose my bar. They don’t swagger. They don’t preen. They just… arrive, and sit, and exhale like they’ve been holding their breath for several light-years. “Vega whisky,” they say, voice low and scraped raw. “Neat. Better make that a double.” I reach for the Vega bottle without asking questions. The label is faded from being touched too often. “You got credit,” I say, “or are we doing favors tonight?” The stranger’s mouth twitches, not quite a smile. “Credit.” A coin-chip lands on the bar—real metal, old style, the kind that makes merchants sit up straighter. It spins once, then falls flat with a dull clack. Interesting. I pour. Two fingers becomes four. The whisky hits the glass with a warm amber glug and the scent of smoke and star-anise. They take it like they’ve been thirsty for weeks. One swallow, then a second slower one, like they’re remembering what it is to taste something that isn’t recycled air. “What’s your name?” I ask, because names matter and because if I don’t ask, my brain will invent worse possibilities. The stranger’s eyes flick up. Dark. Reflective in a way that makes me think of deep water. “Do I need one?” “Here?” I nod toward the room. “Yeah. People get nervous around blanks.” A beat. “Call me Sable.” “Sure,” I say. “Sable.” They cradle the glass, hands steady now that the drink has something to do. Their fingers are long, with faint suction-cup ridges at the pads that catch the light when they shift. Kesh makes a quiet sound beside me, not quite a warning, not quite a greeting. Sable’s gaze flicks to her and back to me. “You run this place?” “I pour drinks,” I say. “The place runs itself. Mostly.” Sable’s mouth opens, like they’re about to say something else, but the words don’t come. Instead they listen, head angled slightly. I listen too, because whatever they’re listening for, it makes the hair on my arms lift. At first I hear nothing but the normal: laughter at the card table, the rattle of ice, the slow thrum of the Outpost’s aging life-support vents. Then—beneath it—something else. A soft, irregular ping, like metal being tapped with a nail. Kesh’s eyes narrow. “Nets,” she murmurs, too low for anyone else, “did you order a delivery?” “No,” I whisper back. “Did you?” She shakes her head once. Sable swallows another mouthful of whisky. “You have a back door?” they ask. “There’s an access corridor,” I say carefully. “For supplies. Why?” Sable sets the glass down. “Because someone’s tracing me.” The words land like a weight. Not loud, not dramatic—worse. Matter-of-fact. The kind of truth you can’t argue with. I force my face into calm. “People trace lots of people,” I say. “Miners with debts. Merchants with cargo. Lovers with bad boundaries.” Sable’s gaze doesn’t blink. “Not like this.” Across the room, the merchant at table three—Linn, the one with the gold tooth—stops mid-sentence. His eyes lock on the airlock door, then slide away too fast. I know that move. I’ve done it myself. “Who?” I ask, keeping my hands busy, wiping a nonexistent spill. “Out here, it could be anyone.” Sable’s tentacled dreads shift as they tilt their head, a subtle ripple like sea grass. “If I say it, do you throw me out?” “That depends,” I say. “On whether you bleed on my floor.” A sound cracks through the bar—sharp, sudden. A glass shatters somewhere behind me, near the dish station. Everyone flinches. For a heartbeat, the Outpost’s cozy noise collapses into a tight silence. “Sorry!” calls Miko, my runner, from the back. “Dropped one—my bad!” Laughter resumes in a delayed wave, too loud, too quick. People are eager to pretend nothing happened. But Sable’s shoulders go rigid. “That wasn’t an accident,” they say quietly. I glance over my shoulder. Miko is crouched, sweeping glass into a magnetic pan. His hands are shaking. He looks up and meets my eyes—just for a second—and the panic there is raw. Kesh’s fingers curl on the bar. “Nets,” she says, “do you want me to—” “Not yet,” I murmur. Sable leans forward, lowering their voice until it’s just for me. “I was supposed to meet someone here,” they say. “A contact. They didn’t show.” My pulse ticks in my throat. “A contact from where?” Sable’s eyes flick toward the ceiling, toward the vents, toward the places where sound hides. “From the inner lanes,” they say. “From the kind of work you don’t want to know about.” I bark a soft laugh that isn’t funny. “You’re in a bar on the Andromeda rim. I know about work I don’t want to know about.” Sable’s expression tightens. “Then you understand why I came here.” “I understand why you came,” I say. “I don’t understand why you’re telling me.” Sable’s gaze sharpens, like a blade finally unsheathed. “Because they’ll ask you,” they say. “And if you answer wrong, this place stops being your home.” My fingers still on the rag. For a second, the Outpost feels too small, the air too thin. “Who is ‘they’?” I ask again, and this time the question has teeth. Sable’s lips part. A name is right there, hanging on the edge of breath— The airlock hisses again. Every head turns, not because they want to, but because something in their bodies knows. The way prey knows when the grass parts wrong. Three figures step inside. Not miners. Not merchants. Clean boots. Matching jackets with a faint sheen that says corporate composite. Their faces are ordinary in a way that feels engineered. The one in front carries a small case in one hand like it’s nothing. They don’t look around like they’re new. They look around like they own the air. The leader’s eyes land on me first, then slide to Sable, and the smallest smile touches their mouth. “Evening,” the leader says, voice pleasant as poured syrup. “We’re looking for someone.” Sable’s hand closes around their glass hard enough that I hear the faint protest of strained crystal. Kesh leans closer to me. “Nets,” she whispers, “tell me what you want me to do.” I wet my lips, tasting citrus and smoke. My mind runs through exits, hiding places, people I can trust, people I can’t. Past lives I thought I’d outrun. I meet the leader’s gaze and force my voice steady. “Outpost policy,” I say, “is you tell me what you’re drinking before you tell me what you’re hunting.” The leader’s smile widens just a fraction. “How charming,” they say. “In that case—two waters. And”—their eyes flick back to Sable—“we’ll take our fugitive on the side.” Sable’s breath stutters. And behind the bar, where my hands are supposed to be steady, my fingers tighten around the rag like it’s a lifeline.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution and atmospheric world-building within the cozy sci-fi framework. The author successfully establishes the setting of The Last Outpost as a lived-in space station bar, populated with believable characters who have histories and relationships. The dialogue feels natural and serves multiple purposes - revealing character, advancing plot, and building tension. The narrative voice is consistent throughout, maintaining Nets' perspective as a bartender who's clearly experienced but trying to keep a low profile. The author skillfully uses small details to build the world - the pressure seals, gravity references, synthetic drinks, and various alien characteristics feel integrated rather than forced. The pacing builds tension effectively, starting with routine bar interactions and escalating to the arrival of corporate hunters. Character development is particularly strong. Nets comes across as competent and observant, with hints of a troubled past that align with the prompt's setup. Sable is introduced with appropriate mystery while still feeling like a real person rather than a plot device. The supporting characters like Kesh and the various patrons feel authentic to the setting. The dialogue achieves the requested 60% ratio naturally, never feeling forced or excessive. Conversations reveal character relationships and advance the plot simultaneously. The tension builds organically through increasingly loaded exchanges. However, the piece occasionally veers toward overwrought description, particularly in some metaphorical passages. Some imagery, while evocative, borders on purple prose. The conflict setup, while competent, follows fairly predictable patterns - mysterious stranger, corporate pursuers, bartender with a past. The ending, while appropriately unresolved as requested, relies on somewhat familiar thriller tropes. The writing demonstrates technical proficiency with sentence structure and flow, though some passages could be tightened. The emotional engagement is solid, creating investment in the characters' fates without resorting to melodrama. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 14 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 7 Overwrought: 6 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 14.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8.0, Amateurish: 4.0, Purple Prose: 7.0, Overwrought: 6.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Young adult drama: Gone South — Score: 85.0
Prompt:
Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The first thing New Orleans does is hit me in the face. Not, like, literally. More like the air. It’s thick and wet and smells like hot concrete, fried something, and—underneath it all—old river water that’s been keeping secrets longer than any person I’ve ever met. My shirt sticks to my back the second I step away from the curb like I’m already sweating out my entire life. The guy who gave me a ride from somewhere outside Biloxi (I think? I wasn’t exactly tracking) doesn’t even look at me when he says, “This is as far as I go.” We’re downtown. Cars and people and noise and colors I don’t have words for. A tourist couple is arguing over a map. A kid in a Saints jersey is eating something powdered sugar is actively falling off of. Everyone looks like they belong here, even the ones who obviously don’t. I stand there with my backpack—too light because I couldn’t take anything that would make Mom notice faster—and I watch his tail lights vanish into traffic. And for one gorgeous, terrifying second, I feel… free. Then my stomach drops through my shoes. Okay. New plan, Taylor. Because the old plan was “go literally anywhere else,” and you’ve achieved that. Congrats. Gold star. Now what? I start walking because standing still makes me feel like a target. My phone’s battery is at 12% and I’m not turning it on. If I turn it on, it pings. If it pings, somebody finds me. If somebody finds me, I’m back in that kitchen with my mother’s face like stone and my dad looking at the table like he could bore a hole through it and disappear. “Taylor?” Mom had said, like she was trying it on. Like it was a coat she didn’t want to buy. “No. That’s not— Don’t do this.” Don’t do this. As if I’m a tantrum. The street is crowded and loud and the buildings are old in this proud, leaning way. Iron balconies drip plants like the city is growing over itself. A saxophone threads through all the noise, turning it into something almost… cinematic. Like if I look over my shoulder I’ll see a camera crew, and someone will yell cut, and we’ll reset and do it again with different parents. The sax is coming from up ahead. It’s not cheerful, exactly. It’s the kind of sound that makes your ribs ache, like it knows what your chest has been holding. I follow it without thinking. There’s a guy on the sidewalk with a battered case open at his feet, wearing a white shirt that used to be crisp. He’s older, maybe late forties, hair pulled back, eyes closed while he plays like the street itself is his stage and everyone else is just passing through his story. A couple people throw bills into the case without stopping. A little kid sways and grins until his mom tugs him along. I stop at the edge of the crowd, the music catching me in a way I don’t want. It makes the past two days feel like they’re pressing their hands against my back. I’m not crying. I’m not. My eyes are just—whatever. Someone bumps my shoulder. “Watch it,” a voice says, sharp and low. I turn, ready to snap back, and instead I find a person about my age glaring at me like I just stepped on their foot on purpose. They’re maybe seventeen. Dark hair cut in a messy blunt bob under a black cap. Their eyeliner looks like it was applied in a moving vehicle, which I respect. They’ve got a long sleeve shirt even though it’s approximately a million degrees, and they’re holding a paper cup like it’s the last thing tethering them to Earth. They look me up and down in one second, clocking the backpack, the too-fast breathing, the way I keep scanning like I’m expecting someone to jump out from behind a lamppost and drag me home. “Tourist?” they ask, like it’s an insult. “No,” I say automatically. Which is true, because tourists have plans. Tourists have hotels. Tourists have people expecting them to come back with souvenirs and stories, not… whatever this is. They snort. “Sure.” I should walk away. Stranger danger. Tennessee health class actually did cover something useful, once. But my brain is stuck on the fact that they didn’t say sir or ma’am, didn’t gender me at all, and my body unclenches by a microscopic amount. “What’s your deal?” I ask, because apparently I’ve decided to become the kind of person who starts conversations with random hostile teenagers. They take a sip of whatever’s in their cup and make a face. “My deal is it’s hot and I’m broke. Your deal is you look like you’re about to bolt.” “Maybe I like bolting.” “Mm.” They tilt their head. “You got somewhere to be?” I almost laugh. It comes out more like a cough. “Do I look like I have somewhere to be?” They glance past me, toward the sax player. “You got cash?” “Like… five dollars.” “Good,” they say, immediately. “You can buy water. Or you can buy a beignet and die happy in a sugar coma.” “I’m not dying today,” I say, and the words land heavier than they should. Like they have history. Their eyes narrow a fraction, like they heard it too. “Okay. Not today.” The saxophone slides into a long note that makes my spine tingle. The musician opens his eyes and looks straight at me like he knows I’m not supposed to be here. Like he can see the invisible label that says RUNAWAY in sharpie across my forehead. I shift, uneasy. “Come on,” the teenager says, jerking their chin. “If you stand there looking lost, somebody will try to sell you something or steal your bag.” “Are you going to steal my bag?” I ask. They grin, not friendly. “If I wanted your bag, I’d already have it.” I hate that they’re right. “What’s your name?” I ask, as I fall into step beside them. They hesitate. Just a beat too long. “Jules,” they say finally. It feels like a lie. Or like a name they put on when the real one doesn’t fit. Which, okay. Pot, meet kettle. “I’m—” My throat tightens around it. Saying my name out loud still feels like stepping onto thin ice. Like if I say it, it becomes real, and then I have to deal with all the consequences of being real. Jules looks at me, waiting, but not pushing. It’s weirdly… considerate. “Taylor,” I say. “I’m Taylor.” Something in me relaxes. Just a notch. It’s not joy. It’s not peace. It’s just… not lying. Jules nods like they’re filing it away. “Taylor. Alright. You hungry?” I should say no. I should conserve everything. But my stomach chooses that moment to growl loud enough to be heard over the city. Jules laughs. “Yeah. That’s what I thought.” We weave through the crowd, past souvenir shops and bars that aren’t even pretending to be subtle. The street smells like spilled beer and perfume and something sweet baking somewhere close. My heart won’t stop doing this jittery thing, like it’s trying to sprint out of my chest. Every time someone brushes too close, I flinch. Every time a man’s voice gets too loud behind us, my mind flashes to my dad’s, low and dangerous, saying, “You are not—” and then cutting himself off because the words were too ugly to finish. Jules leads me down a side street where it’s quieter. Not quiet, because New Orleans doesn’t do quiet. But quieter. The buildings here feel more lived-in. Less like a postcard. They stop at a corner store and push the door open with their shoulder. Cold air hits me like a blessing. Inside, Jules grabs two bottles of water without asking. I hover, panicking, because what if they expect me to pay for both? What if this is the part where the trap snaps shut? At the counter, Jules slides one bottle toward me and then digs in their pocket. Coins. A crumpled bill. Not enough, I can tell. They glance at me. “You got that five?” they ask, casual. Relief floods me so hard it’s almost embarrassing. “Yeah.” I hand it over, pretending my fingers aren’t shaking. We pay. We leave. No alarms. No cops. No concerned adults materializing out of the humidity to send me back. Outside, Jules twists their cap around and drinks half the bottle like they’ve been wandering the desert. I drink too, slower, trying to make it last. “Thanks,” I say. “Don’t thank me,” Jules replies. “You paid.” “Still.” They look at me, eyes sharp. “So where you sleeping tonight, Taylor?” My mouth opens and closes. The answer is nowhere. The answer is I didn’t get that far. The answer is my escape plan was basically a middle finger and a prayer. Jules watches my face and their expression changes—just a flicker of something like recognition, like seeing a reflection in dirty glass. “Yeah,” they say softly, like they’ve just confirmed something. “Thought so.” My throat tightens again, but this time it’s not the name. It’s everything else. The fear. The anger. The stupid, traitorous part of me that misses my little brother even though he didn’t say a word when I told them. The part of me that wants to go home and also wants to burn it down. “I can’t go back,” I say, and I don’t mean to say it out loud. It just slips out, raw. Jules doesn’t ask why. They don’t do the pity face. They just nod like, yeah, no kidding. “Me neither,” they say. And there it is. The crack in their armor. We stand there on the sidewalk with the city moving around us, the saxophone still faint in the distance like a heartbeat, and for a second I can almost believe in the idea of not being alone. “What happened?” I ask, immediately regretting it because it’s none of my business. Jules’s jaw tightens. Their fingers tap the side of their water bottle too fast. “Long story,” they say. “Not telling it to someone I met five minutes ago.” Fair. “I’m not telling mine either,” I say, and I’m trying to sound tough, but it comes out small. Jules’s mouth twitches. “Good. Don’t. People hear your story, they think they own it.” I stare at them. “You talk like you’ve been here awhile.” “I have.” They glance down the street, like they’re checking for someone. “This place… it’ll swallow you if you let it. But you can survive if you’re not stupid.” “I’m not stupid,” I say automatically. Jules raises an eyebrow. I sigh. “Okay, I might be a little stupid.” “Honesty,” Jules says. “We love to see it.” They take another sip, then nod toward the shaded side of the street. “Come on. There’s a park a few blocks over. You can sit, think, freak out privately. Figure out a plan.” “A plan,” I repeat, like it’s a foreign language. Jules starts walking, and I hesitate.
