That would have been comforting. A person could be found. We staged controls. I was escorted into my office after hours. The memo paper in my desk was removed and replaced with a tamper-evident package containing ten sheets, serial-marked, initialed by Security, and photographed. I was watched while I locked the drawer. The key went into a tagged envelope. The envelope went into a safe. The safe was monitored. Two nights later I opened the drawer under supervision. The package remained intact. On top of it, unsealed, lay a single additional sheet of memo paper with no serial marks. It was not from the controlled batch. I did not touch it until the memetics specialist cleared it for embedded patterns. Then I read it. > **FOUNDATION INTERNAL MEMO** > **To:** L. Sato > **From:** L. Sato > **Re:** You’re being used as a calendar > > Don’t ask them about “temporal.” They will hear *bargaining.* > > It’s learning how you decide what’s real. It will feed you contradictions until you stop checking. > > You have to keep checking. Even when it hurts. > > The breach is not loud at first. It is *administrative.* > > —L “Administrative” bothered me more than “breach.” I lived inside administration. We were all paper and locks and procedures pretending to be stronger than teeth. PSY ran me through cognitive interviews. I answered the same questions until my answers began to feel rehearsed and therefore suspicious. Had I experienced stress? Yes. Had I been sleeping? Poorly. Had I been exposed to any entities known for manipulation? Not directly, but “directly” is a word people cling to like it’s a spell. They administered a baseline memetic screen. Negative. They asked if I heard a voice when I read the notes. I said no, but I noticed my own tone when I read them in my head: clipped, impatient, like I was scolding myself for being slow. TA attempted temporal verification by comparing note content with future events. The first note warned about airflow changes. No breach occurred. Facilities eventually filed a separate request, rerouting vents in Wing C for mold control. Nothing happened. TA called that a point against time travel. PSY called it “displacement and fixation.” I called it a delayed sentence. --- ### Addendum 3: Contradictions The notes arrived faster after that—every few days, then daily. Always memo paper. Always my handwriting. Sometimes folded into my lab coat pocket after it had been hung in a locker with a numbered seal. Sometimes taped under my keyboard. Once, slid beneath my pillow. The content shifted from warnings to arguments, like I was fighting myself across an abyss. > **FOUNDATION INTERNAL MEMO** > **To:** L. Sato > **From:** L. Sato > **Re:** You already died > > You remember the smell of smoke in the stairwell? That was you. That was your hair. > > Don’t go to the lower archive on the 24th. You go anyway. You always do. > > —L There had been no smoke in any stairwell. I wrote down that fact in my personal log, underlining it, as if ink could nail reality in place. Another note arrived two hours later. > **FOUNDATION INTERNAL MEMO** > **To:** L. Sato > **From:** L. Sato > **Re:** Stop writing logs > > Your underlines are a tell. They know you’re scared because you *underline.* > > You are training it how to lie better. > > —L That was true. I underlined when I was scared. I stopped underlining. Then I hated myself for obeying. PSY suggested the phenomenon resembled “externalized self-harm ideation” shaped by my familiarity with Foundation documentation. TA countered that the physical impossibility of paper appearance in sealed environments suggested a spacetime irregularity. Security proposed a contained entity with access to office materials: SCP-███ (a cognitohazard with a history of inducing written compulsions) was briefly flagged as a candidate. I had never been assigned to that wing, but “never assigned” did not mean “never exposed.” The Foundation taught me that. They moved me to a monitored room with no paper. I was given a tablet. My meals arrived on plastic trays. The walls were bare. The third night, I woke to the sound of paper sliding across concrete. There was a memo sheet on the floor near the door, as if it had been pushed under a gap that did not exist. > **FOUNDATION INTERNAL MEMO** > **To:** L. Sato > **From:** L. Sato > **Re:** This is the part where you start doubting your eyes > > If you see the note appear, look away. Don’t watch. It *likes* being seen. > > The breach starts when you agree that contradictions don’t matter. > > The door code is not 7731. It will be 7731 when you forget. > > —L I stared at the keypad. The code had always been 7731. I had typed it every day for months. The note said it wasn’t—unless I forgot. I typed 7731. The door opened. My throat went dry, because both outcomes felt like proof of something I couldn’t name. TA seized on this as evidence of retroactive alteration—if the note was correct in a reality where the code differed, then my memory had been overwritten. PSY seized on it as evidence of suggestibility—if the note could make me doubt something trivial, it could make me doubt anything. I couldn’t tell which interpretation was kinder. --- ### Addendum 4: The “Breach” That Hadn’t Happened On 03/24/20██, the date referenced in the “lower archive” note, I was assigned to PSY for further evaluation. I was not scheduled anywhere near the archives. I tried to be grateful. At 10:13, I found a note in the pocket of the scrubs they had issued me—scrubs that had come sealed in plastic. > **FOUNDATION INTERNAL MEMO** > **To:** L. Sato > **From:** L. Sato > **Re:** It isn’t claws. It’s stamps. > > They will call it a breach because “breach” is a word with teeth. > > But it’s a policy update. A reclassification. A form that routes the wrong way. > > When the file moves, it moves *it.* > > Don’t sign. Don’t initial. Don’t accept the packet. > > I’m out of time. I’m sorry. I’m sorry. I’m sorry. > > —L At 10:19, an administrator arrived with a packet for me to initial: a revision to the environmental controls audit. It was mundane. It was exactly the kind of thing I would sign without looking, because that was how the machine ran. My hands shook. I asked what it was for. The administrator looked annoyed, like my hesitation was a kind of sabotage. I read it anyway. The routing code at the top referenced Wing C—the same wing Facilities had rerouted. The revision authorized transferring archived ventilation logs from Records to a different storage unit “for consolidation.” The storage unit was the lower archive. I did not initial. I said I needed confirmation from my supervisor. I said it too many times, like a mantra. The administrator left, irritated. I watched the door after he was gone, expecting paper to slide in like a tongue. PSY later told me that refusing to sign was “a positive assertion of agency.” TA later told me that refusing to sign might have “averted a causal pathway.” That night I found another note, crumpled, as if someone had gripped it too hard. > **FOUNDATION INTERNAL MEMO** > **To:** L. Sato > **From:** L. Sato > **Re:** You didn’t stop it, you delayed it > > It will come through someone else. It always does when you try to be the hero. > > Stop thinking in single timelines. Stop thinking you’re the main version. > > I can’t remember your face anymore. Is that me or is that it? > > The vents are singing again. > > —L The last line made me nauseous because I could hear the ventilation in my room: a thin, steady hiss. It had always been there. It sounded like nothing until the note told me it was singing. I pressed my palms to my ears and tried to decide whether I was hearing metal and air, or hearing fear. --- ### Addendum 5: Current Status TA never proved time travel. They never proved an entity did it either. The notes continued. They grew messier, ink blotted by what looked like tears or water damage, sentences collapsing into fragments. > **FOUNDATION INTERNAL MEMO** > **To:** L. Sato > **From:** L. Sato > **Re:** PLEASE > > THEY PUT THE PAPER IN YOUR HANDS AND YOU THINK IT’S YOURS > > IT ISN’T YOURS > > DON’T LET THEM MAKE YOU THE AUTHOR > > I CAN’T HOLD THE LINE I CAN’T HOLD I CAN’T > > —L PSY asked me if I believed the notes were mine. I told them the handwriting was mine and the fear felt familiar, but familiarity was not proof. In the Foundation, nothing was proof. Proof was paperwork, and paperwork was exactly what the notes were made of. I began distrusting my own perception in small ways. I checked the time three times before speaking. I reread emails until the words looked wrong. I watched my hands when I signed my name, half-expecting them to write something else. The worst part was that the notes sometimes helped. They made me cautious, made me notice routing codes and signatures and gaps in procedure. They made me harder to manipulate. Or they made me think I was harder to manipulate, which was the same trap in a different mask. Every sheet was standard Foundation memo paper. Every sheet implied that the Foundation itself—its language, its forms, its rituals—was the medium. TA wanted to catch the moment a note arrived. PSY wanted to catch the moment I decided it mattered. Security wanted to catch whoever was laughing. I wanted to sleep without listening to the vents. I kept the latest note locked in my drawer, even though I knew locks didn’t matter. I did it anyway, because the act of locking something away was a way of telling myself there was still an “away” to lock it into. In the morning, the drawer contained two notes. One was the one I had locked away. The other lay on top of it, clean and flat. > **FOUNDATION INTERNAL MEMO** > **To:** L. Sato > **From:** L. Sato > **Re:** If you’re reading this, it worked > > The breach didn’t happen *yet.* > > That’s the danger. > > —L I sat at my desk and tried to decide whether “worked” meant I had prevented something, or whether it meant the system had successfully trained me to accept a new kind of reality: one where contradictions were normal, where paper appeared from nowhere, where my own handwriting could be used as a mouth. Outside my office, the Site ran as usual. People walked, doors clicked, printers hummed. The world stayed intact in all the ways it always had. I stared at the memo paper until my eyes watered, and I wrote a report about it in the only language I trusted less than my senses.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of the SCP format while delivering a genuinely unsettling psychological horror story. The author successfully merges the clinical, bureaucratic tone of Foundation documentation with the intimate terror of a researcher losing their grip on reality. The structure is particularly effective, alternating between formal containment procedures and personal accounts that gradually deteriorate in reliability. The use of memo format for the mysterious notes is brilliant - it weaponizes the Foundation's own bureaucratic language against itself, suggesting that the very systems meant to contain anomalies might be the medium through which they operate. The characterization of Researcher Sato is nuanced and believable. Their responses feel authentic - the initial skepticism, the growing paranoia, the desperate attempts to maintain scientific objectivity even as their world becomes increasingly unreliable. The progression from confident professional to someone who "checked the time three times before speaking" feels earned and psychologically realistic. The central ambiguity - whether this is temporal anomaly, psychological manipulation, or something else entirely - is maintained expertly throughout. The author resists the temptation to provide easy answers, instead focusing on the erosion of certainty itself. The notes become increasingly desperate and contradictory, but in ways that feel purposeful rather than random. The prose is generally elegant and controlled, with moments of genuine poetry ("paper appeared from nowhere, where my own handwriting could be used as a mouth"). The clinical language occasionally gives way to more visceral descriptions that effectively convey the protagonist's deteriorating state. The ending is particularly strong - it doesn't resolve the mystery but instead focuses on the protagonist's acceptance of a new reality where "contradictions were normal." This feels thematically appropriate and emotionally satisfying without being artificially positive. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the clinical tone becomes slightly repetitive, and a few instances where the horror elements could have been more subtly integrated. The piece also runs slightly long for its concept, though this may be intentional to mirror the obsessive, circular nature of the protagonist's experience. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 6 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 6.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 5.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Scp: Unmarked Doors Archive — Score: 85.7
Prompt:
Write an SCP entry about a series of identical unmarked doors appearing in abandoned buildings worldwide that lead to a massive, architecturally impossible archive. Documents within reference a previous global civilization destroyed by an unspecified containment failure. Foundation researchers discover references to their own organization under a different name, including personnel files for current staff dated centuries ago. Include exploration logs revealing sections of the archive actively being removed by entities resembling hazmat teams who flee when approached, and evidence that O5 Council members have visited the archive without authorization. Third person (exploration team perspective) with recovered document excerpts. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Item #:** SCP-7███ **Object Class:** Keter **Special Containment Procedures:** All confirmed instances of SCP-7███-A (see Description) are to be secured within Foundation-controlled exclusion zones or fronted as condemned sites under cooperating municipal authorities. Entry points are to be monitored by motion-triggered cameras and staffed by no fewer than two armed agents at all times. No personnel are permitted to engage SCP-7███-A without written authorization from at least two (2) Site Directors and one (1) O5 liaison. All documents removed from SCP-7███-B are to be quarantined in an archival containment vault rated for memetic and infohazard screening. Any references to pre-Foundation global governance, prior “containment failures,” or personnel identity parallels are to be forwarded to RAISA and Overwatch Command immediately. Following Incident 7███-Θ (see Addendum 7███.4), internal security has instituted continuous audit of O5 access logs, on-site teleportation signatures, and off-the-books travel requisitions to any SCP-7███-A location. The Ethics Committee has been granted standing authority to investigate anomalous visits regardless of clearance level. --- ## Description SCP-7███ is a phenomenon involving the appearance of unmarked doors (designated SCP-7███-A) in abandoned or condemned structures worldwide. Doors manifest flush with existing interior walls, frequently in corridors or rooms with no architectural justification for a doorway. SCP-7███-A are visually identical: plain industrial wood, no signage, no peephole, no manufacturer marks, and no hardware variations beyond localized wear. All SCP-7███-A exhibit **identical concentric scratch patterns** around the doorknob area, as if repeatedly abraded by the same tool at the same angle. Microscopic analysis indicates the scratches contain trace amounts of ferritic steel and silica consistent across all instances, regardless of door material and country of origin. Opening SCP-7███-A leads to an extradimensional space designated SCP-7███-B: an archive of vast scale exhibiting architecturally impossible geometry. Interior features include: corridors that loop without turning, staircases terminating at doors that open into their own underside, and shelving systems that remain parallel despite visible curvature in hallways. Long-range laser measurements fail beyond ~70 m due to recurring line-of-sight discontinuities; mapping attempts produce contradictory results. SCP-7███-B contains extensive documentation in multiple languages, including extinct scripts and unclassified modern dialects. A recurring set of materials—binders, microfiche drawers, film canisters, and “index slates” of an unknown composite—reference a **prior global civilization** that maintained containment-like practices before suffering an unspecified “containment failure” resulting in civilization collapse. Numerous documents reference an organization functionally equivalent to the Foundation under the name **“The Custodial Continuance”** (translated from multiple languages with consistent semantic meaning: *to keep; to continue; to hold closed*). Of note, personnel files recovered from SCP-7███-B include biographical data matching current Foundation staff, including photographs and biometric measurements, bearing issue dates **centuries prior** to SCP-7███’s discovery. RAISA has verified that several recovered photographs predate the invention of the camera techniques required to produce them. --- ## Addendum 7███.1: Recovered Document Excerpts (RAISA-Translated) **Excerpt 7███-B/Index Slate, Section Header:** > **ARCHIVE: POST-FAILURE TRIAGE / CHRONOLOGY STABILIZATION** > Do not attempt to preserve *names.* Preserve functions. Preserve chains. Preserve doors. > The failure was not a breach. It was *a method that worked once* and then learned to work again. **Excerpt 7███-B/Operational Memo, stamped “CUSTODIAL CONTINUANCE”** > …when the ninth seal was authorized, consensus was recorded as unanimous despite lack of quorum. > The Council will deny entry; the Archive will remember it. > If you are reading this in a later cycle, verify whether your Council also “does not visit.” **Excerpt 7███-B/Personnel File Fragment:** > **SUBJECT:** [REDACTED] (matches Foundation staff: Dr. ███████ █████) > **ROLE:** Cognitive Hazards Division / Field Support > **DATE OF INDUCTION:** 14th year of the Ash Calendar > **NOTES:** Subject exhibits recurring dream-contact with “door rooms.” Do not advise. > **RETENTION INSTRUCTION:** If subject claims prior employment, document the claim. Do not refute. > **CROSS-REFERENCE:** Continuance Directory, Cycle 3 / Cycle 7 **Excerpt 7███-B/Incident Summary, partially burned:** > …global civilization was not ended by war, famine, or plague. Those were symptoms. > The cause was *Containment Failure: Unspecified.* > The Archive was built after, to keep the concept of “before” from disappearing. --- ## Addendum 7███.2: Exploration Log 7███-BE-03 (Third-Person Narrative) **Team:** Mobile Task Force Iota-17 (“Bookbinders”) **Entry Point:** SCP-7███-A instance in condemned hotel, ███████, Argentina **Objective:** Survey, retrieve index samples, locate origin references to “Custodial Continuance.” Team members crossed the threshold at 09:12 local time. From the doorway, the archive presented as a narrow aisle between shelves, lit by indirect luminance with no visible fixtures. Dust was absent. Ambient sound resembled distant paper being handled, though no movement was initially observed. At 09:18, the team reached an intersection where the corridor appeared to branch into three identical aisles. Compass bearings disagreed between members by up to 90 degrees. The point man marked the floor with paint; on return glance, the mark was visible on the ceiling. The team proceeded into the leftmost aisle. Shelving contained gray boxes labeled in a consistent code, interspersed with drawers of microfiche. A binder labeled **“COUNCIL MINUTES—CYCLE 5”** was recovered, its pages thin as onion-skin but resistant to tearing. At 09:31, a low-frequency vibration began, felt through boots rather than heard. Loose paper in open boxes fluttered toward the aisle’s end, as if drawn by airflow. The team advanced and observed a broad service corridor opening into a bay filled with wheeled carts. At 09:34, the first entities were observed: four humanoid figures in pale, featureless hazmat-like suits with dark visors, moving in coordinated silence. They did not acknowledge the team, but their pace increased when the team’s lights fell on them. Each carried crates marked with a simple symbol resembling a bracketed door: **[ | ]**. One figure pushed a cart loaded with sealed boxes. Another held a hand tool shaped like a rotary rasp. The tool’s head matched, in rough profile, the concentric scratch pattern seen on SCP-7███-A doorknobs. When Agent Hsu called out, the figures froze. All visors oriented toward the team simultaneously. No facial features were visible, but the synchronized movement was interpreted as attention. At 09:35, the figures fled deeper into the bay, turning between shelves with efficiency suggesting familiarity. Iota-17 pursued for 40 m before the corridor “folded” visually: the team observed the fleeing figures enter a doorway-sized gap between shelves that, upon approach, narrowed into a seam. The team returned to the carts. Boxes on one cart had torn labels. One exposed file sleeve contained a photograph of a Foundation ID badge with the name **“O5-3”** printed in an older typeface, beneath the header **CUSTODIAL CONTINUANCE / OVERSIGHT NODE.** The photograph’s issue date read: **Cycle 6, Year 201** (local calendar unknown). At 09:47, the team withdrew. The original threshold was located without difficulty, contradicting earlier spatial inconsistencies. On exit, the paint mark from 09:18 was found on the floor again, but smeared in a circular pattern consistent with the doorknob scratches. --- ## Addendum 7███.3: Exploration Log 7███-BE-07 (Recovered Audio Transcript) **Team:** MTF Iota-17 **Entry Point:** SCP-7███-A instance in derelict library, ███████, Japan **Objective:** Locate “post-failure triage” wing referenced in recovered slate. The team entered at 22:06. The interior opened into a vaulted hall whose ceiling could not be seen. Shelves formed terraces like stadium seating, each level stacked with cabinets. The air smelled faintly of ozone and old adhesive. At 22:19, the team encountered a signboard reading **“REMOVAL IN PROGRESS—DO NOT CATALOG”** in multiple languages, including modern English. Underneath, a smaller line read: **“If you are Foundation, you are late.”** At 22:23, two hazmat-suited entities were observed loading cabinets into a rectangular aperture of darkness standing upright like a doorway without a frame. The aperture made no sound. Cabinet edges distorted slightly as they passed through, as if submerged. Agent Varga raised a camera. Both entities turned; one produced a small device emitting a clicking tone. Camera feeds suffered frame loss for 11 seconds. When video resumed, the entities were gone, but the aperture remained, now reduced to a hairline slit. The slit closed from top to bottom like an eyelid. At 22:31, the team located an open file drawer labeled **“VISITORS—UNAUTHORIZED”**. Inside were thin sheets, each bearing a single line and a stamp. Recovered sheet #4 read: > **VISITOR:** Oversight Council (3 members) > **CLEARANCE:** Not filed / Not requested > **ESCORT:** None > **NOTES:** They know where the door is. They always have. Recovered sheet #9 read: > **VISITOR:** “O5-█” (one individual) > **NOTES:** Asked for *the old roster.* Left with it. At 22:40, the team heard footsteps ahead—unarmored, human cadence. Rounding a shelf, they found an empty reading desk with three chairs still warm to the touch (thermal camera measured 33–35°C). On the desk lay a Foundation-style authorization form, older paper stock, unsigned. The header read: **“CONTINUANCE INTERNAL TRANSIT REQUEST.”** The destination field contained only: **ARCHIVE / COUNCIL SHELF.** The team withdrew at 22:55 without further contact. --- ## Addendum 7███.4: Incident 7███-Θ (Internal Security Memorandum) On ██/██/20██, motion cameras at SCP-7███-A-19 (secured site in rural France) recorded the door opening at 03:14 with no personnel present. A figure in a dark suit entered without visible hesitation. Facial recognition was blocked by sensor noise localized to the subject’s head and shoulders. However, gait analysis and body metrics matched **O5-2** with 87% confidence. At 03:21, the same figure exited carrying a flat case. The door closed. The subject departed the exclusion zone on foot; thermal imaging lost the subject at the treeline, consistent with teleportation or anomalous extraction. Subsequent inspection of SCP-7███-B via authorized entry found a section previously mapped as “Council Minutes—Cycle 5” missing entirely. Shelving remained, but all binders, labels, and dust impressions were absent as if they had never existed. Around the doorknob area of SCP-7███-A-19, fresh scratches were present—identical pattern, deeper cut. **Note:** Oversight Command has denied unauthorized visitation. SCP-7███-B documentation indicates such denials are expected. --- ## Closing Note (RAISA Summary) SCP-7███-B appears to be both record and mechanism: an archive that documents the aftermath of a “containment failure” while actively preventing certain records from persisting. The removal teams are not confirmed hostile, but their actions correlate with loss of information critical to understanding SCP-7███ and the named predecessor organization. The recurrence of identical scratches suggests a standardized method applied across all doors, possibly by the same group conducting removals. The presence of “unauthorized visitor” logs naming the Council, alongside contemporary security footage consistent with O5 activity, indicates internal compromise or foreknowledge. Further exploration is suspended pending resolution of the question repeatedly appearing in recovered materials, stamped in the same ink across centuries: > **“IN WHICH CYCLE DID YOU BEGIN CALLING IT THE FOUNDATION?”**
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This SCP entry demonstrates exceptional adherence to the Foundation's clinical documentation style while weaving a complex narrative about cyclical civilizations and institutional memory. The piece successfully captures the distinctive voice of SCP documentation - dry, bureaucratic, yet increasingly unsettling as implications unfold. The writing excels in several key areas. The technical formatting is flawless, matching authentic SCP entries with appropriate redactions, classification levels, and procedural language. The concept is genuinely creative and unsettling: doors leading to an archive documenting a previous civilization's "containment failure," with current Foundation personnel appearing in centuries-old records. This creates a compelling sense of cosmic horror through institutional dread rather than overt supernatural elements. The exploration logs effectively build tension through careful pacing and atmospheric details. The description of architecturally impossible geometry (corridors that loop without turning, paint marks appearing on ceilings) creates genuine unease. The hazmat-suited entities removing documents adds urgency and mystery without over-explaining their nature or purpose. Character actions remain believable within the SCP universe's constraints. The exploration teams behave professionally and logically, their reactions appropriate to the anomalous situations they encounter. The implied unauthorized O5 visits create institutional paranoia that feels authentic to the Foundation's secretive nature. The prose maintains clinical precision while building dread through accumulating details. Phrases like "the failure was not a breach. It was a method that worked once and then learned to work again" demonstrate sophisticated horror writing that trusts the reader's intelligence. The recurring motif of identical scratch patterns provides effective continuity across different sections. However, the piece has some limitations. The characters, while believable, lack individual personality due to the clinical documentation style - though this is arguably appropriate for the format. Emotional engagement operates primarily through intellectual horror rather than character connection. The ending, while thematically strong, could benefit from slightly more resolution or a clearer sense of escalating threat. The writing avoids common pitfalls: it's neither overwrought nor purple, maintains consistent tone throughout, and earns its dark implications through careful worldbuilding rather than cheap shock tactics. The concept feels genuinely original within the SCP framework, combining familiar elements (anomalous spaces, institutional conspiracy) in fresh ways. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 12 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 12.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Classic sci-fi: Offworlder (Le Guin) — Score: 89.1
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi: Offworlder (Author style: Le Guin) Write a chapter following a young diplomatic envoy sent to address tensions on a distant human colony where humanity has diverged into distinct subspecies through both natural adaptation and separation of lineages. Against protocol, the envoy slips away from official functions to walk the streets alone, encountering markets, ordinary citizens, and social structures that contradict the official briefings. Upon returning to their quarters, the envoy is reprimanded by Command, and is tasked with approaching the stationed Minister of Science (a political posting rather than scientific). A challenging conversation ensues, in which the envoy's wits and will are tested, by a seasoned political operator looking to test the mettle of the offworlder. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
They had briefed Aster all the way down the gravity well: the Colony of Sile, established two hundred and nine years prior by a splinter of the Equatorial Consortium, environmentally harsh, politically delicate. Its people had adapted—some by selection, some by design—to thin air and high ultraviolet. Distinct lineages had been kept apart “for health,” “for tradition,” “for stability.” There were tensions between the Highstone communes and the River-basin assemblies, between those called the Longbreathed and those called the Deepblooded. The briefing spoke of “subspecies,” and said the word as if it were a neutral classification, a technicality like the difference between basalt and granite. Aster’s job was to be neutral, a diplomatic surface: smooth, reflective, giving back what the other wanted to see. Aster was nineteen standard years and had never been trusted with anything that mattered until now, which was either a mark of talent or of expendability. In the receiving hall of the Governor’s House—the House cut into the living rock, all cool shadow and pink lamplight—the formalities went on without end. There were speeches with translations that lagged a second behind, there were strings of titles like beaded necklaces, and there were the carvings, everywhere the carvings: a stone frieze above the dais showing a woman with serpent-hair holding a mirror; a doorway lintel with a figure hunched under a sphere, its back bent as if under the weight of the world. Earth myths, the briefings had said, “used as a unifying cultural referent.” Unifying. Aster watched the Longbreathed delegates—tall, narrow-chested, their skin clouded with a faint opalescence to protect against the sun—watch the Deepblooded—stockier, dark-eyed, with the capillary flush of those who lived close to water. They did not look unified. They looked like people trained to stand in a room without moving. At some point Aster stopped being able to tell protocol from performance. The words slid by. The air tasted of stone dust and dried herbs. In that moment of fatigue, Aster did something simple and unforgivable: when the ceremonial exchange of gifts began and everyone’s attention fixed on a latticework of hammered copper presented in the name of the Governor, Aster let their assigned aide fall behind, turned into a side corridor, and kept walking. There was no alarm. No hand clamped down on their shoulder. There was only the corridor, the hush of rock, the coolness that seeped into the bones. Doors opened onto smaller rooms with low tables, onto storage alcoves and passages that went down, down. Aster followed the smell of air that was not conditioned and perfumed, but alive. A service door stood ajar. Through it came light. Outside, the city did not look like a colony in the briefings. It looked old. Not ancient, not ruined, but as if it had grown there for a long time, fitted to the stone the way lichen fits to a rock. Buildings rose in steps along the slope, blocks of pale stone cut tight and clean. Between them ran narrow streets and stairs worn shiny at the edges. The sun was sharp. Above, the sky held that particular blue that means thin air; it made the distance between things feel deceitful. Aster blinked and walked downhill until the sounds of people found them: a child’s high shout, the clatter of ceramic, the low murmur of bargaining. The market was under awnings of woven reed and synthetic cloth. Vendors sat behind slabs of stone and wood, their goods arranged in a kind of deliberate disorder—bundles of dried fungus, beads cut from river glass, small carved figures. The air smelled of salt and roasted grain. People moved with a watchfulness that was not fear, exactly, but attention: heads turning, eyes tracking. Aster had been told that the lineages lived apart. Yet here, in the press of bodies, there was no clear separation. A Longbreathed woman with hair braided close to her skull leaned over a tub of fish beside a Deepblooded man in a sleeveless tunic, their shoulders nearly touching. Aster saw a third kind of person too—short, sinewy, pale as ash with wide pupils—who must have been from the high caves. No one in the briefings had mentioned them. Aster stopped at a stall where stone tiles were laid out like playing cards. Each tile bore a carved glyph: an eye, a spiral, a hook, a hand. The seller, an older person with a scar that crossed their mouth, watched Aster with a neutral gaze. “Offworld,” they said in Trade, the consonants softened by local accent. Not a question. A statement of fact, like naming the weather. Aster nodded. “Yes.” The seller turned over a tile. It showed a figure with wings and a man’s face, falling. “Who is that?” Aster asked, though they knew, or thought they did. “You know him,” the seller said. “He thought he could be the sun.” “Icarus,” Aster said. The seller’s scarred mouth moved, almost a smile. “We carve him because the stone remembers. The stone tells us: don’t fly too close. Don’t go too high. Don’t forget the ground.” Aster picked up another tile. A woman holding a thread. “Ariadne.” “She helps,” the seller said. “But only if you listen. Only if you take the thread and don’t cut it.” Aster looked up. Across the market, on the wall of a public cistern, a long band of glyphs ran like writing. There was Medusa again, her snakes stylized into a pattern of rivers. There was Atlas, but instead of a sphere he held a dome with a map of stars. The myths were not merely references. They were arguments, warnings, instructions. “You put Earth stories on your walls,” Aster said, more to test the seller than from curiosity. “We put our stories on our walls,” the seller corrected. “They came from Earth, yes. So did you. But the stone is here. So the stories are here now.” Aster felt a small, unreasonable relief at being corrected. It meant the world could still surprise them. It meant the briefings were not the whole truth. A group of young men passed, laughing, pushing at each other. One wore the silver throat-ring of a Governor’s House attendant, another had the red cord that marked a River-basin assembly runner. They slapped hands and separated without looking back. Aster saw, in a gap between bodies, a woman with a basket of bread stop to speak to a boy with the pale high-cave eyes; she touched his cheek with her thumb as if he were her own child. The boy flinched, then leaned into it. Social structures contradicting briefings: not neatly segregated, not purely hostile. Complicated, and alive. Aster bought one tile—Ariadne, because of the thread—and tucked it into their pocket. They walked until their lungs began to complain at the altitude, until the narrow streets opened onto a small plaza with a dry fountain. The fountain basin was carved with glyphs of sea creatures—dolphins and whales—on a planet with no sea. Aster sat on the rim, feeling the stone’s stored cold. They listened to the city breathing. When they returned to the Governor’s House by way of a side stair, it was too late to pretend they had simply taken a wrong turn. Their aide found them in the corridor outside their assigned quarters, face pale with controlled panic. “Envoy,” the aide said, using Aster’s title like a shield. “Command is waiting.” The comm unit in the room was already live. The screen showed the angular, unblinking face of Command Liaison Sen Varr, half-lit by shiplight. Behind him, the flag of the Consortium hung as if it could impose gravity. “You were absent,” Sen Varr said. Not raised voice, not anger—worse: certainty. “I went for a walk,” Aster said. “You went alone.” “Yes.” “You broke protocol. You exposed yourself. You exposed the mission.” Aster’s throat tightened. In the market, offworld had been a fact. Here, it was an accusation. “I needed to see,” Aster said. “The briefings—” “The briefings are curated intelligence,” Sen Varr cut in. “Not a travel guide. Your function is to maintain the ceremonial sequence, present our goodwill, receive their declarations, and relay them accurately. You are not here to ‘see.’” Aster looked down at their hands. Their fingers had stone dust under the nails. They had forgotten to be clean. Sen Varr leaned forward. “You will not repeat this. You will attend the remaining functions. And,” he paused, as if savoring the word, “you will go speak with the Minister of Science.” Aster blinked. “The Minister of Science is part of tomorrow’s panel.” “You will speak tonight. In private. He has requested it, after hearing of your… excursion.” Aster’s pulse hitched. “He requested me.” “He requested to assess you,” Sen Varr said, as if correcting a naive child. “Minister Orm is a political appointment. He holds the portfolio that manages lineage policy. He is not a scientist; he is a gate. You will go to him and you will not improvise. Understood?” Aster’s mouth was dry. “Understood.” Sen Varr’s gaze sharpened. “One more thing. Do not mention what you observed in the streets. It is not relevant.” The screen went dark. Aster stood for a long moment, hearing the faint hum of the Governor’s House vents. In their pocket, Ariadne’s tile pressed against their thigh like a secret. They thought of the thread and the maze and the part the hero never told: that the thread is given, not taken. Minister Orm’s rooms were in a wing that looked outward over the city. The corridor was lined with stone plaques carved in glyphs, each plaque lit from below. Aster recognized one: a figure with a mouth full of stars. “Cassandra,” murmured the attendant who led them. “She tells and is not believed.” The door opened. Minister Orm was not old, but he had the kind of settled face that meant he had been in power long enough to be bored by it. His skin was the honey-brown of someone from the middle altitudes; his eyes were very dark. He rose as Aster entered, not to honor them but to control the room by moving first. “Envoy Aster,” he said in careful Trade. “Welcome. Sit.” There was no offer of drink. No small talk. The room itself was spare: stone walls, a table of polished basalt, shelves holding a few objects that looked ceremonial rather than personal. On the far wall a carving showed a man with a lion’s skin over his shoulders, club raised. “Hercules,” Aster said before they could stop themselves. Orm’s gaze flicked to the carving, then back to Aster. “Yes. Strength. Labor. A useful myth for officials.” Aster sat, hands on their knees. “Command told me you wished to assess me.” Orm’s mouth curved slightly. “Command told you? Good. We like clear channels. We have had trouble with channels here. With lineages, with assemblies, with the Highstone communes. With offworlders bringing us solutions we did not ask for.” Aster kept their face still. “I am here to listen.” “To listen,” Orm repeated, as if tasting the word and finding it thin. “And yet you walked the streets alone. That is not listening. That is—what do you call it?—fieldwork.” Aster felt heat in their cheeks. “I wanted to understand the place I’m speaking to.” “Understanding is dangerous,” Orm said calmly. “It complicates policy. Tell me, Envoy: what did you see in the market?” Aster hesitated. Sen Varr’s order pressed like a hand on their spine. But Orm’s question was a hook; to refuse to answer would be to be caught, and to answer falsely would be to be owned. “I saw people,” Aster said. “Living together more than our intelligence suggests.” Orm’s eyes narrowed, satisfied, not surprised. “You saw what you were not supposed to see.” “I saw that the lineages aren’t sealed compartments,” Aster said, finding their voice. “Not in ordinary life.” Orm leaned back. “Ordinary life,” he said, as if it were a concept offworlders carried in their luggage. “Do you know why we created the Ministry of Science?” “To oversee adaptation policy,” Aster said, reciting. “To name things,” Orm corrected. “To make categories. ‘Longbreathed.’ ‘Deepblooded.’ ‘Subspecies.’ Words with sharp edges. If you can name, you can count. If you can count, you can ration. If you can ration, you can rule.” Aster’s mouth went slightly open. They shut it. “So the Ministry is not about science.” Orm smiled without warmth. “Science is a story we tell to make power sound inevitable. We carve Hercules on the wall to make labor sound noble. We carve Cassandra to make dissent sound doomed. We carve Medusa to make the enemy monstrous.” He gestured toward the shelves. On one sat a small stone head with snakes for hair, the eyes blank. “Do you know why that one is here?” “To ward off evil,” Aster said, remembering a childhood lesson. “To remind me,” Orm said softly. “That anyone can be turned into a monster by a story.” Aster felt the thread in their pocket like a tug. “Then why request me tonight? Why test me?” Orm’s gaze held theirs. “Because you are young. Because you walked alone. Because you might not be fully trained into your own story yet.” He leaned forward. “Offworlder: tell me what you will report.” Aster’s heart thudded. The easy answer—what Command wanted—rose to their tongue: that the city was tense, the lineages volatile, the Ministry competent, the Governor cooperative. But that answer would be a cut thread. It would lead them deeper into a maze built by other people. Aster looked at Orm’s face, at the calmness that could be kindness or cruelty depending on what it needed to be. “I will report what is useful,” Aster said carefully, “and what is true.” Orm’s eyebrows rose. “Both? That is ambitious.” Aster swallowed. “Truth is useful. Eventually.” For the first time Orm laughed, a short sound. “Eventually,” he echoed. Then he sobered. “You will learn that ‘eventually’ is where governments bury inconvenient facts. Listen to me, Envoy. Your Command wants a clean narrative: subspecies in conflict, Ministry as mediator, Consortium as benevolent arbiter. My rivals want a different narrative: offworld interference, lineage pride, resistance. The streets you walked have their own narrative, which nobody in this room is paid to hear.” Aster’s hands tightened on their knees. “But I heard it.” Orm’s eyes sharpened again. “Did you? Or did you hear what pleased your conscience? The market can look like unity because people must eat. Hunger makes treaties that politics breaks.” Aster thought of the woman touching the boy’s cheek. That hadn’t been hunger. That had been something else—something like kinship, or pity, or habit. Ordinary life. “It wasn’t only food,” Aster said. Orm watched them a long moment. “Good,” he said finally, as if marking a point on an invisible tally. “You’re not entirely made of slogans.” He stood, ending the conversation as he had begun it, by moving first. He walked to the window and looked out at the stepped stone city, the lights beginning to come on like low stars. “You want to be a thread-holder, Envoy,” he said without turning. “Ariadne with her ball of string. But remember: the thread can also be a noose. If you report too much truth, you will hang yourself. If you report too little, you will hang us, slowly.” Aster rose as well, compelled by the weight of his words. “What do you want from me, Minister?” Orm turned then, and his face in the low light looked carved, as if he too were one of the glyphs on the wall—an emblem of something older than a job title. “I want to know,” he said, “whether you will be a mouthpiece or a person. Whether you will fly like Icarus because you think you can touch the sun, or whether you will learn the shape of the ground.” Aster felt again the stone under their fingers at the fountain rim, cold and patient. “I don’t know yet,” they admitted. Orm nodded, as if that were the only honest answer he could respect. “Then you may be worth the trouble.” He gestured toward the door. “Go back to your quarters. Attend your functions. Smile the right smiles. And when you can, walk again—but not alone. Take someone from the streets with you. Learn their story from their mouth, not from my ministry’s categories.” As Aster left, the corridor plaques seemed to watch. Cassandra with her star-filled mouth. Medusa with her river-snakes. Atlas bending under a dome of mapped stars. The myths were not unifying, Aster thought. They were warnings carved into stone: about power, about pride, about seeing what you are not supposed to see. In their pocket, Ariadne’s tile warmed against their skin, as if the thread had been there all along, waiting for a hand willing to hold it without cutting.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of Ursula K. Le Guin's literary style, successfully capturing her characteristic blend of anthropological observation, philosophical depth, and restrained prose. The author has created a compelling narrative that fulfills the prompt's requirements while maintaining thematic coherence throughout. The worldbuilding is particularly strong, presenting a believable human colony where adaptation has created distinct lineages without falling into crude biological determinism. The integration of Earth mythology as living cultural symbols rather than mere decoration shows sophisticated thinking about how cultures evolve and adapt stories to new contexts. The stone carvings serve as both atmospheric detail and thematic reinforcement, creating layers of meaning that reward careful reading. Aster emerges as a well-realized protagonist whose youth and inexperience feel authentic rather than contrived. Their decision to break protocol and explore the streets alone is believable given their character setup, and their internal conflicts between duty and curiosity drive the narrative effectively. The character's growth feels organic rather than forced. Minister Orm is expertly crafted as a complex political figure who defies easy categorization. His conversation with Aster crackles with intelligence and subtext, revealing him as neither villain nor ally but something more interesting—a pragmatic operator who understands the machinery of power while maintaining some capacity for genuine assessment of others. His dialogue feels natural while carrying significant thematic weight. The prose style successfully emulates Le Guin's approach: clear, precise, and deceptively simple while carrying deeper currents of meaning. The author avoids purple prose while maintaining rich descriptive passages that serve the story's themes. The pacing is well-controlled, moving from ceremonial tedium through street-level discovery to political confrontation without feeling rushed or meandering. The thematic exploration of truth versus narrative, the complexity of colonial adaptation, and the tension between official stories and lived reality demonstrates sophisticated engagement with science fiction's capacity for social commentary. The mythological framework provides structure without becoming heavy-handed. The ending strikes an appropriate note of uncertainty and possibility, avoiding both false optimism and unearned darkness. Aster's admission of not knowing what they will become feels honest and leaves room for future development while providing satisfying closure to this chapter. Minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the mythological references feel slightly forced, and some descriptions that edge toward being overly literary, though these never seriously detract from the overall effectiveness of the piece. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18

+ Biopunk: Polymerase Chain Reaction — Score: 83.2
Prompt:
Biopunk -- Polymerase Chain Reaction Write a chapter set in a near-future post-apocalyptic world where corporate genetic engineering was designed with built-in obsolescence—engineered DNA lasting only one generation to maximize profits before societal collapse. Follow a biohacker working with salvaged equipment to splice viable food crops for their settlement using rapidly degrading genetic material. As world building / window dressing, include details about jury-rigged lab equipment, and the physical toll (and unexpected upsides) of using untested genetic modifications as medicine. The plot of this chapter is centred around a black market contract. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The solar rig was a rectangle of scavenged glass and bruised silicon lashed to the roof with copper wire and prayers. On clear days it fed the lab a steady trickle; today it flickered like a tired eyelid, voltage spiking and sagging in time with the dirty clouds dragging themselves over the broken skyline. The lights didn’t so much turn on as decide, moment to moment, not to turn off. Kestrel watched the multimeter needle dance and kept her hand on the knife switch anyway. The switch was an old breaker from a metro substation, mounted to plywood with hose clamps. When the panel surged, it kept her centrifuge from screaming itself apart. When it dipped, it kept her thermocycler from forgetting what temperature meant halfway through a run. The thermocycler had never been a thermocycler, not really. It was a repurposed drink cooler wrapped in insulation foam, with two Peltier tiles on either side, a salvaged CPU fan, and a cracked microcontroller that still remembered how to count to thirty-five. A strip of nichrome wire inside provided heat when the sun was stingy. A thermistor taped to an aluminum block fed temperature readings back to the controller—when the tape held. Across the bench, a rack of PCR tubes sat nested in a block of milled aluminum. Each tube held a few microliters of hope: template DNA, primers, nucleotides, polymerase. On paper, it was the same reaction corporations used to sell the future. In practice, it was a tiny ritual performed with dubious reagents and a power supply that wanted to die. Kestrel’s settlement wanted food. Not just any food—food that could survive the dust storms, the alkaline rain, the late frosts that came out of season like old debts. Before the collapse, AgroDyne and its competitors had promised drought-proof maize, saline-tolerant rice, blight-resistant tubers. They’d delivered, too. For one generation. The obsolescence had been elegant: engineered traits encoded with built-in expiry. “Proprietary genetic containment,” the brochures had called it. Gene cassettes designed to self-silence after meiosis. Recombination traps that shredded the insert during gamete formation. Epigenetic locks keyed to chemicals only AgroDyne sold. Farmers could buy seed, harvest, eat, sell—but they couldn’t save. Not if they wanted the traits to persist. The corporations had made biology into a subscription service. Then the money stopped mattering, and the subscription ended. The modified plants still grew—once—but their children were ghosts of the promise: weak stalks, brittle leaves, yields that collapsed like tired lungs. Kestrel had been a grad student when the first riots started. She remembered lectures about “biosecurity” and “gene flow” delivered in windowless halls with biometric locks. She remembered the day her advisor stopped coming to campus and nobody replaced him. She remembered walking home past a burned-out AgroDyne kiosk with a poster still clinging to the glass: *ONE SEED. ONE WORLD. ONE BRAND.* Now she worked in a room carved out of a gutted dental clinic, its walls lined with shelves made from filing cabinets and shipping pallets. The dental chair was gone; in its place sat a lab bench made from a door. The autoclave was a pressure cooker wired to a temperature probe. The laminar hood was a clear plastic storage bin turned on its side, with a HEPA filter from a vacuum cleaner and a fan meant for a server rack. When she needed “sterile,” she wiped everything down with ethanol distilled in a pressure-cooker still and prayed her hands shook less than yesterday. The multimeter needle twitched again. The thermocycler beeped—an optimistic chirp—and began its cycle. Denature, anneal, extend. Over and over. A polymerase chain reaction, a little engine that turned scarcity into abundance, at least on a molecular scale. Kestrel flexed her fingers, feeling the ache in the joints. The ache had a name: the price of her last experiment. The settlement’s medic, Mara, had brought her a vial of something two months ago, wrapped in foil and secrecy. “Black market,” Mara had said, as if the words alone were a contagion. “Not AgroDyne. Something else.” It had been a gene therapy vector in a cold chain that had failed three times on the way to them. A viral capsule carrying a modification designed to upregulate clotting factors and boost immune response—sold, before the collapse, to wealthy preppers and private security contractors. The kind of people who wanted to bleed less and heal faster when the world turned sharp. Kestrel had taken it because her hands were always cut. Because lab work in a broken world meant scavenged glass and dull blades and infections that killed the careful. Because every fever in the settlement was a coin flip, and she was tired of flipping. The injection had burned like solvent. The first week she’d sweated through her blankets, hallucinating pollen storms in the dark. The second week the cuts on her knuckles stopped reopening. The third week she noticed she wasn’t bruising the way she used to. The unexpected upside was that she could work longer. The toll was that her body felt *louder*—heart pounding harder, skin itching with a restless vigor, sleep shallow and full of teeth. Her hair had started coming in thicker at the temples, an odd vanity in a life that had no mirrors that weren’t cracked. Mara monitored her, worried about thrombosis, about immune overreaction, about cancer. Kestrel took her own blood smears under a salvaged microscope and looked for the story in the cells, reading clusters of platelets like tea leaves. The therapy had been untested on anyone who wasn’t a client with a lawyer. If it turned her blood to sludge in a year, there’d be no recall, no class action, no compensation. Just a corpse and a settlement down a biohacker. That was why she didn’t take contracts lightly. A knock at the door—three taps, a pause, two taps—broke her focus. The signal they’d agreed on after the last time someone wandered in while she was running gels and ruined a day’s work with their curious breath. She flipped the knife switch to isolate the thermocycler, letting it run on the capacitor bank for a minute, then opened the door. Rook stood in the hall, rain on his jacket, goggles pushed up into his hair. He smelled like wet concrete and smoke. Behind him hovered a stranger, small and wrapped in a patched coat whose pockets bulged with things that clinked softly. Their face was hidden behind a respirator with the filter taped on. “Contract,” Rook said, because he always said the word like it was a warning. Kestrel’s eyes went to the stranger’s hands. Gloves. Good. People who understood contamination were rare. “Come in,” she said. “Wipe your boots.” They stepped into the lab, and the stranger’s gaze swept over everything: the jury-rigged centrifuge made from a cordless drill mounted in a wooden frame, the gel electrophoresis box that used aquarium wire and a phone charger, the rack of pipette tips washed and re-used until they went cloudy, the battered laptop running open-source software to control the thermocycler. “You’re Kestrel,” the stranger said through the respirator, voice muffled and genderless. “We heard you can make traits stick.” “I can make things *try*,” Kestrel said. “Nothing sticks if the genetics are designed to rot.” The stranger reached into their coat and set a small hard case on the bench. The case was foam-lined. Inside were three cryovials, each labeled with a corporate logo that made Kestrel’s stomach tighten: AgroDyne’s old helix-mark, faded but unmistakable. “Salvage from a vault,” the stranger said. “Pre-collapse stock. Not seed. Not product. Source.” Kestrel didn’t touch the vials. “That’s radioactive,” she said, meaning *dangerous* in every way that mattered. If it was real, it was the kind of material people killed for: original lines before the obsolescence triggers were spliced in, or the chemicals that unlocked them, or the master template that let you rebuild. “Not quite,” the stranger said. “It’s plasmids. Trait cassettes. Clean. We need you to amplify them. PCR. Enough copies to inoculate a nursery run.” Kestrel laughed once, sharp. “And how do you plan to deliver plasmids into plants without a particle gun or Agrobacterium cultures?” The stranger’s eyes—dark lenses behind the respirator—tilted toward her makeshift hood. “We heard you have cultures.” Kestrel did. In a mini-fridge that used a car battery and hope, she kept a few strains of *Agrobacterium tumefaciens* alive, fed on homemade agar and sugar. She’d salvaged them from a university greenhouse early on, before the fires. They were finicky, prone to contamination, but they were her best tool for turning DNA into plants. “That’s not the hard part,” she said. “The hard part is the obsolescence. Even if these plasmids are clean, if you’re trying to recreate corporate traits, you’ll just recreate corporate rot. One generation. Then nothing.” The stranger leaned closer. “That’s why we’re paying you. We don’t want their rot. We want the drought tolerance *without* the fail-safe. We want something that breeds true. For our people.” “Our people,” Rook echoed, but his tone made it a question. Kestrel’s gaze flicked to him. Rook handled security for the settlement; he also handled the ugly ethics when they came. His scars had scars. He didn’t like black market work because it brought black market attention. “What’s the payment?” Kestrel asked. The stranger opened another pocket and produced a foil-wrapped brick. Not food. Too heavy, too precise. They unwrapped it just enough to show a stack of sealed blister packs. Antibiotics. Real ones. Not the dubious herbal tinctures Mara brewed or the half-expired pills scavenged from abandoned pharmacies. These were clean, labeled, unpunctured. Kestrel’s throat tightened. She thought of the settlement’s children with infected cuts, the old man with pneumonia who’d coughed himself hollow last winter. She thought of Mara rationing amoxicillin like it was gold. “Where did you get those?” she asked. The stranger’s shrug was small. “We have routes.” “Routes,” Kestrel repeated. Smuggling. Raids. Something worse. “And the other half?” the stranger asked. “We heard you… modify people.” Kestrel’s hand went, unconsciously, to the inside of her elbow where the last injection site had left a faint scar. “I don’t do medicine for strangers,” she said. “You will,” the stranger said, calm. “If you want the rest.” They placed a second case on the bench. This one had a biometric lock. A little screen blinked red, hungry for a fingerprint it would never get. “Inside,” the stranger said, “is a vector. Medical grade. Not the cheap stuff. Designed to repair radiation damage. Upregulate DNA repair pathways. Keep hair from falling out. Keep marrow from failing. We need it. You need it.” Kestrel stared at the case like it was a snake. Radiation had become a background flavor in the wastes—old industrial sites, dirty bombs, leaking reactors nobody had the parts to fix. People got sick in slow, ugly ways. She’d seen it: gums bleeding, bruises blooming, infections that never healed. Her own hands, for all their improved clotting, still tingled sometimes after scavenging runs near the dead zones. “Why come to us?” Rook asked. “Why not your own lab?” The stranger’s shoulders rose and fell. “We had one. We lost it. And we can’t run PCR without stable power. Your solar rig—” they nodded toward the flickering meter “—is better than ours.” Kestrel’s eyes went to the multimeter needle again. It trembled, then dipped. The lights dimmed as if listening. She thought of the plasmids in the first case: a chance to rebuild traits that could make food resilient, not just for one harvest but for every harvest after, seed saved and shared like stories. She thought of the antibiotics and the locked medical vector: salvation with strings, as always. “What’s the catch?” she asked, because there was always one. The stranger’s voice softened, almost kind. “You deliver us stable, inheritable crop lines in six weeks. We deliver the medicine and the antibiotics. You fail, we take back what we’ve given and we take something else. Your lab. Your cultures. Maybe you.” Rook shifted, and Kestrel heard the faint whisper of his knife leaving its sheath. Kestrel held up a hand. Violence in a lab was like dust in a clean room: it ruined everything. She looked down at the PCR tubes, the tiny volumes already cycling through heat and cold, duplicating fragments of DNA that would decay if she didn’t act fast. Corporate genetics had been designed to die; everything she did was a race against entropy. A black market contract just added a timer made of teeth. “I’ll do the amplification,” she said slowly. “I’ll take a look at your plasmids. But if they carry obsolescence triggers—if they’re poisoned—then I’m not your tool. I’m not growing you another monopoly.” The stranger nodded once, as if they’d expected resistance and budgeted for it. “We’re not asking for monopoly. We’re asking for survival.” Kestrel reached for a pair of gloves—washed, dried, patched at the fingertips with tape—and pulled them on. The nitrile was thin, almost transparent. She could feel her pulse in her fingers, steady and hard, like the therapy had taught her blood new songs. She opened the first case, lifted one cryovial, and held it up to the flickering light. Outside, thunder rolled over the ruins. Inside, her jury-rigged thermocycler clicked as it reached the end of its first cycle and began the next, persistent as a heartbeat. In six weeks, either she would have something that could feed her settlement for years, or she would have handed power back to people who still believed life was a product. The multimeter needle jumped. Kestrel adjusted the knife switch, stabilized the current, and began to work.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This biopunk chapter demonstrates strong technical writing and worldbuilding, creating a convincing post-apocalyptic setting where corporate genetic engineering has collapsed. The author successfully integrates scientific terminology and jury-rigged laboratory equipment into the narrative, showing clear research and understanding of both PCR technology and the broader biotechnology landscape. The worldbuilding is particularly effective, with the concept of built-in genetic obsolescence feeling both plausible and thematically resonant. The details of salvaged equipment—the thermocycler made from a drink cooler, the laminar hood from a storage bin—create authentic texture without overwhelming the narrative. The author skillfully weaves exposition about the collapse into character thoughts and dialogue rather than dumping information. Kestrel emerges as a well-developed protagonist with clear motivations and a compelling backstory. Her transition from grad student to settlement biohacker feels earned, and her physical modifications from untested gene therapy add both personal stakes and worldbuilding depth. The writing effectively shows her expertise through her interactions with equipment and assessment of the contract rather than simply telling us she's skilled. The dialogue serves multiple functions effectively—advancing plot, revealing character, and providing exposition. The stranger's measured responses and Rook's protective skepticism feel natural to their roles. The conversation flows organically while building tension around the moral complexity of the contract. The prose maintains a consistent, slightly gritty tone that matches the setting. Metaphors like "voltage spiking and sagging in time with the dirty clouds" and "every fever in the settlement was a coin flip" enhance rather than distract from the narrative. The writing avoids excessive purple prose while maintaining literary quality. The chapter structure builds tension effectively, moving from technical setup through character establishment to the central conflict of the black market contract. The ending appropriately leaves the protagonist at a decision point without forcing resolution, fitting the chapter format. However, some elements feel slightly predictable—the mysterious stranger with valuable but dangerous goods, the moral dilemma between survival and principles. While well-executed, these don't break particularly new ground in post-apocalyptic fiction. The pacing occasionally slows during technical exposition, though this serves the worldbuilding effectively. The emotional complexity around survival versus ethics, the physical toll of untested modifications, and the weight of responsibility for the settlement creates genuine engagement. The stakes feel real and personal rather than abstract. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
