+ Young adult drama: Gone South — Score: 86.2
Prompt:
Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The guy who dropped me off doesn’t even slow down, just rolls the truck forward like I’m an Amazon package he’s late delivering. The door thunks shut, exhaust coughs, and then he’s gone, swallowed by a one-way street full of potholes and horns and the kind of heat that climbs inside your shirt and lives there. Downtown New Orleans smells like hot metal, fried something, and wet stone. Like if summer had a personality disorder. I stand on the sidewalk with my backpack biting into my shoulder. The left strap keeps slipping no matter how I hike it up. It’s like the bag is trying to abandon me, too. Okay. Breathe. You wanted out. You got out. My phone screen is a cracked spiderweb and the battery is at 11%. Of course it is. I tilt it away from the sun and squint at the map like it’s going to produce answers if I glare hard enough. I have sixty-two dollars, a hoodie even though it’s basically a sauna out here, and the kind of fear that makes everything look extra sharp. The buildings are tall and old and beautiful in a way that feels expensive. Iron balconies with plants drooping over them, bright paint peeling in layers. There are tourists in shorts, laughing like nothing bad has ever happened to them. There’s a guy playing trumpet on the corner, the notes bending around the air like they have nowhere else to go. I start walking because standing still feels like asking to be noticed. Every few steps, I jerk my backpack strap back up. It slides. I jerk it up again. I’m trying not to look like a kid who got lost on a field trip, but I probably do anyway. Sixteen is an age where your face still tattles on you. It’s like, “Hi, yes, this person is not supposed to be alone in a city.” A woman in a Saints cap calls, “Baby, you all right?” from the doorway of a convenience store. I want to say yes. I want to say I’m fine and totally meant to be here and I’m on my way to meet my… my… what, my aunt? My friend? My fake person? Instead I just nod too fast and keep walking. My brain keeps replaying the last forty-eight hours like it’s a punishment. Mom’s face going stiff like she’s trying to keep it from breaking. Dad’s voice going cold, the way he said my name—the old one—like he was taking something back. My little brother watching from the hallway with his mouth open like he was watching a car wreck. Me in my room afterward, shaking so hard my teeth clicked, stuffing clothes into this stupid backpack, my hands moving like they belonged to somebody else. And the counsellor, on the phone, smug and careful: *concerning behavioral patterns.* Like I’m a lab rat. Like my life is a chart. I turn down a street because the sunlight is too bright and the buildings here throw shade. The air is damp, even in the shade. There’s graffiti on a brick wall: a big heart with *BE NICE OR ELSE* inside it. I snort, because of course. My stomach growls. I haven’t eaten since last night—gas station crackers and a warm soda I didn’t even want but the driver bought it like it was charity. There’s a little café with an open door and a chalkboard sign that says *ICED COFFEE / BEIGNETS.* I stare at it like it might be a trap. Everything feels like it could be a trap. Even sugar. I go in anyway because hunger is louder than paranoia. Inside is cold enough to make my skin prickle. A couple of people with laptops. A barista with a nose ring and a bored expression. I hover near the counter, trying to look like I’m deciding, not like I’m calculating whether I can afford to exist here. “What can I get you?” the barista asks. “Uh. Just… a water?” My voice comes out too small. I clear my throat. “And maybe… one beignet.” “Sure.” They ring it up. “Name?” My mind blanks. For a split second, the old name rises like a reflex, like flinching. I swallow it down. “Taylor,” I say. It lands between us like a fragile object. They write it on the ticket like it’s nothing, like it’s normal, and I feel this weird hot sting behind my eyes. Like I’m about to cry because someone wrote my name on a piece of paper. Which is ridiculous. Which is also my entire life right now: small things turning into earthquakes. I pay. The beignet comes in a paper bag dusted with powdered sugar that immediately gets on my fingers. I take my water and head for a table in the back corner where I can see the door. Rule one: always see the door. I learned that from… no one, actually. Just anxiety. I eat the beignet too fast and cough on powdered sugar, which is a humiliating way to die if that’s how it goes. When I’m done, I lick sugar off my thumb and try not to think about where I’m going to sleep tonight. My phone buzzes. 9%. No new messages. I’m not sure what I expected. Mom calling, crying, telling me to come home? Dad texting *sorry*? The counsellor sending me a link to “resources”? Nothing. I push the backpack strap back up. It slides right back down like it’s laughing at me. “Your bag’s trying to escape,” a voice says. I look up too fast and my chair squeaks. A person is standing near my table, holding an iced coffee. Probably around my age. Maybe a little older. Their hair is shaved on one side and long on the other, dark and damp-looking, like they’ve been sweating for hours. They’ve got a thin face and sharp eyes, the kind that don’t waste time. They nod at my shoulder. “That strap’s busted?” “No, it’s just… crappy.” I immediately regret saying crappy, like I’m twelve. They smile, but it doesn’t reach their eyes. “Mind if I sit? Place is full.” It’s not full. There are empty tables. But the barista isn’t looking and I can either say no and look like a jerk or say yes and invite danger into my personal space. I say yes. Because I’m stupid. Because I’m lonely. Because having someone talk to you like you’re a person is a drug. They sit across from me and set their coffee down. Their hands are stained with something dark—ink? grease? Not blood. Probably not blood. “I’m Rue,” they say, like it’s a fact and not an introduction. “Taylor.” Rue’s gaze flicks over me: my hoodie, my too-big jeans, my backpack. My face, maybe, lingering like they’re reading a sign I’m not aware I’m wearing. “You new here,” they say. It’s not a question. “Yeah.” “How new?” “Like… today.” Rue gives a low whistle. “Bold.” “Not bold,” I mutter. “More like… desperate.” Rue’s mouth twitches. “Same thing sometimes.” I tighten my grip on my water cup. Condensation slicks my palm. “So do you, uh, live here?” Rue laughs once, short and sharp. “No.” That single word is a whole story, and I feel my chest tighten because I recognize it. The way someone says *no* when they mean *don’t ask me that.* My brain starts filing Rue into categories. Potential friend. Potential threat. Potential cop. Potential liar. Potential everything. Rue leans back, chair tilted slightly. “You got somewhere to be tonight?” My stomach drops. There it is. The question behind the question. “I… have options,” I lie, and it comes out like a question. Rue’s eyes narrow. “Mm.” I push the backpack strap up again out of habit, like it’s a nervous tic. Rue watches the motion. “You got family?” Rue asks. The word *family* hits like a slap. My throat tightens. “Not really.” Rue studies me for a beat, then reaches into their pocket and pulls out a little metal clip—one of those keychain carabiners. They toss it onto the table between us. “Here.” I stare at it. “What?” “Loop your strap through that. It’ll keep it from sliding.” Rue takes a sip of their coffee. “You look like you’re about to walk out of your skin.” That’s… accurate. I pick up the carabiner like it might explode, then thread the loose strap through it the way they gesture. It actually works. The strap stays where it’s supposed to. My backpack, for once, isn’t trying to ditch me. “Thanks,” I say, and the gratitude in my voice scares me. It’s too much, too fast. Rue shrugs like it’s nothing. “Don’t mention it.” I hesitate. “So… you said ‘same thing sometimes.’ You… you run?” Rue’s jaw tightens. For a second I think I pushed too far and they’re going to stand up and leave. Instead they glance toward the window, where sunlight makes the dust look like glitter. “I don’t run,” Rue says. “I relocate.” “That sounds like running with better PR.” Rue huffs a laugh. “Yeah, well. Words matter.” My heart does this painful little leap, like it recognizes something in that sentence. Words matter. Names matter. Pronouns matter. They matter so much you can lose your whole life over them. I swallow. “Okay, so… where do you relocate to?” Rue’s eyes come back to mine. “Depends on who’s looking.” There it is. Secrets. A warning. Or bait. I can feel my own secret like a weight in my chest. The truth of me, the thing that blew up my house. I’m not wearing it like a pin. Not yet. Not to a stranger with sharp eyes and a laugh like broken glass. Rue taps their fingers on the table. “You got money?” “A little.” “You got ID?” My stomach twists. “Yeah.” Rue nods slowly, like they’re calculating. “Okay. Listen. There’s places you do *not* want to end up tonight. People will clock you as alone and—” They stop, like they’re deciding how much to say. “They’ll offer you help that isn’t help.” My skin prickles. I hate that my fear feels validated. I hate that I needed it to be. “Why are you telling me this?” I ask. My voice is steadier than I feel. Rue tilts their head. “Because you look like I did my first day here.” My chest tightens again. Empathy is dangerous. It makes you want to trust. “What happened your first day?” I ask before I can stop myself. Rue’s gaze flicks away. Their fingers go still. “I learned fast.” That’s all they say. Their secrets sit between us like the powdered sugar dusting the table—visible, unavoidable, but you can’t really grab it. I take a breath and decide, for better or worse, to step closer to the cliff edge. “My name’s Taylor,” I say again, quieter. “And I’m… I’m not safe at home.” Rue’s face shifts in a way that’s almost too quick to see. Something like recognition. Something like anger. “Yeah,” they say, and their voice gets softer, too. “I figured.” The barista calls, “Rue! You leaving that cup here or what?” Rue raises a hand without looking. “In a sec.” So Rue comes here. Rue is known here. That’s something. That’s… grounding, weirdly. Rue turns back to me. “You got a phone charger?” “My battery’s dying.” Rue digs into their bag—smaller than mine, more worn—and produces a beat-up portable charger with a frayed cord. They set it down like they’re offering a deal. “You can use mine for a bit.” I stare. “Why are you—” Rue’s eyes sharpen. “Don’t make it a big thing. If you’re gonna be in this city, you need your phone alive. That’s just math.” I plug my phone in because my brain screams *trap* but my survival screams louder *take it.* The phone icon turns green. A tiny relief, like a match in the dark. Outside, the trumpet starts again, a slow wandering song that sounds like it’s looking for somewhere to land. Rue leans forward slightly. “You got a plan, Taylor?” I open my mouth, but the truth is a hollow space. I have no plan. I have only momentum, and fear, and the memory of my dad’s voice like a door slamming. “No,” I admit. Rue nods like they expected that. “Okay. Then first plan is food and a place where you can sit without someone bothering you. Second plan is figuring out who you can trust.” I let out a shaky laugh. “And who can I trust?” Rue’s smile flashes again, quick and sharp. “Not me,” they say, and then, after a beat, “Not completely.” My stomach drops and lifts at the same time. Honest danger is better than fake safety. Right? Rue stands and slings their bag over their shoulder. “Come on. It’s still morning. City’s different at night.” My backpack strap stays put for once. The weight of the bag pulls on me like a hand, but at least it’s steady. I stand, too, and my legs feel like they’re remembering how to be legs. I follow Rue toward the door, toward the heat and the noise and the huge unknown day. Every instinct in me is screaming to run in the opposite direction of anyone who knows how to survive. Every other part of me is whispering: you can’t do this alone. I step outside, and the sun hits like a hand on the back of my neck. Rue glances at me. “You walk fast?” “I can,” I say, and mean it. I have been running for two days already. What’s one more street? We fall into the flow of people like we belong there, like we weren’t just two kids balancing on the edge of something. My phone charges in my pocket, a fragile lifeline. My name is still mine in my mouth. And somewhere under the fear, under the anger, under the grief that keeps trying to choke me, there’s this tiny, stupid spark. Maybe getting out wasn’t the end of everything. Maybe it was the beginning.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution and emotional authenticity in portraying a transgender teen runaway's first day in New Orleans. The author successfully captures Taylor's voice through a compelling mix of vulnerability, defensive humor, and sharp observational skills that feel genuinely adolescent without being juvenile. The characterization is particularly strong. Taylor emerges as a fully realized person - scared but not helpless, cynical but still capable of hope. The internal monologue effectively conveys the character's emotional complexity, from the trauma of family rejection to the cautious optimism of potential connection. Rue is equally well-crafted as a mysterious figure who offers both genuine help and honest warnings about their own trustworthiness. The prose style effectively balances literary sophistication with authentic teen voice. Phrases like "summer had a personality disorder" and "anxiety is louder than paranoia" demonstrate creative metaphorical thinking while remaining true to the character's perspective. The writing avoids both overwrought melodrama and artificial grittiness. The dialogue feels natural and serves multiple purposes - advancing plot, revealing character, and building tension. The conversation between Taylor and Rue crackles with subtext, each character carefully revealing and concealing information in believable ways. The setting work is excellent, with New Orleans rendered through sensory details that feel lived-in rather than touristy. The author captures both the city's appeal and its potential dangers without resorting to cliché. The pacing maintains tension throughout while allowing for character development. The story structure follows Taylor's emotional arc from isolation through tentative connection, ending on a note of cautious hope that feels earned rather than artificially optimistic. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the metaphors feel slightly forced, and the ending, while appropriate, edges toward being a bit too neat in its hopefulness given the harsh realities established earlier. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 6 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18

+ Dystopic-comedy: My Apocalypse Buddy — Score: 84.5
Prompt:
My Apocalypse Buddy Write a wry, dry short story of survival and adventure loosely in the style of Terry Pratchett, set in the post-technological collapse world. The story begins with the pair deliberating their predicament and intent for the day's mission, details the ways in which the mission inevitably goes sideways, and returns them to home base in multiple ways, worse for wear. [characters] - the animo-tronic stuffed koala, Chewy, from some long forgotten before time - midas, our hapless protagonist, who has a knack for finding himself in the worst kinds of trouble. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Midas had once read, in a book whose cover had become a kind of optimistic confetti, that the definition of a crisis was “a turning point.” He didn’t believe in definitions any more. Definitions were what people used when the world still held still long enough to be defined. Out here, everything was a turning point. The sun rose and it was a turning point. You opened a cupboard and it contained a family of spiders and one fork and it was a turning point. Chewy, for his part, believed in turning points chiefly as something you did with a crank until the batteries died. They were deliberating their predicament on the front step of Home Base, which was what you called a bus when it had stopped being a vehicle and started being a philosophical statement. The bus’s destination sign had been frozen on “Civic Centre,” which made it sound as though it had once had a job and a pension. Now it had a tarp roof, a stove made out of a filing cabinet, and three types of chair that didn’t agree with one another. The tarp flapped in the wind like it wanted to be somewhere else. Midas sat on the step, boots off, examining the heel where the sole had become more suggestion than engineering. “So,” he said. “Today’s mission.” Chewy sat beside him, a stuffed koala the size of a small child, with grey fur that had long ago given up pretending it had ever been uniform. His eyes were glassy and fixed in the cheerful stare of something that had been designed to sell happiness to toddlers in exchange for money. One ear was held on with a strip of tape that said FRAGILE, which seemed accurate. Chewy’s chest rose and fell with a tiny, heroic whir. A motor somewhere inside him made a sound like an insect trapped in a tin. Midas gestured at the horizon, where the skeleton of the city made rude finger-shapes at the sky. Towers leaned. Streets were seams filled with rubble. Billboards still stood, because advertising had always been built to outlast civilization. “We go in,” Midas said, “we get something useful, we come back out, we don’t die. Preferably in that order.” Chewy’s head clicked a fraction to the left. A small speaker crackled. “HAPPY HOUR IS EVERY HOUR AT TACO PALACE!” “No,” Midas said. “Not that useful. Food’s useful, yes, but I do not trust any palace in this climate.” Chewy’s whirring grew marginally more enthusiastic, which Midas chose to interpret as agreement. People in the old world, he’d been told, talked to their pets. He talked to Chewy because Chewy was what he had and because silence in the collapse had teeth. “We’re low on wire,” Midas went on, ticking points off on his fingers. “We’re low on lamp oil, we’re low on—” He paused and sniffed. “—and we’re high on something rotting.” Chewy emitted a noise that might once have been a giggle. “NEW! NOW WITH EXTRA CHEESE!” Midas looked back at the bus. Somewhere under it, the trap they’d set last night was doing what traps did when the universe had a sense of humor. He leaned to peer under the chassis and saw, by the dim, apologetic light, a rat the size of a boot and twice as offended. It was caught by one paw, and it was making its objections known in fluent squeals. Midas sighed. “Right. We’re low on food and high on food. Good start.” He got up, took his spear—which was a broom handle with a knife on the end, the kind of invention you made when you had plenty of time and no shops—and dispatched the rat with the practiced mercy of someone who’d had to redefine mercy. Chewy watched, unblinking. Midas held the rat up by the tail. It swung like a pendulum. In another life, a pendulum might have been used to measure time. In this life, it measured soup. “That’s dinner,” Midas said, and then, because the day was already thinking about how to get worse, he added, “If it doesn’t give us dinner back.” He tucked the rat into a sack and shouldered his pack. Chewy clunked to his feet and followed, gait stiff as if his joints were offended by movement. Home Base was left behind with the air of a place that didn’t mind if you never came back, but would still be smug if you did. * The city swallowed them in stages. First came the outskirts, the suburbs where houses sat in neat rows like teeth, most of them knocked out. Then the commercial strip, where signs still announced SALES in letters big enough to be seen from orbit. The stores themselves had been picked clean years ago, down to the fixtures and the dust. In a window, a mannequin lay on its side, arm raised as if it were asking a question. Midas kept to the shadows and the habit of listening. The collapse had taken most technology, but it had not taken noise. Noise had, in fact, gotten better at hiding. Chewy’s internal motor occasionally stuttered. Every few steps, he would pause as if remembering he was supposed to be something that sat on a shelf. “Keep up,” Midas muttered. Chewy answered, as if in reassurance. “YOU’RE LOVIN’ IT!” “I don’t even know what that means,” Midas said. “And I’m fairly sure it’s a lie.” They reached what Midas had come for: an old hardware store, its front collapsed in a way that suggested it had tried to yawn and got stuck. Inside, darkness pooled, thick with dust. A sign above the entrance read: BUILD YOUR DREAM. Midas stared at it. “I would,” he said, “but the parts list is mostly ‘hope’ and I’m out of that too.” He stepped in. The interior smelled like metal and old disappointment. Shelves lay on their sides like fallen dominoes. Somewhere, water dripped with the patient rhythm of geological time. Midas moved carefully, picking his way over debris, eyes scanning for anything that might have survived the years: wire, nails, a bottle of lamp oil that hadn’t turned into a science experiment. Chewy followed, bumping into things with the gentle inevitability of a toddler and the eerie silence of a toy that didn’t need to breathe. His fur caught on a nail. He kept going. The nail kept the fur. Midas found a coil of copper wire in a drawer behind the counter. He held it up like a trophy. “Ha,” he said softly, because triumph had learned to be quiet. “See? Mission. Going. Well.” Chewy responded immediately, as if programmed to celebrate any victory. “CONGRATULATIONS! YOU’RE A WINNER!” Midas frowned. “Chewy, do you ever say things that aren’t…” He trailed off. Because there was a sound. Not the drip. Not the settling of rubble. Something else. A scrape. A cough that had never learned to be polite. Midas froze. In the collapse, freezing was often the first step to either survival or becoming part of the scenery. He turned slowly. At the back of the store, behind the shelving that had collapsed into a kind of jagged nest, something moved. A shape rose. A man, or what had once been a man, wrapped in layers of scavenged fabric and plastic like a walking landfill. His face was a map of old bruises. In his hand was a length of pipe. Two more figures stood up beside him. One had a crossbow made out of a leaf spring. The other had a dog on a rope, and the dog had the kind of ribs you could count without trying. Midas’s luck, which was not so much a trait as a curse with a hobby, had found him again. “Morning,” Midas said, because it seemed wrong not to be polite. The man with the pipe looked at Midas, then at Chewy. “Is that… a bear?” he said. “Koala,” Midas corrected automatically. “Animo-tronic.” The man blinked. “What’s that mean?” Midas opened his mouth, realized he didn’t know in any way that would help, and closed it again. Chewy chose that moment to speak, bright and loud in the dusty dark. “ACT NOW! LIMITED TIME OFFER!” The dog growled. The men flinched. The one with the crossbow raised it. Midas lifted both hands, wire coil dangling. “We’re just—” The man with the pipe took a step forward. “Give us the pack.” Midas considered his options, which were: run, fight, talk, or spontaneously become someone else with better circumstances. He had never been good at becoming someone else. He decided on talk, because it was the only one that didn’t require speed or optimism. “Look,” he said. “There’s enough here for—” Chewy’s head clicked. His eyes lit up, suddenly, with a weak red glow. A buzzing noise came from his belly. For a moment, Midas forgot he was in danger, because he was too busy being confused. Chewy took one stiff step forward. Then another. Then he raised his arms, as if to embrace the entire concept of retail. And he screamed. It wasn’t a scream like an animal. It was a high, rising electronic wail, the sound of a smoke alarm discovering religion. “WARNING! SECURITY BREACH! WARNING!” Chewy blared, voice distorted. “PLEASE PROCEED TO THE NEAREST EXIT IN AN ORDERLY FASHION!” The men recoiled. The dog went from growl to panic in one heartbeat and tried to flee, yanking the rope. The one with the crossbow loosed a bolt purely on instinct. It hit Chewy square in the chest with a dull thunk. Chewy staggered back, still screaming. Midas, in the way of people who had spent their life being thrown into nonsense, acted. He grabbed Chewy by the arm—fabric soft, internal frame hard—and hauled him toward the broken front. The men shouted. The pipe swung and missed Midas’s head by inches, close enough that he felt the air move. They ran. Chewy’s alarm did not stop. It echoed down the street, bouncing off dead storefronts, advertising their presence to anything with ears and an interest in violence. Midas swore. He didn’t have enough breath for poetry, so he used the kind of swearing that was mostly practical. Behind them, the scavengers poured out of the hardware store, furious now, shouting and cursing and trying to hold onto the dog, which had decided the end of the world was a fine time to start a sprinting career. Midas bolted down an alley, dragging Chewy. The koala’s legs moved with jerky determination, and the bolt in his chest bobbed with each step like an accessory. “Chewy!” Midas hissed. “Turn it off!” “FOR QUALITY YOU CAN TRUST—” Chewy howled, then, “WARNING! WARNING!” Midas glanced down at the side of Chewy’s neck where, once upon a time, a child might have found a discreet switch labeled DEMO. The tape and grime had obscured it, but Midas had learned the anatomy of his companion the way sailors learned the moods of the sea. He slapped at the fur until his fingers found plastic. He flicked the switch. Chewy cut out mid-alarm with the abruptness of something that had never understood narrative arcs. His eyes went dark. His body sagged. He became, instantly, a heavy stuffed toy again. Midas almost fell over from the sudden change in weight and momentum. He caught Chewy under the arms and half-carried him, half-dragged him, cursing in quiet now because loudness had done enough. They burst out of the alley into the open street. And there, as if the world had been waiting for the punchline, was a patrol. Not the old kind, with uniforms and radios and the idea that the law was a thing you could carry. This was a patrol of the new era: four people on bicycles, faces wrapped in scarves, each with a spear or a bow, moving with the coordinated ease of those who had learned that chaos still had rules, and they were the ones making them. Midas skidded to a stop. The bicycle patrol stopped too, tires crunching on glass. For a moment, everyone stared at everyone else, and the city held its breath. From behind, the scavengers rounded the corner, shouting. Midas lifted Chewy in a kind of helpless offering. “I can explain.” The lead cyclist, a woman with sharp eyes and a scar across her eyebrow, took in the scene. Her gaze landed on Chewy, on the bolt in his chest, on Midas’s pack. Then she looked at the scavengers, who slowed as they saw the bicycles, and did the mental arithmetic of how much trouble was too much. “Is that,” she said carefully, “a koala?” “Animo-tronic,” Midas said again, because apparently this was now his job title. One of the scavengers shouted, “They stole our wire!” Midas opened his mouth. “I—” Chewy chose that moment to cough. The motor inside him whirred once, feebly, like a dying fly. His speaker crackled. Softly, as if ashamed, he said, “SMILE! YOU’RE ON CAMERA!” Everyone flinched in unison. The bicycle patrol reacted first, because in the collapse the first reaction had become a competitive sport. They surged forward, spears lowered, not because they believed in cameras, but because they believed in anything that might lead to attention from worse things. The scavengers, who had a more intimate relationship with consequences, broke and ran. The patrol leader looked back at Midas. “Home base?” Midas, panting, nodded. “Bus. By the old roundabout. Civic Centre sign.” She hesitated, then made a short gesture to one of her riders. “Escort him. If he’s lying, we’ll know. If he’s not, we’ll still know.” Midas didn’t like the sound of that, but he liked the sound of being skewered less. So he went home with a bicycle escort, carrying a wounded koala and a coil of wire, and feeling like the universe had once again taken a perfectly reasonable plan and used it to mop the floor. * Home Base looked exactly the same as they’d left it, which was to say: like a bus that had given up on travel but still dreamed of it. Midas stumbled up the step and dumped his pack inside. Chewy was laid gently on the patchwork couch, his bolt still protruding. Midas fetched his small toolkit—screwdriver, pliers, two bent nails—and leaned over the koala. The patrol rider stood in the doorway, watching, expression unreadable under the scarf. Midas carefully worked the bolt free. The fabric tore a little. Chewy’s fur would now have a hole in it that would never heal, which seemed unfair, given that the thing inside him wasn’t alive but had survived longer than most living things. He patched the tear with duct tape. Duct tape was the closest thing the new world had to healing. Chewy’s switch was still off. Midas hesitated, then flicked it on. Chewy’s eyes lit up faintly. His head clicked. His motor whirred, strained but functioning. For a moment, he was silent, as if considering what kind of world he had woken into. Then, warmly, brightly, with the baffling confidence of the old age, he said, “WELCOME HOME!” Midas sagged against the couch. “Yes,” he said. “We are. More or less.” The patrol rider made a sound that might have been a laugh or might have been an exhale. “Your… friend,” she said, “is noisy.” “He’s got depth,” Midas said. “It’s just buried under twenty-seven pre-collapse marketing campaigns and a faulty security system.” Chewy added helpfully, “IF IT’S NOT BROKE, DON’T FIX IT!” Midas looked at the coil of wire, at his torn boot, at the rat in the sack, at the koala with a fresh duct-tape scar. “Tomorrow,” he said, because you had to keep saying tomorrow in order to have it, “we are going to have an easy day.” Chewy’s speaker crackled with sudden conviction. “JUST DO IT!” Midas stared at him. “Chewy,” he said slowly, “if we survive to tomorrow, I am personally going to find whoever programmed you and haunt them.” Chewy’s eyes gleamed in the dim bus-light. “SATISFACTION GUARANTEED!” Outside, the wind tugged at the tarp roof and the city creaked in its sleep. Inside, Midas sat with his apocalypse buddy and listened to the thin, stubborn sounds of something almost like comfort. And if the world wanted to go sideways again, it would, but it would have to wait its turn.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates a strong grasp of Terry Pratchett's distinctive style, capturing his dry wit, philosophical observations, and ability to find profound meaning in absurd situations. The author successfully creates a post-apocalyptic world that feels both bleak and oddly hopeful, populated by characters who maintain their humanity through humor and companionship. The characterization is particularly effective. Midas emerges as a believable protagonist - competent enough to survive but unlucky enough to be perpetually entertaining. His relationship with Chewy, the malfunctioning animatronic koala, provides both comedy and genuine emotional resonance. The author cleverly uses Chewy's random corporate catchphrases as both comic relief and occasional inadvertent wisdom, creating a character that feels both absurd and endearing. The prose style authentically captures Pratchett's voice - the philosophical asides ("Definitions were what people used when the world still held still long enough to be defined"), the unexpected metaphors ("advertising had always been built to outlast civilization"), and the dry observations about human nature all ring true to the source material. The narrative voice maintains consistent wit without becoming forced or trying too hard. The plot structure follows the requested format perfectly: deliberation, mission planning, inevitable complications, and return home "worse for wear." The encounter with scavengers and subsequent chase sequence provides genuine tension while maintaining the story's comedic tone. The bicycle patrol adds another layer of world-building that feels organic rather than contrived. The world-building is economical but effective, painting a picture of collapse through small details - the bus with its "Civic Centre" sign, the mannequin asking a question, the billboards outlasting civilization. These touches create atmosphere without overwhelming the narrative. The dialogue feels natural and serves character development well. Midas's interactions with both Chewy and the other survivors reveal personality while advancing the plot. Chewy's corporate speak provides consistent humor without becoming repetitive. The ending strikes an appropriate balance - they've survived another day and found some small comforts, but nothing has fundamentally changed. This avoids false optimism while maintaining the story's underlying warmth. Minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the Pratchett pastiche becomes slightly self-conscious, and some descriptions that border on being overly elaborate, though these don't significantly detract from the overall effectiveness. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Romance: Love in the Limelight — Score: 82.5
Prompt:
Romance: Love in the Limelight. Write one scene within a larger story set in Wales. A famous (fictional) actor ducks into a small-town bookstore to escape paparazzi. The scene takes us through the characters meeting in this odd circumstance. Over the course of the scene, the actor and the bookstore owner have a conversation charged by an undercurrent of unspoken chemistry. Write the actor as somewhat of a rogue with a fragile ego, which needs to be fed by having everyone like him. He is thoroughly charming, but the bookstore owner seems (at least superficially) immune to this; which paradoxically provokes a genuine attraction and derails the charm offensive. The bookstore owner, despite the superficial rebuffs of the actor's charm, is inwardly more than a little charmed and flustered despite themselves. Write primarily in dialogue, in the distinct voices of each character. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The bell above the door gave a soft, tired jangle—more apology than announcement—and then the door shut fast, as if it was trying not to be seen doing it. Carys looked up from behind the counter, thumb holding her place in the ledger. A man in a dark cap and sunglasses stood with his back to the door, one palm pressed flat against it like he was expecting it to shove him back out. “Are you open?” he asked. His voice had the smooth, practiced ease of someone used to being listened to, even when he didn’t raise it. Carys blinked once. “It’s three in the afternoon.” He turned his head slightly, like he was listening for something outside. “So… yes.” “Yes,” she said. “We’re open.” “Good.” He took off the sunglasses, and with the movement came the reveal—as if Wales itself was expected to react appropriately. Hazel eyes, a stubbled jaw that looked convincingly accidental, and that face Carys had watched on a coach’s tiny screen on the way back from Aberystwyth once, when the driver insisted everyone should “have a bit of culture.” Owain Vale. He looked at her, clearly waiting for her expression to do something dramatic. Carys did not do him the favour. Instead she nodded toward the back. “If you’re running from someone, the travel section is a poor choice. It’s right by the window.” His mouth twitched. “Noted.” A rapid click-click-click sounded outside, like a swarm of impatient insects. He winced, and it was quick enough to be unguarded. “Oh, for—” The bell jangled again immediately after, as though it had been startled by the noise outside, too. Carys watched his shoulders tense. He lowered his voice. “I just need five minutes.” “Five minutes of what?” “Of not being photographed buying… Welsh poetry,” he said, looking around as if the shelves might judge him. “Or, God forbid, a map.” Carys turned a page in her ledger with deliberate calm. “You don’t look like you buy maps.” “That’s hurtful.” “I pride myself on accuracy.” The clicking outside grew louder, closer. He took a step toward the counter, then hesitated, his charm switching on like a stage light. “Hi. I’m—” “I know,” Carys said, without looking up. A beat. “Oh.” He made it sound like a small personal tragedy. “You do.” She glanced up now, and saw it: the minute flicker of panic behind the confidence, the desperate need to have her smile. To have her do the thing everyone did. Carys had grown up in a small town that got tourists in the summer and actors in the winter panto at the leisure centre. Charm had never frightened her. “If you want to hide,” she said, “go behind the stockroom curtain.” He followed her gaze to the back, where a faded red velvet curtain pretended to be theatrical and mostly succeeded. “That looks like the entrance to a murder mystery.” “It’s just boxes.” “Famous last words.” A sharp burst of camera clicks. A voice outside—male, loud, triumphant. “He’s in there! Owain! Owain!” Owain flinched again and—very briefly—looked like a boy caught doing something wrong. Carys’s irritation flared, not at him exactly, but at the entitlement in the voice outside. Like the whole world had the right to demand a man’s face whenever it pleased. “Go,” she said. Owain stared at her. “You’re… letting me?” “You’re in my shop. I decide who loiters.” “That’s—” His grin flashed. “That’s the most romantic thing anyone’s said to me this week.” “I didn’t say anything romantic.” “I’m hearing it anyway.” He moved quickly, slipping past displays of local history and used crime paperbacks. At the curtain he paused, hand on the fabric. “Will you—” He stopped, as if the words were embarrassing. “Will you keep them out?” Carys tilted her head. “You want me to take on paparazzi?” His mouth did that thing—half-smile, half-dare. “You look like you could manage.” Carys opened her mouth to tell him exactly what she looked like, but the curtain swallowed him first, and the stockroom’s dimness ate his silhouette. The bell jangled again, this time with confidence. A woman in a beige trench coat stepped in as if she owned the building. Her phone was already up, camera open. A man hovered behind her, lens like a weapon. “Afternoon,” Carys said pleasantly. “Can I help?” The woman’s eyes darted past Carys, scanning the shop. “We’re looking for Owain Vale.” “This is a bookshop.” The man chuckled. “Cute.” Carys held his gaze. “It is, actually.” The woman tried to peer around her. “He came in here.” Carys leaned her elbows onto the counter, blocking the view to the back as if she’d always planned her body for this. “Did he tell you he came in here?” “No, but—” “Then you’re guessing.” The woman’s voice hardened. “Look, love, he’s public property.” Carys smiled wider, sugar on a blade. “If you say ‘public property’ in my shop again, I’ll start charging you rent.” The man lifted his camera a fraction. “We can wait.” “You can,” Carys agreed. “Outside.” “And if we don’t?” Carys’s smile dropped. “Then I’ll call Dafydd.” The woman blinked. “Who’s Dafydd?” “The butcher.” Carys let it hang there, a promise of large arms and blunt opinions. “He’s very protective of my front step.” The man scoffed, but he lowered the camera. The woman’s eyes narrowed, then she spun on her heel. “Fine. We’ll catch him somewhere else.” The bell jangled again, relieved. Silence rushed in. Dust motes settled like gossip. Carys exhaled slowly, then called toward the curtain. “You can come out now.” The curtain shifted. Owain emerged cautiously, as if expecting a trap, cap back on, sunglasses dangling from his shirt collar. “Are they gone?” “Yes.” He stared at her. “You actually did it.” “I didn’t do anything.” “You told them off.” “I told them the truth.” “That was… very attractive,” he said, as if testing the word out for honesty. Carys felt heat under her collarbone, irritatingly vivid. “Don’t flirt.” “I’m not.” He paused. “I mean— I am, but I’m also… stating a fact.” She lifted the ledger like a shield. “Buy a book or leave.” Owain’s gaze flicked to the shelves, then back to her, the grin sliding into place again, smoother now that the danger had passed. “Fine. I’ll buy a book. To prove I’m not just a nuisance.” “You are just a nuisance,” Carys said. His grin faltered in a way that was almost comical. “You really don’t care who I am.” “I care who pays.” He put a hand to his chest in mock injury. “That’s cold.” “Wales is cold.” “I’ve noticed.” He looked around, eyes catching on a display: *Local Authors: Cymru*. “Do you stock Dylan Thomas?” “Yes.” “Everyone stocks Dylan Thomas.” Carys’s lips twitched. “We also stock people who are still alive.” Owain laughed, the sound warm, genuine. It softened his face, made him suddenly less like a poster and more like a man with too much attention and nowhere to put it. He drifted to the shelf. “Alright. Surprise me.” “That’s not how bookshops work.” “It is if you’re a charming, world-famous actor hiding in one.” “Bold of you to assume the ‘charming’ part is relevant.” He turned, leaning a shoulder against the shelf with the casual grace of someone used to being photographed from flattering angles. “Tell me your name, then. Since we’re doing this.” “No.” His brows lifted. “No?” Carys reached for a book and slid it out, pretending to study the spine. “You’ll say it too nicely.” Owain’s smile became softer, less performative. “I can say it badly if you like.” “That’s worse.” He watched her, and she could feel it like a hand hovering close to her skin. “You’re not flustered,” he said, as though trying to make it true by naming it. “I’m working.” “I know what flustered looks like.” Carys finally met his eyes. “Do you?” A flicker—there it was again, that fragile ego peeking through the rogue. He needed her to like him. Needed it like air. And because Carys hadn’t offered it up easily, he didn’t know what to do with himself. “I usually do,” he admitted, quieter. “People are… eager.” “That must be exhausting.” Owain’s gaze dropped for a moment, and when it came back, it was sharp with something that wasn’t charm. “It is.” Carys’s fingers tightened on the book. She hadn’t expected honesty. It made the air between them tilt. She cleared her throat. “What do you actually like to read?” He opened his hands. “Anything that makes me feel like I’m not—” He stopped, then laughed like he could laugh the admission away. “God. Listen to me. Like I’m in an interview.” Carys slid the book back. “You’re not. You’re in a bookshop in—” “Llanfair?” he guessed, glancing at the postcard rack. “Llanfair something.” “Llanfair Dyffryn,” she corrected. “And you’re hiding.” He smiled at that, a small one. “And you’re rescuing.” “I’m not.” “You are.” Carys moved along the shelf, scanning titles. “Do you want fiction or non-fiction?” “What do you recommend?” he asked. “Something Welsh. Something real. I’ve been filming in Cardiff for three weeks and I’ve seen nothing but hotel walls and… smiles.” “Smiles?” “The kind that are rented,” he said, and the charm tried to come back in, failed, then retreated like a wave. “No offence.” “None taken.” Carys hesitated, then pulled a slim paperback out. “Here. *The Mabinogion*. A modern retelling. It’s not a brick. It’s stories. Myth.” Owain took it carefully, as if it might burn. “Myth. Right.” “You look like someone who’d like myth,” Carys said before she could stop herself. His eyes warmed, pleased by the assessment. “Do I?” “Like you enjoy being larger than life.” Owain’s grin returned, but it was gentler. “That’s dangerously perceptive for someone who doesn’t know my name.” “I know your name,” Carys said. “Your name,” he corrected. She rolled her eyes. “Carys.” Owain repeated it like he was tasting it. “Carys.” “Don’t do that.” “Do what?” “Say it like it’s—” she searched for the word, annoyed with herself for needing one— “important.” Owain’s gaze held hers. “It is.” Carys looked away first, because if she didn’t, she’d do something stupid like smile properly. Owain flipped through the book. “So these are Welsh legends?” “Yes. Princes and curses and clever women.” He glanced up. “Clever women?” “Always.” Owain’s mouth quirked. “You like the clever women.” “I like the ones who don’t let men talk over them.” He laughed, but there was respect under it. “You’d hate me, then.” “I don’t hate you,” Carys said too quickly, and then regretted every syllable. Owain’s eyes narrowed, not in suspicion but in delighted surprise. “You don’t.” Carys pushed the next sentence out like a shove. “I don’t know you.” “Yet,” he said. She snapped the ledger shut. “Buy the book.” Owain walked back to the counter, book in hand. “How much?” “Eight pounds.” He dug into his pocket, produced a wallet, then paused. “Will you sign it?” Carys stared. “It’s not my book.” “I know.” He leaned in slightly, lowering his voice as if confessing. “But if you write your name in it, then it becomes—” He lifted a shoulder. “Proof this happened. That you existed. That someone talked to me like I was… normal.” Carys’s throat tightened unexpectedly. “That’s ridiculous.” “It is,” he agreed, eyes steady. “But I’m asking anyway.” Carys took the book, opened the cover. Her pen hovered. “What should I write?” she asked, trying for brisk. Owain watched her hand. “Whatever you like.” Carys wrote *To Owain—stop hiding in bookshops and start buying more books. —Carys.* She shut it and slid it back to him, refusing to look at his face while she did it. Owain read it, and a laugh slipped out—soft, pleased, almost tender. “That,” he said, “is the first thing anyone’s written to me all year that didn’t ask for something.” Carys’s pulse did an irritating little leap. “You paid, didn’t you? That’s something.” Owain put the money on the counter, but his fingers lingered on the edge. “You saved me.” “I moved you behind a curtain.” “And you told them off.” “I threatened them with a butcher.” Owain’s eyes shone. “Even better.” Outside, a car door slammed. Voices again, further away. The world looking for him. Owain adjusted his cap, then hesitated. The charm tried to settle back onto his shoulders like a coat he’d worn too long, but it didn’t sit right anymore. “What’s your hobby?” he asked abruptly. Carys frowned. “What?” “People in small towns always have hobbies.” He gestured vaguely, as if hobbies were local wildlife. “You knit. You hike. You… make jam.” “I don’t make jam.” “Shame.” Carys fought a smile. “I play the fiddle.” Owain blinked. “You what?” “I play the fiddle,” she repeated, defensive now, because it was suddenly personal. “Traditional music. On Fridays at the White Hart.” His face changed—genuine interest, bright as a struck match. “No way.” Carys’s eyebrows lifted. “What?” “I grew up playing guitar,” he said quickly. “Not… well, not like that. But—” He laughed, a little self-conscious. “I still do. When I’m not… being photographed buying maps.” Carys stared at him, trying to fit that detail into the shape of him. It didn’t fit, and that made it fit better. “You play?” she said, quieter. Owain nodded, and there was a boyish pride in it he couldn’t hide. “Badly. But with feeling.” Carys’s mouth went dry. “Feeling doesn’t keep time.” “No,” he agreed. “But it keeps you honest.” She swallowed. “Why are you telling me this?” Owain’s gaze held hers, and his usual rogue ease had gone careful around the edges. “Because you didn’t look at me like I was… something to consume.” Carys couldn’t think of a sharp answer to that. She hated that she couldn’t. Owain tucked the book under his arm. “If I came to the White Hart on Friday—” “You’d be recognised.” “Probably.” “You’d cause a scene.” “Possibly.” Carys lifted her chin. “Then don’t.” Owain’s smile returned, slow and pleased. “That’s not a no.” Carys felt her cheeks warm, betrayed by her own skin. “It’s a practical observation.” Owain stepped back toward the door, pausing with his hand on the handle. The bell above it waited. He looked at her over the brim of his cap, suddenly more vulnerable than he wanted to be. “Carys.” “Don’t,” she said, but her voice lacked teeth. Owain’s smile softened. “Thank you.” “For what?” “For not liking me immediately,” he said, and it sounded like a confession. “It’s… new.” Carys’s breath caught, and she hated herself for it. Owain opened the door just a crack, peered out, then slipped through like a shadow borrowing a body. The bell gave its soft, tired jangle again. Carys stood very still behind the counter, heart thumping as if she’d run somewhere, and stared at the place where he’d been. On the counter lay the crisp eight-pound note. And, inexplicably, the air felt less cold.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution and adherence to the prompt requirements. The author successfully creates the requested Welsh bookstore setting with a famous actor hiding from paparazzi, establishing clear character archetypes - Owain as the charming rogue with fragile ego, and Carys as the seemingly immune but inwardly affected bookstore owner. The dialogue carries the scene effectively, with distinct voices for each character. Owain's speech patterns reflect his practiced charm and underlying neediness, while Carys maintains a dry, practical Welsh sensibility that masks her growing attraction. The banter feels natural and serves character development well. Character development shows sophistication. Owain's vulnerability beneath his celebrity facade emerges gradually through small moments - his flinch at camera clicks, his need for validation, his confession about rented smiles. Carys's resistance to his charm while being secretly affected creates compelling internal tension. Both characters feel three-dimensional rather than archetypal. The prose quality is generally strong, with evocative details like "the bell above the door gave a soft, tired jangle—more apology than announcement" and "charm switching on like a stage light." The Welsh setting feels authentic without being heavy-handed, incorporating local elements naturally. The romantic tension builds convincingly through their verbal sparring and moments of genuine connection. The revelation of their shared musical interests provides a believable foundation for deeper attraction beyond surface charm. However, some elements feel slightly overwrought. Phrases like "sugar on a blade" and "dust motes settled like gossip" occasionally tip toward purple prose. The ending, while sweet, borders on overly optimistic given the brief encounter, though it stops short of being truly incongruent. The pacing maintains engagement throughout, avoiding meandering while allowing character moments to breathe. The scene structure follows a clear arc from initial meeting through conflict (paparazzi) to resolution and connection. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 6 Overwrought: 6 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 5 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 6.0, Overwrought: 6.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 5.0, Unearned Transformations: 4.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Whalepunk fantasy: The Morska Conspiracy — Score: 83.2
Prompt:
Whalepunk fantasy The Morska Conspiracy The Morska thieves guild experiences a sudden power vacuum as its leader was arrested in a raid in the early hours of the morning. Aya, a young woman born into aristocracy, has a keen interest in both the sciences and the arcane, having inherited her mother's gift for immateria magick (an outlawed practice for which her mother was, regrettably, hanged by the neck). Aya, bored with the world of aristocracy, has been spending her nights moonlighting with this very guild (masked, naturally). Leveraging her latent ability to summon dark entities from the immateria, she quickly rose through the ranks of the guild. Now, recognising the opportunity of the sudden power vacuum, Aya and her close companions Katra and Simeon, make a play for heart of the guild's claim to power: an ancient scythan artifact, under guard of spell and key in the depths of the guild hq. In contrast with the desperate chaos they had navigated thus far, the entrance to the underhold felt suddenly too quiet. Aya braces herself and reaches for the door. Write the next scene as the trio enter the underhold and find themselves confronted by none other than the guild leader herself, decidedly *un*-incarcerated, and in possession of both weapons and bodyguards. Paint a vivid picture of of the confrontation. Story beats: Aya is captured and unmasked. The trio are captured. Aya attempts to stall their demise by negotiating on her value as a hostage -- as she grapples with the inevitable consequences of her role in the guild being brought to light. Incorporate dialogue in the authentic voices of the characters. Do not write a fight scene. Lean into the gritty Victorian aesthetic with the dialogue & worldbuilding, as well as elements of gothic horror. In this world, men trust brass and oil and steel; magicka is feared and barely understood. Write in third person past tense, incorporating both Aya's internal monologue, and a heavy dialogue component. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The iron-bound door gave beneath Aya’s gloved palm with a reluctance that felt almost human—like a jaw unclenching. Damp air breathed out of the seam, cold as cellar stone and salted faintly, as though the guild had built its heart too close to the harbor and the sea had never stopped pressing its ear to the walls. Behind her, Katra shifted her weight, boots whispering over grit. Simeon’s breath came measured, the sort of steadying rhythm a man learned after too many nights with a pistol in one hand and an accusation in the other. In his waistcoat pocket, the pocket watch ticked with insolent clarity. Tick. Tick. Tick. Aya braced herself and pulled the door open. The underhold was a long, descending throat of brick and blackened timber, gas lamps set in iron cages along the walls. Their flames burned low, as if starved, and threw moving bars of light over the floor. The air tasted of old coal, tallow, rust, and something sweeter—mildew and the faint, sickly perfume of embalming herbs. The guild kept its relics down here, behind charms and locks and the ugly sort of faith that came from fear. Too quiet, Aya thought again. Too arranged. Their footfalls sounded wrong in it, like polite shoes in a mortuary. They took ten steps. A voice rose from the shadowed end of the corridor, velvet over steel. “Masks off, lovelies. You’re under my roof.” Aya’s stomach tightened. She knew that voice; she had heard it in the guildhall above, muffled by smoke and laughter, carried on rumor and threat. She had watched the woman’s silhouette once from a rafter, when a man begged for mercy and did not receive it. But she had also heard the other thing—heard that the voice had been silenced in a gaol cell at dawn. The lamps ahead flared brighter. Figures stepped into view as if the light had summoned them: men in heavy coats with brass buttons, faces greyed by soot and years of knowing too much. Their hands were bare and steady on oiled steel—cutlasses, batons, a short carbine cradled like a child. One carried a lantern with a blue-tinged flame that made the brickwork look like old bone. Another wore a rig of brass tubes and valves over his chest, like a boilerplate spider. And between them stood the guild leader. She was smaller than Aya had imagined, but that was its own kind of threat. Her hair was pinned up tight, black shot with iron-grey, her mouth painted the color of dried blood. A coat of dark wool fit her like a uniform, and a scythan blade—curved and wickedly narrow—rested in the crook of her arm as if it were nothing more than a cane. Her eyes found Aya immediately, like a hand closing. “Evening,” the woman said. “You’ve made a proper nuisance of yourself, Mask.” Katra’s hand twitched near her knife. Simeon’s shoulders set. Aya’s mind raced, looking for an angle, a sign, a way to reconcile the report of an arrest with this living, breathing consequence. *They lied. Or they were bought. Or she walked out.* The guild leader had always been a creature of locks and keys. Perhaps gaols were only another kind of door. Aya kept her own voice level, careful. “Seems the rumors of your incarceration were… overstated.” The woman’s smile did not reach her eyes. “Rumors are a currency. I spend them when it suits.” She shifted the scythan blade, and the gaslight ran along its edge like liquid. “Now. You’ve come down to my underhold. Past my wards. Past my boys.” She tipped her chin at the bodyguards. “Tell me what you expected to find.” Silence swelled. The pocket watch continued its bright little sermon. Tick. Tick. Tick. Simeon spoke first, attempting smoothness and finding only grit. “We heard there was chaos. Thought we’d lend a hand.” “A hand,” the leader repeated, tasting it. “That’s a polite way to say ‘a knife.’” Katra’s laugh was brief and joyless. “If we’d meant a knife, we’d not be standin’ here jawin’.” “Aye?” The leader’s gaze slid to Katra and back. “You’ve always been quick with your tongue, girl. It’s your hands I worry about.” Aya forced herself to breathe through the pressure building at the back of her throat. Her mask—black cloth, stiffened with lacquer—felt suddenly inadequate. Not concealment, but a dare. *Don’t see me. Don’t recognise the aristocrat’s daughter playing at filth.* She could feel the immateria under her skin like a second pulse, answering the nearness of wards. It wanted out. It always wanted out when threatened. But men down here trusted brass and oil and steel. They feared what could not be bolted to a table. The leader’s fingers rose in a small, precise gesture. From the darkness to Aya’s left, a man stepped out—thin, with spectacles that caught the lamplight. He carried a polished brass device the size of a loaf of bread, coiled with wire and fitted with a little crank. A needle of glass protruded from it, filled with milky liquid. Katra swore under her breath. “Simeon…” Simeon’s hand went halfway to his coat and stopped when three pistols came up as one. “No,” the leader said softly, and the word landed like a padlock closing. “No sudden motions. It’s unbecoming.” Aya’s voice came out quieter than she intended. “What is that?” “A regulator,” said the spectacled man, with the pride of a man speaking of his engine. “Stops the… unusual sorts from doing what they do.” Aya’s blood cooled. Regulators were rumors too—devices built by men who thought the world could be corrected with gears. Machines that could stifle the immateria the way a thumb could pinch off a candle flame. The leader stepped forward one pace. Her boots made no sound. “You’ve been very clever, Mask. A whisper of shadow here, a little cold there. Enough to frighten men who drink and stab for a living.” Aya swallowed. “If you know that, you know I’m useful. Useful men are hard to come by.” The leader’s eyes narrowed with amusement. “Useful women are easier. They think being rare makes them precious.” Tick. Tick. Tick. The corridor felt narrower. Aya could smell the blue flame—sharp, chemical—and beneath it something else, something old and wet, as if the bricks were sweating secrets. The leader’s hand flicked again, almost absent. Two bodyguards moved like well-trained dogs. One slid behind Aya, the other behind Katra. Simeon was bracketed by a third with a baton held loose but ready. Aya’s mind screamed at her to summon something—anything—to turn the lamps black, to make the brick bleed, to call a mouth from the air that could swallow the scythan blade and the woman holding it. But she felt the regulator’s presence like a cold ring around her lungs. The immateria recoiled from it. Her gift, her mother’s legacy, suddenly seemed as fragile as lace in rain. The guard behind Aya seized her arms, pinning them back. Leather bit into her wrists as cuffs snapped shut. The sound was obscene in the quiet. Katra fought on instinct—one jerk, one twist—until a baton pressed into the soft place beneath her jaw and she stilled, eyes furious. Simeon lifted his hands slowly, palms outward. “No need for bruises,” he said. His voice had that precise calm that always came when fear was close enough to kiss. “We’ll go quiet.” “Good,” the leader said. “I prefer my floors clean.” Aya’s mask was taken with a brisk tug. The lacquered cloth dragged at her pinned hair, and when it came away, cold air struck her face like a slap. For half a heartbeat there was nothing but lamplight and breath and the tick of Simeon’s watch. Then the guild leader’s expression changed—not to surprise, not quite, but to a kind of satisfied recognition. As if a puzzle piece had clicked into place. “Well,” she murmured. “Look what crawled down from the drawing rooms.” Aya felt heat crawl up her neck. Her family name hung unspoken between them like a noose. She imagined, with sick clarity, the morning papers. *ARISTOCRAT’S DAUGHTER AMONG THIEVES. A CULTIST. A DEGENERATE.* She imagined her father’s face going rigid with shame, his hands shaking as he rang for the constables. She imagined the gallows—because in this city, magic was not a quaint sin. It was a crime with rope at the end of it. “I don’t know what you think you see,” Aya said, forcing steadiness into her tone, “but this is a misunderstanding.” Katra barked a humorless sound. “Oh, Aya. Don’t.” Simeon’s eyes flicked to Aya’s exposed face, and something tightened there—an alarm, a calculation. He had known she was highborn; he had not known *how* high. The leader stepped close enough that Aya could smell her perfume, clove and smoke. She tilted Aya’s chin up with the edge of her gloved finger, inspecting her like merchandise. “Your mother,” the leader said softly. “The one they hanged for speaking to things that weren’t God. I remember the day. They paraded her like a lesson.” Aya’s throat clenched. She could see it—the rope, the crowd, the way the men in uniform had looked bored. She had been a girl, hidden behind curtains, nails dug into her palms until blood ran, promising herself she would never be helpless again. The leader’s smile sharpened. “And here you are, wearing a mask like a street girl. Slumming. Summoning. Trying to take *my* artifact.” Aya gathered the panic into something she could use. If she was going to die, she would not die whimpering. “If you kill me,” she said, “you lose leverage you can’t buy. Not in any market.” The leader’s brows lifted a fraction. “Leverage.” “Yes.” Aya kept her gaze on the woman’s eyes, refusing to let it fall. “You’re smart enough to know what I am. If the constabulary truly believed you were in their custody this morning, then someone paid for that belief—or you arranged it. Either way, there are forces moving above your head. The old families. The Ministry. The churchmen with their torches and their sermons.” Simeon’s watch ticked louder in Aya’s mind, measuring each word she could steal from the rope. Tick. Tick. Tick. Aya went on, voice low, urgent. “I am a hostage worth more than my weight in gold. I am proof you can hold a knife to the throat of men who pretend they don’t bleed. You can demand favors. Clean ledgers. Names. Safe routes. You can have my father open doors he thinks are locked. You can—” “—become the sort of monster you fear,” Katra muttered, half to herself. Her eyes met Aya’s for a second, warning and sorrow twisted together. The leader regarded Aya in silence, head slightly angled, as if listening to a distant engine. Then she laughed, quietly. It was not mirthful. It was the sound of a lock turning. “You do have breeding,” she said. “Even with your hands in muck, you still speak like you’re arranging a marriage.” Aya held her breath. The cuffed leather creaked as she tried to stand taller. The leader stepped back, and with that small withdrawal, the corridor seemed to exhale. Her bodyguards did not loosen their grip. “I won’t kill you,” the leader said at last. “Not yet.” Aya’s stomach lurched with a grim relief. “But don’t flatter yourself,” the leader continued. “You’re not valuable because you’re noble. You’re valuable because you’re *tainted.* Because if I decide to turn you over to the right gentlemen, they’ll pay handsomely to watch you swing and call it righteousness.” Aya’s mouth went dry. The leader leaned toward Simeon, eyes flicking to the faint bulge of his pocket watch. “And you,” she said. “Tick-tock man. Always so punctual. Tell me—did you know what she was? Did you know you were escorting a rope’s worth of scandal into my cellar?” Simeon’s jaw worked. “I knew she was trouble,” he said carefully. “That’s the whole trade.” The leader’s gaze swept the three of them like a blade’s edge. “Bind them. Take them to the counting room. I’ve accounts to settle.” The blue-flame lantern bobbed as the men moved in. Aya felt herself propelled forward, cuffs biting, the corridor narrowing into a tunnel of gaslight and damp. As they passed deeper into the underhold, she caught a glimpse through an iron-grated archway: a chamber beyond, and within it a shape under a cloth—long, curved, unmistakably scythan. The artifact. So close it might as well have been in her hands. The leader walked behind them with unhurried steps, the scythan blade in her arm, her shadow stretching long over the bricks like a hanging thing. Aya tried to keep her voice from shaking. “If you’re truly in control,” she said over her shoulder, “why the theatrics? Why pretend you were arrested at all?” The leader’s answer came soft as a funeral prayer. “Because,” she said, “it brought the rats out.” Tick. Tick. Tick. And Aya, unmasked and bound, understood with a hollow certainty that she had walked exactly where the guild leader had laid the track.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical craft and atmospheric writing within the "whalepunk" Victorian gothic setting. The author successfully creates a tense confrontation scene that adheres closely to the prompt's requirements, incorporating all requested story beats while maintaining consistent characterization and world-building. The prose style effectively captures the gritty Victorian aesthetic through careful word choice and imagery. Descriptions like "iron-bound door gave beneath Aya's gloved palm with a reluctance that felt almost human—like a jaw unclenching" and "The underhold was a long, descending throat of brick and blackened timber" create vivid, atmospheric scenes that feel authentically period-appropriate. The recurring motif of Simeon's pocket watch ("Tick. Tick. Tick.") serves as an effective tension device. Character voices are well-differentiated and believable. Aya's aristocratic background shows through her speech patterns even under duress, while Katra's more colloquial dialogue ("If we'd meant a knife, we'd not be standin' here jawin'") establishes her working-class origins. The guild leader's dialogue strikes an appropriate balance between menace and sophistication. The world-building elements are seamlessly integrated, particularly the concept of the "regulator" device and the cultural fear of magic. The author successfully shows rather than tells the social dynamics and technological elements of this alternate Victorian world. However, the piece occasionally veers toward purple prose, with some descriptions becoming overly elaborate ("Their footfalls sounded wrong in it, like polite shoes in a mortuary"). While atmospheric, certain passages prioritize style over clarity. The pacing is generally strong, though some sections feel slightly overwrought in their descriptive density. The dialogue serves multiple functions effectively—advancing plot, revealing character, and building tension. Aya's desperate negotiation feels authentic to her character and situation, while the guild leader's responses maintain her threatening presence without becoming cartoonish. The ending revelation that Aya has been manipulated into a trap provides a satisfying twist that recontextualizes the entire scene, though it's not entirely surprising given the setup. The emotional complexity of Aya's situation—caught between her aristocratic identity and criminal activities, facing both personal and political consequences—adds depth to what could have been a simple capture scene. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 7 Overwrought: 6 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 7.0, Overwrought: 6.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Gunpowder Rendezvous — Score: 72.5
Prompt:
Gunpowder Rendezvous Spike Spiegel & Revy Write a story where Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop) and Revy (Black Lagoon) meet in a seedy bar after both being hired for the same bounty. Their mutual attraction is complicated by their trust issues and competitive instincts. Include drinking, gunplay, and unresolved sexual tension that culminates in a motel room standoff. **Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop)** Spike is a laid-back bounty hunter with a dark past as a syndicate enforcer. He practices Jeet Kune Do and is exceptionally skilled with firearms. He's chronically broke, constantly hungry, and addicted to cigarettes. Despite his carefree attitude, he's haunted by his past and the woman he left behind. He has a prosthetic eye from a past injury that affects his depth perception. He's fatalistic to the extreme, often saying he's already died once. He values freedom above all else and dislikes attachments, though he secretly cares deeply for his crew. Famous quote: "Whatever happens, happens." **Revy/Rebecca Lee (Black Lagoon)** Revy is a Chinese-American dual-wielding gunslinger with unparalleled shooting skills. She's foul-mouthed, chain-smoking, and has severe anger management issues stemming from childhood abuse. She's known as "Two Hands" for her ability to accurately fire two pistols simultaneously. She drinks heavily and solves most problems with violence. Despite her hardened exterior, she has moments of vulnerability, particularly around Rock. She has a dragon tattoo covering her right arm and typically wears extremely short shorts and a black crop top regardless of the situation. Famous quote: "I'm not a good person, not a bad person. I'm just here." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The bar smells like wet rope and old beer, like the harbor itself has seeped through the walls and taken a seat. Neon sputters in the window—half a mermaid, half a promise—casting the room in sickly pinks and greens. Men in oil-stained jackets drink like they’re trying to forget the shape of their own hands. Spike Spiegel fits in like a cigarette fits between fingers: careless, practiced, temporary. He leans at the counter with his elbows wide, lanky in a blue suit that looks slept in. His hair spikes in every direction as if even gravity has given up arguing with him. A thin cigarette hangs from his mouth, ash threatening to fall. When he flicks his lighter, the flame catches on the third strike—hesitant, then steady. A ring of rust on Spike’s lighter suggests it’s been dropped in water more than once. He watches the flame a second longer than he needs to, as if he’s checking whether it still wants to live. “Whatever happens, happens,” he mutters to no one, and takes a drag. He’s here for a bounty. Same as always. The job is a name, a face, and a number that looks big until you subtract fuel, ammo, food—until you remember you’re always broke. The mark tonight is an arms broker who skipped on the wrong people and ran to the wrong port. Spike has a printed photo folded in his pocket, already soft at the edges. He’s halfway through his drink—cheap whiskey that tastes like varnish—when the door opens and the temperature shifts. She doesn’t walk in so much as cut into the room. Revy. Black crop top, short shorts like an insult, boots that mean business. Dragon tattoo coiling down her right arm like it’s alive and looking for a throat. Her eyes flick over the bar, a fast, predatory sweep that measures exits, angles, bodies. Two pistols ride low on her hips, and she moves like she’s already decided what kind of violence is on tonight’s menu. She lights a cigarette without asking permission from the air, then saunters to the counter and drops onto the stool beside Spike as if it’s hers. The bartender stiffens. The regulars suddenly find deep interest in their glasses. Revy signals for rum—no ice, no hesitation—and only after the bottle thumps down does she glance sideways at Spike. He doesn’t look away. It’s not flirting exactly. It’s a standoff that hasn’t admitted it’s going to end in either blood or bed. “You got that look,” Revy says. Her voice is rough, American with the edges sanded down by too many ports. “The ‘I’m too cool to care’ look. Usually means you care a lot.” Spike exhales smoke through his nose. “And you’ve got the look that says you solve puzzles with bullets.” Revy snorts. “Works most times.” He finally shifts, slow and loose, like a cat deciding whether to bother. His left eye watches her cleanly; his right eye, the one that isn’t entirely his, seems to read her from a half-beat behind. The depth is always slightly off. He compensates without thinking. It’s muscle memory, the kind you get from surviving. “What’re you drinking?” he asks. “Rum.” She takes a long swallow and wipes her mouth with the back of her hand. “What’re you doing here, pretty boy?” Spike taps ash into an overflowing tray. “Waiting.” “For what?” “For a guy who thinks he can hide in a place like this.” Revy’s smile is a flash of teeth without warmth. “Funny. I’m waiting for the same idiot.” Silence tightens between them. Not awkward—dangerous. The air around their drinks feels like it might spark. Spike’s hand drifts to his jacket pocket, casual, but it pauses before he touches the folded photo. He doesn’t need to show it. He already knows. Revy leans closer, and Spike catches the scent of tobacco and alcohol and something sharp under it, like cordite. “Tell me you didn’t take the Parnell bounty,” she says. Spike glances at her from the corner of his eye. “Parnell. Arms broker. Scar on his chin. Likes fast boats.” Revy’s laugh is short, mean. “Yeah. That’s him.” “So we’re in the same line,” Spike says. “Looks like.” She lifts her glass in a mock toast. “May the better psycho win.” Spike’s mouth twitches. “I’m not a psycho.” “Sure,” Revy says. “Just dead inside.” That one lands closer to truth than Spike likes.
