The day began the way most of my days began—before the sun had climbed over the tiled roofs of Rome, before the streets had fully remembered their noise. In the barracks of the ludus, the air lay heavy with yesterday’s sweat and boiled barley. Somewhere in the dark a man coughed, deep and wet, the kind of cough that never left once it found purchase in the lungs. The straw in my pallet prickled through the thin cloth of my tunic. I lay still for a moment and listened, because listening was the only thing a man could do without permission. Beyond the practice yard wall, the city breathed. I heard carts on stone, the groan of axles, the occasional shout as an early vendor argued over space. Rome always sounded like it was being built and broken at once. The smell of smoke drifted in—cooking fires, baker’s ovens, charcoal—mixed with the sour tang of the Tiber that never quite washed off the wind. “Up,” Crispus muttered from the pallet beside mine. He was already sitting, rubbing his face with both hands as if he could wipe away the day. His hair stuck up like straw. He had the look of a man who had dreamed of blades and woke with the same taste in his mouth. I sat up, and my joints answered with small, resentful pains. My shoulders had been bruised for a week from drills. The lanista liked to see us marked; it proved we were being used. A slave with no bruises was an investment left idle. In the corner, the armorum rack loomed, black shapes against blacker shadow—helmets, greaves, wooden practice swords with edges worn smooth. I had once thought armor would make me feel safer. It didn’t. It only reminded me how much of my body was always offered. We washed in the basin, water cold enough to bite. A film of oil and dust floated on the surface. As I scrubbed, my fingers found old scars—one along my ribs, rope-like; another on my forearm where a blade had kissed and been pulled away, a lover reconsidering. The scars were not what frightened me. The places with no scars did, because they still had something to lose. Breakfast was porridge and bread. The cook, an old freedman with a temper like a snapping dog, slapped bowls down and barked for us to eat quickly. The porridge steamed, smelling of grain and garlic, and as I lifted the spoon my stomach clenched with hunger that felt separate from the rest of me, like it belonged to another man. Across the table, a young Thracian—barely old enough to shave—kept glancing at the door as if expecting it to open and show him a way out. “You’ll look at the sand soon enough,” Crispus said to him, not unkindly. “Save your eyes.” The Thracian swallowed. “They say the Emperor will be there,” he whispered. The name didn’t need saying. In Rome, the Emperor was a presence the way weather was a presence. Men blamed him for storms and praised him for sunshine. They feared him when the Tiber rose and loved him when the grain ships arrived. “They say a lot,” I said. My voice sounded rough, scraped raw by sleep. “They say the gods are watching. They say the crowd decides. They say if you fight well, you’ll be free.” I didn’t mention the other things they said—that freedom was a word given the way bones were tossed to dogs; that men were cheered into dying so the city could forget its hunger; that the same hands that demanded games demanded bread, and that the ones in the Senate watched the Emperor watch us, measuring his generosity like merchants. After breakfast, we trained. Not for long—not on a day like this. The trainer wanted our muscles awake, not exhausted. The yard was damp, the sand cool underfoot, and the sun finally reached over the wall, turning dust into drifting gold. We moved in pairs, shields thudding, wooden blades tapping, the rhythm steady and cruel. Every sound in a ludus had a purpose: the crack of the whip, the grunt of exertion, the shout of correction. Even silence was measured. “Again,” the trainer called when my guard slipped. “Again. You die by small mistakes.” He had once been celebrated. Now his nose was broken and his eyes were tired. He limped, and I had learned to watch the way he shifted his weight; it told me when he was angry and when he was simply afraid for us. A dead gladiator was a loss, but a dead gladiator was also proof that the world still worked the way it was supposed to. When training ended, we were oiled and scraped clean. The strigil pulled sweat and dust from my skin in long, satisfying lines, leaving me smooth and raw. The oil smelled of olives and herbs, and under it lingered the iron scent of my own body. In the bath room, men spoke quietly. No one joked. Laughter was a luxury for days when you didn’t know the calendar had your name on it. At midday, the lanista came. He wore a bright cloak, too fine for the yard, and rings that caught the sun. He walked among us as if we were horses, hands behind his back, head slightly tilted in appraisal. Behind him trailed a scribe with a wax tablet and a thin smile. “You,” the lanista said, stopping in front of me. His eyes flicked to my shoulders, my arms, the set of my jaw. “You will be on the fourth pairing.” My mouth went dry. “Against who?” He glanced at the tablet. “Crispus.” Crispus’s face didn’t change, but I saw his throat work as he swallowed. He met my eyes, and there was something there that wasn’t anger and wasn’t fear exactly—more like resignation sharpened into a point. The lanista continued down the line. Names were assigned, destinies arranged with the ease of a man choosing which wine to drink. The scribe scratched marks into wax. Somewhere beyond the walls, Rome went about its business: senators arguing over laws they would never obey, merchants counting coins, women buying fish, children chasing dogs through alleyways. The empire held itself up with rituals—sacrifices, votes, speeches, games—and the games were the most honest ritual of all, because they admitted what everyone pretended not to know: that someone always paid. Later, we were given a few hours of rest. I sat on the edge of my pallet and tightened the leather thong around my wrist, then loosened it again, then tightened it. My fingers would not stay still. The barracks smelled of oiled leather and stale wine. In the far corner someone was praying under his breath, words in a tongue I didn’t recognize. I reached under my pallet and pulled out the thing I had kept hidden since the first time I fought: a small piece of red wool, frayed at the edges, tied into a knot. It had belonged to my mother, or so I told myself. I couldn’t remember her face clearly anymore. Sometimes I wondered if I had invented her so I wouldn’t feel entirely made by other men. Before each fight, I performed the same ritual. Superstition, the trainer called it, but he crossed himself in his own way before entering the yard, so he had no right to mock. I pressed the knot of wool to my lips. The fibers tasted of dust and old sweat. I breathed into it three times, slow, as if giving it my fear to hold. Then I tied it around my left ankle, hidden beneath where the greave would sit, a secret tether. If I survived, I would untie it and fold it back under my pallet. If I didn’t, it would go into the sand with me. Either way, it meant I had done something for myself in a life where everything else was done to me. Crispus sat down across from me. He rolled a small coin along his knuckles, back and forth, back and forth. The light caught on it: the Emperor’s profile, stern and perfect, stamped into metal. “My wife used to keep coins like that for luck,” he said softly. “She said if you carried the Emperor, you carried Rome’s protection.” “And did it protect her?” I asked. He snorted, a sound without humor. “Rome doesn’t protect. Rome takes.” We sat in silence. Outside, the noise of the city swelled as afternoon thickened—more carts, more voices, the distant bray of a trumpet calling men to some other duty. A smell of incense drifted in, sweet and cloying; the neighbor’s shrine, perhaps, or a procession. Rome loved incense. It covered everything, like a lie that smelled pleasant. “You ever think about what we are?” Crispus asked at last. I knew what he meant. We were not soldiers. We did not defend borders or swear oaths to standards. We were a different sort of instrument. “We’re a distraction,” I said. “A story they tell themselves. The Emperor feeds the people with our blood so they forget their own.” Crispus rolled the coin again. “And we? What do we forget?” I thought of the Senate, men in white togas arguing over power while slaves carried their litter. I thought of the poor in the Subura, crowded into insulae that could collapse or burn at any moment. I thought of the legions on the frontiers, freezing in Germania or sweating in Judea, fighting wars that would be commemorated in stone. All of it held together by spectacle and fear, by promises of greatness and the quiet certainty that someone else would suffer. “I forget that I used to be a man with choices,” I said. Crispus looked at me, and for a moment I saw the man he might have been—a husband, a father, perhaps a baker with flour on his hands. Then the moment passed, and we were what the ludus had made us again. A horn sounded in the yard. The call to prepare. My stomach lurched as if it wanted to leave my body and run. We rose. The air seemed thicker, full of heat and expectation. Men around us began their own rituals—touching amulets, spitting on their palms, murmuring prayers to Nemesis or Mars. Someone kissed the hilt of a practice sword as if it were holy. I reached down and pressed my fingers to the knot at my ankle. It was there, rough and solid. I let my hand rest on it for a heartbeat longer than necessary. Then I stepped toward the door, toward the light, toward the roar of Rome that waited beyond the walls—hungry, restless, and endlessly entertained.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical competence and atmospheric writing within the historical fiction genre. The author successfully creates an immersive Roman setting through carefully chosen sensory details - the "heavy air with yesterday's sweat and boiled barley," the "sour tang of the Tiber," and the tactile descriptions of oil, straw, and scars. The first-person narration maintains a consistent, contemplative voice that feels appropriate for a gladiator facing potential death. The characterization shows depth, particularly in the protagonist's philosophical reflections on his circumstances and the broader Roman society. The relationship with Crispus adds emotional weight, especially the revelation that they must fight each other. The author effectively weaves in period-appropriate social commentary about the Emperor, the Senate, and Rome's use of spectacle to control the masses. However, the piece suffers from some significant weaknesses. The pacing is quite slow, with extensive internal monologue that sometimes feels indulgent rather than purposeful. While the prose is generally well-crafted, it occasionally veers toward the overwrought, particularly in passages like "freedom was a word given the way bones were tossed to dogs." Some metaphors feel forced or overly literary for the character's voice. The dialogue, while limited, feels natural and serves character development well. The author successfully avoids combat scenes as requested and creates a genuine sense of foreboding without relying on action. The ending maintains appropriate darkness without false hope, though it doesn't offer much surprise or revelation. The piece reads more like a character study than a dynamic narrative, which works for the "slice of life" requirement but may limit reader engagement. The historical details feel researched and authentic, from the ludus structure to the social dynamics. The exploration of themes around agency, identity, and societal control is thoughtful, though sometimes heavy-handed. Overall, this is competent literary fiction that succeeds in its atmospheric and character goals but lacks the narrative momentum or surprising insights that would elevate it to exceptional status. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 14 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 12 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 11 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 9 Overwrought: 10 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 14 Overall Impression: 15
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 14.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 12.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 6.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 11.0, Amateurish: 5.0, Purple Prose: 9.0, Overwrought: 10.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 14.0, Overall Impression: 15.0
+ Epistolary: The Lighthouse Keeper — Score: 85.2
Prompt:
The Lighthouse Keeper Epistolary Narrative: Write a story told entirely through a series of brief correspondences: telegrams or letters or emails between two characters. The correspondence should span several months or years, and reveal a gradually unfolding plot. Use distinct voices for each character, and include details that provide insight into their personalities and motivations. The story should build to an emotional climax, and the final letter should provide a satisfying resolution. The setting is a lighthouse keeper writing to his mother. He is working class and Scottish. He is struggling with the isolation of his posting. Write naturally and without cliches. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**LETTER — 14 March 1932** Mum, I’m writing from the Bothy Room of Eilean Mòr Light. That’s what they call it but it’s a stone box with a desk that wobbles and a chair that’s missing a screw. The sea makes its own noise here. It’s never quiet, even when the wind drops, because the rocks keep talking to the swell like old men refusing to stop their argument. Don’t fret. I’ve all my fingers and my boots are still mine. They’ve set me on the outer station, three months at a time with relief by boat, if weather allows. The Head Keeper, Mr. Rattray, is a tidy man in a tidy mind. He folds his towels as if the Board might inspect the linen. He’s not unkind, just spare with words. Work is simple on paper: keep the light burning, keep the lens clean, keep the foghorn fit, keep the log, keep yourself from going soft. It’s that last one they don’t put in the manual. I’ll write Sundays when the mail boat comes near enough. Tell Lizzie I’ve not forgotten her singing at Hogmanay. Your son, **Calum** --- **LETTER — 27 March 1932** Mum, First fortnight and I’m already fed up of my own thoughts. I didn’t know a man could be tired of his own head, but there it is. There’s a challenge here you might laugh at till you tried it: the lamp room stairs. It’s a spiral of iron that bites through your soles and it’s always damp. Twice a day, more if the weather changes, I’m up and down carrying oil tins, rags, tools. The iron sweats salt. Your hands stay tacky with it even after you wash. The lens is the size of a wardrobe, all prisms and brass, and it needs wiped like a good parlour window. Any smear and the beam goes dull, and dull is sin. Mr. Rattray stands over you and says nothing, only watches the rag. It’s worse than being shouted at. Nights are long. The light turns and turns, and you start matching your breathing to it without meaning to. I’ve taken to whistling just to put a different sound in the room. How’s your chest? Are you still taking the drops? **Calum** --- **LETTER — 10 April 1932** My Calum, Your letter came with salt still in the fold, I’m sure of it. I read it twice and then again aloud, because it’s good to hear your voice in the kitchen even when it’s only ink. Your chest: it’s your father’s in you, all that carrying and climbing. Mind you eat. Don’t live on tea and pride. Put fat on your bread even if Mr. Rattray eats like a minister. I’ve mended your old jumper. The elbows were near through. I’ll send it on the next parcel boat if they’ll take it. Lizzie was at the kirk last week. She asked after you and pretended it was only politeness. She’s not a good liar. Love from your Mum, **Mairi** --- **TELEGRAM — 22 April 1932** TO: MRS MAIRI MACLEOD, KILMORRIE FROM: EILEAN MÒR LIGHT STATION ALL WELL STOP HEAVY GALES STOP MAIL BOAT TURNED BACK STOP WILL WRITE WHEN ABLE STOP CALUM --- **LETTER — 4 May 1932** Mum, That gale: it’s the kind that makes you understand why folk used to pray to the sea like it could hear. We had spray hitting the lantern glass and freezing. You don’t think of ice on the ocean, but it came like white teeth and made the rails slick as eels. We were meant to test the foghorn at noon. The horn is run off compressed air, a big iron lung in the engine room. The trouble is the intake pipe outside clogs with salt crust if you don’t keep at it. Mr. Rattray says it’s “housekeeping.” I say it’s a fight with a thing that wants to be blocked. He sent me out to chip it clear when the wind was still pushing sideways. A rope round my waist and him holding the other end like I was a boat. I did it. Then my hands wouldn’t stop shaking for an hour. I told him it was the cold. He looked at me and said, “Aye.” Like we’d made an agreement not to speak of fear. At night I hear the horn in my head even when it’s off. A low note like a cow moaning far away. It makes sleep thin. Your jumper will be a mercy. The station blankets smell of damp dog. I dreamt I was back in our street and the sea was at the end of it, and all the doors opened onto water. **Calum** --- **LETTER — 19 June 1932** Mum, Relief boat came at last. I thought I’d be glad to see fresh faces but it near made me angry, like they’d no right to arrive smiling when I’d been counting waves. A new assistant is posted with us, Euan Fraser from Leith. He’s talkative in a way that feels like he’s afraid of silence. He asks questions and then answers them himself. Mr. Rattray tolerates him like a noise you can’t stop. I should be grateful, but the chatter gets under my skin. It’s like having the wireless on with no tune. The hardship I didn’t expect is the damp getting into everything. Bread sweats. Socks never dry. You put on a shirt and it’s cold as fish. It gets into your bones and makes you slow. If a man gets slow here he gets careless. I’ve started writing in the log with more detail than they ask for. Not just wind direction and oil consumption, but what I saw: gannets diving like stones, a seal with a torn ear, the colour of the sky when it’s about to snow. It helps to put the day somewhere outside my head. Do you remember when I was wee and you’d send me to fetch coal and I’d pretend the close was a cave? It’s like that, only the cave is real and the coal never runs out. Give my love to Auntie Ina. **Calum** --- **LETTER — 3 August 1932** My son, I’m glad you’ve someone to speak to, even if he’s a noise. Sometimes noise is a rope. Your log sounds like a book. Don’t let Mr. Rattray catch you putting poetry in the Board’s pages, but keep your own if you can. A man needs proof he was alive on the days that look the same. The jumper is on its way. I put a bit of lavender in the parcel so it doesn’t smell like the shop. If the sea steals the parcel, I’ll send another and it can choke on wool. About Lizzie: she’s taken a job at the grocer’s. She stands straighter now, like she’s found her own feet. I’m telling you so you don’t come back thinking the world stood still. And I’m well enough. Don’t you go worrying yourself thin. Your Mum, **Mairi** --- **LETTER — 17 November 1932** Mum, I didn’t write because I didn’t want to make you afraid, but now I think you’d rather know. Euan slipped. It wasn’t the stormiest day, which is the worst of it. Just a wet skin on the steps outside the engine room. He was carrying a crate of coal. The crate went first, then he did, and his head hit the iron edge. He didn’t die. Not that. But he lay there with his eyes open and his mouth working like he was chewing words he couldn’t say. Mr. Rattray and I got him into the bunkroom. There’s no doctor, only the first-aid manual and what you’ve got in your hands. We kept him awake as long as we could. He kept trying to stand, like a horse with a broken leg that doesn’t know yet. The boat couldn’t come for two days. Fog thick as porridge and the horn crying all through it. We took turns sitting with him. The smell in the room—sweat and vomit and paraffin—will stay with me longer than I like. When he slept, I watched his chest rise and fall and counted it like prayers. He was taken off at last, alive but not right. He squeezed my wrist when they carried him down. He couldn’t speak but his fingers were strong. After, Mr. Rattray went to the lantern and polished the brass until it shone like a coin. I wanted to hit him, which is daft because what else could he do? The light doesn’t care who fell. Since then the isolation has teeth. The station is quieter without Euan’s talk, but now the silence isn’t peace. It’s like waiting for something else to happen. I’ve been having a black thought, Mum. Not of harming myself—don’t jump there—but of walking down to the rocks and letting the sea decide whether I come back. Just to feel something other than the same routine. I’m ashamed even writing it, but I promised myself I’d not lie to you. Write back quick. Tell me something ordinary. Tell me what you had for supper. **Calum** --- **LETTER — 29 November 1932** Calum, my dear boy, I’m glad you told me. Shame is a thing that grows in the dark. You’ve brought it into the kitchen light between us and it’s smaller already. Listen to me. You are not weak because the place is hard. The place is hard because it’s made to be. You are a man on a rock keeping other men from dying in the water. That’s not nothing. For supper I had tatties and a bit of smoked haddock. The haddock was dear and I complained, then ate it anyway. The cat tried his luck and got a slap on the nose for it, and then I felt guilty and gave him a corner. Mrs. Kerr’s boy got his apprenticeship at the yard. He came by in his new cap and thought he was the King. I told him kings still need to mind their mothers. Here’s what you do: you keep your feet off those rocks unless it’s for work. You do not go wandering to test the sea. The sea is not a friend you can sulk at. It’s a mouth. When you feel that wanting, you write to me. Or you write in your own book. Or you sing if you must. Your father sang when he thought no one listened. I heard him. It kept him from sinking into himself. And Calum—there’s no prize for enduring alone. Ask Mr. Rattray for the wireless set earlier if you can. If he says no, you ask again next week. Wear him down like water does stone. I’m here. I’m not going anywhere. Your Mum, **Mairi** --- **LETTER — 12 February 1933** Mum, Your letter saved me from doing something stupid, and I mean that plain. I read it in the lantern room with the beam going round, and when I got to “the sea is a mouth” I laughed out loud. It startled Mr. Rattray so much he nearly dropped his pipe. I asked for the wireless. He said the Board doesn’t like “unnecessary comforts.” I asked again a week later. He said no. I asked again and he stared at me like I was a stain on his brass. Then he said, “You’re persistent.” I told him I learned it from my mother. He actually smiled, quick as a match flare, and that was the first time I saw there was a man under all that tidiness. He’s let us rig the old set that’s been in the store room. It crackles like bacon and half the time it’s only weather reports and sermons, but even that feels like being tied back to the world. Also, I’ve started a separate notebook like you said. Not the Board’s log. Mine. I write what happens and what it feels like, even when it’s ugly. It’s not poetry; don’t worry. It’s just truth with dates. Mr. Rattray’s had a cough. He hides it. Yesterday I heard him in the engine room, coughing into his sleeve like he could stuff it back inside. I made extra tea and left it by his door without a word. Later he said, “Thank you, MacLeod,” as if it cost him. Relief is due in a month. I’m counting days, but not like before. More like counting steps to home. What did you do for New Year? Did you still put out the bread and the coal? **Calum** --- **LETTER — 6 May 1933** Mum, I’m writing this from home. From our kitchen table. I can hear the neighbour’s radio through the wall and it’s the loveliest racket. But before I came back, something happened I need you to know, because it’s the reason I’m sitting here now and not still out on that rock pretending I’m fine. Mr. Rattray collapsed in the lantern room. Just went down like his strings were cut. He’d been white for days, working through it, polishing and checking and refusing to be a man with limits. I found him sprawled by the pedestal, the beam still turning above him, lighting his face in slices. For a moment I froze. I saw Euan on the steps. I saw the fog. I felt that old pull to let things happen and watch from a distance, like the sea does. Then I heard your voice from the letter—“There’s no prize for enduring alone”—and it was as if you were in the room with me. I shut off the rotation, set the emergency lamp, got him down the stairs inch by inch, swearing the whole way, my back screaming. I worked the wireless till I got a signal and gave our position and his symptoms as best I could. They sent a boat at first light though the swell was bad. He’s alive. Pneumonia, they said, and exhaustion. “He should’ve been off weeks ago,” the boatman muttered, like it was a crime. Mr. Rattray, half-conscious, grabbed my sleeve and rasped, “The light—” and I told him it was tended. He went quiet then, like a child believing you. After he was taken, they asked who could stay to mind the station until a replacement arrived. My mouth opened and the word “I” was in it, ready. Then I thought of the rocks and the wanting, and I thought of you eating haddock and slapping the cat and being solid in the world. I thought of how close I’d come to making the sea my judge. So I said, “Not me.” I said it clear. I told them I’d done my rotation and I was going home. Mum, it felt like stepping onto land after years, even though it was only months. It felt like choosing life without needing a reason grander than wanting it. I’m not leaving the service. Don’t worry. I’m going to ask for an inshore station, or one with a bigger crew. If they won’t give it, I’ll look for work at the yard. I’m not ashamed of either. And I’ve brought my notebook. It’s thicker than it should be. One day I’ll show you some of it if you want, and if not, that’s fine too. It did its job. Tonight I’ll sleep in my own bed. Tomorrow I’ll take you to the pier if you feel up to it, and we’ll look at the water from a place that doesn’t want to swallow us. Thank you for being my rope. Your son, **Calum**
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This epistolary narrative successfully fulfills the prompt's requirements while delivering a compelling and emotionally resonant story. The piece spans nearly a year (March 1932 to May 1933) and follows Calum MacLeod, a Scottish lighthouse keeper, through his correspondence with his mother Mairi as he grapples with isolation and mental health challenges. The Scottish working-class voice is authentically rendered without resorting to heavy dialect or stereotypes. Calum's voice evolves naturally from initial stoicism to vulnerability, while Mairi's maternal wisdom and practical warmth provide perfect counterpoint. The distinct voices are maintained consistently - Calum's poetic observations and growing introspection contrast beautifully with his mother's grounded, loving pragmatism. The narrative structure builds tension effectively through escalating incidents: the dangerous gale work, Euan's accident, Calum's confession of suicidal ideation, and finally Mr. Rattray's collapse. Each crisis deepens our understanding of the psychological toll of isolation while advancing the plot organically. The pacing feels natural, with longer letters during crisis moments and shorter ones during routine periods. The imagery is particularly strong, avoiding purple prose while creating vivid sensory experiences. Descriptions like "the sea makes its own noise" and "spray hitting the lantern glass and freezing" ground us in the harsh environment without overwrought language. The recurring motifs of light, sound, and the sea's relentless presence create atmospheric cohesion. The emotional complexity is sophisticated. Calum's mental health struggles are portrayed with nuance - not as dramatic breakdown but as gradual erosion of resilience. His dark thoughts are presented honestly without sensationalism. Mairi's responses demonstrate deep understanding of depression and isolation, offering practical wisdom rather than empty platitudes. The climax and resolution feel earned rather than artificially positive. Calum's decision to leave the station comes after genuine character growth, supported by his mother's guidance and his own hard-won self-awareness. The final letter's tone of cautious hope and practical planning rings true rather than saccharine. Minor weaknesses include some predictable elements in the progression of crises, and occasionally the metaphorical language borders on being too polished for the character's voice, though this rarely disrupts the overall authenticity. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Hacker Mindset — Score: 83.8
Prompt:
Hacker Mindset Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a reformed (now) white hat hacker who cannot help but notice exploitable weaknesses in both systems and people they encounter. They habitually look for vulnerabilities and exploit vectors. The narrative takes place during a first date at a restaurant, where they're trying to focus on human connection. It's going surprisingly well due to a discovered shared nerd-fandom (magic the gathering). Things go a little sideways when the date reveals a noticeably insecure phone unlock pattern, which protagonist can't help but comment on. They are then left to negotiate the fallout of this faux pas and attempt to salvage (or perhaps sabotage) the remainder of the date. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I clock the restaurant the way I clock a new network. Front door: propped open with a decorative wedge that might as well be a sign reading **PLEASE ENTER UNAUTHENTICATED**. Host stand: one iPad on a swivel, screen angled just enough that I can see reservations scroll by in fat friendly font. Waitstaff POS terminals: all on the same counter, all logged in, all trusting the world. The place has that curated “industrial cozy” look—Edison bulbs, reclaimed wood, black metal—but the security posture is pure default settings. I tell myself it’s fine. I’m not here to audit their access controls. I’m not here to imagine which employee would click the phishing email titled *New Schedule!!!* with three exclamation points. I’m here because I said I would be normal. I’m here because a date is not a penetration test. I spot them—Sam—already seated at a two-top, facing the room. Good situational awareness. Either anxious or ex-military or just sensible. They stand when they see me. Polite. Signals are clean. Their smile hits before their words do, and I feel something in my chest I don’t have a tidy taxonomy for. I am used to systems that respond predictably when you press the right buttons. Humans… humans are patchy. Humans are full of undocumented features. “Hey,” Sam says, and there’s a slight hitch like they’re nervous too. “Hey,” I say back, aiming for warm, not forensic. We do the initial handshake-without-hands dance: are we hugging? are we waving? and land on a quick hug that doesn’t overstay its welcome. A decent handshake of a hug. Minimum viable intimacy. We sit. Menus arrive. Water glasses hit the table. Condensation halos form like little spill logs. Okay. First phase: establish rapport. Second phase: maintain it without letting my brain run `nmap` on their life. Sam starts talking about their week. I listen, I nod, I deploy the standard social scripts I’ve memorized the way I used to memorize command syntax. It’s going fine. Better than fine. Their laugh is easy. Their stories have punchlines that aren’t cruel. When they talk, they look at me like they’re actually seeing me, not scanning for the next conversational exploit. Then I mention, casually, that I spent part of my afternoon reorganizing a box of old Magic cards because I “needed something tactile.” I mean it as a throwaway detail. A harmless port that probably isn’t open. Sam’s eyes light up so fast it’s like someone just plugged in an Ethernet cable. “No way,” they say. “You play?” And just like that, the whole room’s noise drops a few decibels in my head. The restaurant stops being a threat model and becomes… background. The warm hum of other people’s conversations turns into white noise. The date stops being a performance and becomes a shared interface. “I do,” I say, and my voice changes without my permission. It gets lighter. More me. “Mostly Commander. Some Limited when I can.” Sam grins. “Commander. Yes. Okay. What’s your poison?” *Poison.* Love that word choice. My brain supplies a dozen decks I’ve built over the years, the ones that say too much about me. I choose a safe one. “I have a Muldrotha deck,” I admit. “Value grind. Recycling things. I like… options.” Sam makes a sound of approval. “Muldrotha’s disgusting in the best way.” I file that away: Sam isn’t intimidated by recursion. Sam respects inevitability. That’s a compatibility marker, weirdly. They lean in. “I’ve been on a Jhoira kick lately. The artifact one. Historic spells, draw cards, oops all combo.” Jhoira, Weatherlight Captain. Card draw engine. Storm potential. Prefers building a machine and watching it run. Likes assembling a system. Okay. I can work with that. Also: likely to enjoy efficiency. Possibly impatient with slow play. “Oh,” I say, and I can’t keep the delight out of my voice. “So you’re *that* person.” Sam laughs. “Guilty. But I’m not a monster. I don’t play Winter Orb.” They say it like a confession. Like it matters what kind of villain you are. Winter Orb. Resource denial. Hard locks. The fact they brought it up unprompted means they’ve been accused before. That’s good. They’re self-aware. They care about table experience. Then they add, “Okay, I did once, but I took it out. My friends staged an intervention.” *Once.* So they’ve tested the boundary. They’ve seen what it feels like to be hated for an artifact. They patched. Nice. The waiter comes, asks if we want drinks. Sam orders a local IPA. I order something noncommittal, a gin and tonic. I watch the waiter’s pen, the way he writes down the orders. Muscle memory. The pen lingers a fraction too long over Sam’s drink, like he’s deciding if they’re “that” kind of IPA person. Human heuristics are hilarious. As the waiter leaves, Sam says, “What about you? You run anything gross?” My mind flashes to the decks I don’t bring out unless I’m among consenting adults. Stax. Infect. A tuned Yuriko list that’s basically a knife. “I used to,” I say carefully. “I’ve reformed.” Sam’s eyebrows lift. “Reformed, huh?” I feel my shoulders tighten, but for once it’s not because I’m calculating exit routes. It’s because that word has weight for me. “Yeah,” I say. “I’m trying to be… less of a menace. More of a good citizen.” That’s true in more ways than one, and for a moment I wonder if Sam can hear the second meaning rattling around under the first. Sam nods like they understand anyway. “Respect.” They talk about a game last weekend. Their friend dropped a Smothering Tithe on turn four and suddenly everyone was “paying the tax” or dying. Sam mentions Rhystic Study like it’s an old enemy. They bring up Dockside Extortionist with the resigned tone of someone who has seen too much treasure. Smothering Tithe, Rhystic Study, Dockside Extortionist: Sam lives in the world of incremental advantage and explosive ramp. They don’t mind strong staples. They’re not a hipster about it. They want the engine. They mention Aetherflux Reservoir and their hands do this little motion like firing a cannon. Combo finisher. They like a dramatic end. They mention Sensei’s Divining Top, and their eyes go a little dreamy. They like micro-optimizing. They like knowing the top of the library. They like control of information. Information control. Familiar. I’m smiling more than I mean to. I can feel my face doing it—an expression that isn’t calculated. It feels dangerous, but in a good way. Like leaving a port open on purpose because you want the traffic. The food arrives. We do the polite “this looks amazing” routine. Mine is pasta. Sam’s is something with grilled chicken and a salad that looks like it’s been arranged by someone who read a design blog. Sam says, around a bite, “Oh, I also love silly stuff. Like… I have a Phelddagrif deck.” Phelddagrif. The purple hippo. Group hug. Politics. Chaos-but-friendly. That’s… interesting. That says Sam isn’t only about winning. Sam likes social dynamics. Sam can play the table. That’s a different kind of hacker. I file it: strategy preferences are mixed. Combo engine, but also politics. Efficiency *and* feelings. Unexpectedly robust. We’re mid-laugh about the absurdity of giving opponents hippo tokens when Sam’s phone buzzes. They glance at it. “Sorry,” they say, and pick it up with that quick guilty reflex people have, like the phone is contraband. And then I see it. The unlock pattern. The thumb swipe. A neat little shape on the glass: down, right, down, left. A simple loop. Four points. No diagonals. No complexity. The kind of pattern you could guess from smudge marks and a mild sense of geometry. My brain doesn’t even have to try. It just… parses. Recognizes. Stores. I feel the old reflex rise in me like a knee-jerk. Identify vulnerability. Confirm. Exploit. It’s not malice, not anymore. It’s compulsion. Curiosity. The itch of an unpatched system. I’m already speaking before I can stop myself. “That’s a really insecure pattern.” The words land between us with a soft, horrifying thud. Sam freezes. Their phone is halfway back to the table, like it doesn’t know where it belongs now. Their eyes flick up to mine, not angry yet, but startled in a way that makes my stomach drop. I immediately want to rewind. I want an undo command. I want to roll back to the last save state where I was charming and nerdy and not a walking risk assessment. “I—” I start, and I hate how it sounds like an excuse already. “I’m sorry. I didn’t mean to—” “To what?” Sam says, and there it is: the edge. Not sharp, but present. “To… watch me unlock my phone?” That’s fair. That’s so fair it burns. My brain starts forking timelines. Option A: minimize. *It’s not a big deal, I just notice patterns.* That feels like gaslighting, even if I don’t mean it that way. Option B: joke. *Occupational hazard.* Humor can defuse, but it can also make it seem like I don’t take their discomfort seriously. Option C: honesty. The scary one. The one where I admit I have a past that trained me to see doors left open. I take a breath. Actually breathe. Slow. Like I’m trying to keep my hands from typing something they shouldn’t. “I’m sorry,” I say again, but this time I let it sit there without rushing past it. “That was… invasive. I wasn’t trying to spy. My brain just… notices security stuff. It’s a habit I’m working on.” Sam’s mouth tightens. “What, like you’re in IT?” I could take the easy out. Say yes. Let them assume it’s password policy and corporate trainings and nothing more. But Sam deserves better than a social-engineered version of me. “I do security,” I say. “Now. White hat. I used to be… not that.” Sam stares at me for a beat. Their fork hovers above the plate like a paused cursor. “You used to hack people?” they say quietly. The word *people* makes it worse. Because it’s not just systems. Systems are abstractions. People are… Sam. “I used to hack systems,” I say, and then I force myself to add, “And sometimes that meant exploiting people’s mistakes. Which is why I’m telling you the truth now, instead of making a joke. Because I don’t want to be that person anymore.” There’s a long moment where the restaurant sounds rush back in: clinking glasses, a burst of laughter from a nearby table, someone calling for more napkins. The world keeps running while my date decides whether I’m a red flag with legs. Sam’s gaze drops to their phone. Their thumb rubs the edge of the case, like they’re grounding themselves. “I don’t love that you noticed,” they say finally. “But… I guess I appreciate you saying something?” Hope sparks in me, small and cautious. Like a service restarting after a crash. “I shouldn’t have blurted it out like that,” I say. “If you want, I can help you make it better. Or we can just… pretend I never saw it and talk about literally anything else.” Sam exhales. A laugh slips out, reluctant. “Okay, Mr. Reformed. What’s a ‘better’ pattern?” I can’t help it—my brain wants to go into full lecture mode: entropy, shoulder surfing, biometrics tradeoffs, threat models. I bite it back. This is not a client engagement. This is a person across from me who agreed to spend their evening here. “More points,” I say simply. “Use diagonals. Make it something you can do without thinking, but not something someone can guess from watching once. Or just use a passcode.” Sam nods slowly. “Noted.” Then, because they’re either brave or mischievous, they tilt their head and say, “So. You’re like… a Magic player who can also break into my phone.” “I cannot,” I say quickly. “And I wouldn’t.” Sam’s eyes narrow in mock suspicion. “Sounds like something a blue player would say.” Blue player. Control. Counterspells. Information. The sting of that hits my ego in a weirdly affectionate way. “I’m Sultai,” I admit. “I like my blue with graveyard nonsense.” Sam laughs properly this time, and some of the tension drains out of my shoulders. Crisis partially averted. Or postponed. Hard to tell. They pick up their fork again. “Okay, tell me more about your Muldrotha deck. Do you run Spore Frog? Because if you do, I’m judging you.” Spore Frog. Fog on a stick. Recurring prevention. A soft lock. Sam knows the pain points. Sam has scars. “I do,” I say, and I watch their expression carefully. “But I only loop it if someone is about to do something truly horrifying.” Sam snorts. “That’s what they all say.” We’re back in it, sort of. Talking about Magic again, skirting the edge of the earlier moment like it’s a hot pan on the table we’re both pretending not to touch. Sam mentions they hate being milled, which tells me they’re emotionally attached to their library. They mention loving big splashy dragons sometimes, which tells me they’re not purely an efficiency demon. They mention Teferi’s Protection with reverence—safety button, panic shield. They like having an out. I keep cataloging every card name like it’s data points in a profile: Jhoira, Smothering Tithe, Rhystic Study, Dockside, Aetherflux, Top, Phelddagrif, Teferi’s Protection. Combo, value, politics, contingency plans. A player who likes both control and spectacle. A person who wants to feel clever but also wants everyone to have fun—most of the time. And underneath all that, I’m cataloging other things too, the things I shouldn’t reduce to entries in a mental database: the way Sam’s eyes crinkle when they laugh, the way they hold their fork like it’s a pen, the way they didn’t bolt the second I revealed something ugly and true. I am trying—actively trying—not to see vulnerabilities. But my mind is built to find them. In systems, in restaurants, in the soft habits people don’t know they broadcast. Sam’s phone pattern was just the obvious one, the kind you can’t unsee once it’s there. The harder ones are the emotional ones: the way they softened when I apologized, the way they asked for advice instead of punishing me, the way they tested me with that “blue player” joke to see if I’d take it with grace. Exploitable. All of it. And for once, I don’t want to exploit anything. I want to earn access the way you’re supposed to: through consent, through trust, through time. My old self would call that inefficient. My current self takes another bite of pasta, looks across the table at Sam, and decides that maybe—just maybe—some things are worth doing the hard way.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution and creative vision in exploring the mindset of a reformed hacker on a first date. The author successfully maintains the requested internal monologue format throughout, creating an authentic voice that balances technical expertise with genuine vulnerability. The characterization is particularly well-crafted. The protagonist's compulsive pattern recognition feels authentic - from cataloging restaurant security flaws to analyzing Magic: The Gathering deck choices as personality indicators. This creates a believable character whose reformed status feels genuine rather than superficial. The way they catch themselves mid-thought, trying to suppress old habits, rings true. The Magic: The Gathering shared interest serves as an excellent narrative device, providing natural dialogue and character development. The author demonstrates deep knowledge of the game, using card names and mechanics to reveal personality traits in both characters. This creates authentic nerd culture dialogue that advances both plot and characterization. The central conflict - the protagonist's inability to suppress commenting on Sam's insecure phone pattern - feels organic and well-executed. The aftermath is handled with emotional intelligence, showing both characters navigating the awkwardness realistically. Sam's response feels genuine rather than artificially forgiving. The prose style effectively mirrors the protagonist's analytical mindset through technical metaphors and systematic thinking patterns. Phrases like "minimum viable intimacy" and "social-engineered version of me" feel natural to the character while remaining accessible to readers. However, the piece occasionally indulges in overly clever technical metaphors that border on showing off rather than serving the narrative. Some passages become dense with hacker terminology that, while atmospheric, can slow pacing. The ending, while hopeful, feels slightly rushed in its resolution of the central tension. The emotional complexity is strong throughout, particularly in showing the protagonist's internal struggle between old habits and new values. The piece avoids simple redemption narratives, instead showing ongoing work and self-awareness. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 6 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 4 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 6.0, Overwrought: 5.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 4.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Overthinking It — Score: 83.2
Prompt:
Overthinking It Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of an intelligent 8th-grade girl with social anxiety who has developed a crush on a classmate. The narrative takes place during a group science project where they're paired together, as she cycles through rehearsed conversations while second-guessing each potential approach. Her inner thoughts should reveal the gap between her articulate internal voice and her difficulty expressing herself aloud, her fears of coming across as desperate or weird, and the exhausting process of monitoring her every word, expression, and movement for potential embarrassment. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Mr. Halverson says, “You four are together,” and I already know my heart is going to do that thing where it tries to escape through my throat like it’s late for a bus. Because “you four” includes *him*. Elliot Hsu is not even doing anything. He’s just standing there with his goggles pushed up on his forehead like he forgot he’s in eighth grade and not a scientist in a movie. He has his sleeves rolled up like we’re about to perform surgery on the baking soda. He looks at the paper with the groups and then he looks up and our eyes do the eye-contact thing for maybe half a second and my brain turns into a fire alarm. Okay. Breathe. Normal face. Normal face is important. Normal face is something I can do. I’ve practiced normal face in the bathroom mirror while brushing my teeth, which is a sentence I will never say out loud to any other human being because it sounds like I’m auditioning to be a serial killer. We sit at Lab Table Three. The seats are those tall stools that wobble if you move wrong, which means I need to not move wrong for the next forty minutes. That’s fine. I’m a statue. Statues don’t say embarrassing things. Our project is “Design and Test a Water Filtration System Using Household Materials,” which sounds like something I could talk about forever in my head—porosity, particle size, activated carbon, turbidity—like my internal voice has a podcast and ten subscribers. Out loud, I can barely order a sandwich without sounding like I’m apologizing for existing. Elliot pulls the packet toward the middle. “So, um. We have to pick materials and—” He stops, like he’s waiting for someone else to be in charge. I can be in charge. I *want* to be in charge. My brain has already made a chart. Option A: Casual competence. *We could do sand, gravel, and activated charcoal. It’ll remove both large particulates and some dissolved impurities. Then we can measure turbidity by comparing text visibility through the sample.* That sounds smooth in my head. Out loud it could come out like: “We could do… um… like… dirt? And… charcoal? Sorry.” Option B: Friendly joke. Something like, *We are basically building the world’s tiniest Brita.* That’s normal. That’s socially acceptable. But if I say it and no one laughs, I will have to fake my own death. Option C: Compliment him on his rolled-up sleeves. Absolutely not. That’s how you end up in a guidance counselor’s office. My mouth stays closed because my body has decided silence is safer than language. Natalie, who is in our group and wears highlighter-yellow scrunchies like she’s sponsored by them, says, “I can bring cotton balls. My mom has like a billion.” Miguel nods. “I can get gravel from my driveway.” Elliot looks at me again, polite, expectant. Like I’m a person who speaks. My hand is already writing in my lab notebook because writing is my superpower. I can write whole paragraphs without anyone hearing my voice crack. I flip to a clean page and at the top I write: *Filtration Materials Ideas.* Underneath, I start listing: gravel, sand, cotton, charcoal, coffee filter, cheesecloth. Then, because my hand always betrays me by doing things my brain doesn’t authorize, I doodle tiny sketches in the margin. Natalie gets a little sun with spiky rays and a smiling face, because she’s loud and bright and somehow never thinks about whether her laugh is annoying. Miguel gets a small mountain with a flag, because he always seems steady and sure, like he could survive a week in the woods with only a water bottle and a pencil. Elliot gets—my pencil hesitates—an origami crane. Neat folds. Precise. Something you can’t do unless you’re patient. Also, cranes look like they’re always about to take off, which feels accurate, because Elliot always seems like he’s thinking ahead, like he’s halfway out of the room in his head. And then there’s me. I draw a tiny spiral. Like a little snail shell. Like a whirlpool. Like overthinking made visible. Okay, talk. Say one thing. One normal science thing. I clear my throat, which is a mistake because it makes everyone look at me. “Um,” I say. Great start. Incredible. Nobel Prize material. I can hear my own voice from the outside. It sounds smaller than it should. Like it’s wearing a sweater that’s too big. “We could… layer it?” I manage, which is not a sentence so much as a question. Elliot’s face changes in a good way—interested, not confused. “Yeah,” he says quickly. “Like gravel on top, then sand, then charcoal?” Oh. He said it. He took my idea and made it an actual sentence. Which is… good. That’s good. I’m not mad. I’m not mad at all. I’m only mad at my vocal cords for being decorative instead of functional. I nod. Too many nods can look desperate, I remind myself. One nod. One nod is normal. I do one nod. Then I worry it looked stiff, like I’m agreeing to something in court. Natalie says, “Charcoal like from a grill?” Miguel makes a face. “That seems gross.” Elliot leans forward. “Activated charcoal is better. Like aquarium filter stuff.” I know that. I know exactly where it is in the pet store. I could explain the surface area and adsorption and how it traps molecules. In my head, I’m lecturing like I’m at a conference. Out loud, I’m trying to decide if opening my mouth will cause me to spontaneously combust. Say it. Just say one fact. Facts are safe. Facts are not flirtation. Facts are not weird. “It’s… it’s like—” My brain panics because now I’ve started. Starting is the hardest part. “It has a lot of surface area,” I say, and then I hate myself because my voice went up at the end, like I’m asking permission for science. But Elliot nods, actual impressed nod. “Exactly. Adsorption.” He says it like it’s not a huge deal, but my stomach does a weird flip because he said “exactly” to something I said, like we’re on the same team. Which we are. Because of the project. Not because I have built an entire imaginary life where we sit next to each other at lunch and he steals my fries and I pretend to be annoyed but secretly it’s the happiest day of my life. Stop. Stop. Focus. Mr. Halverson walks by, clapping his hands. “Remember, you need a hypothesis and a method. You’re not just making a fancy dirt cup.” Fancy dirt cup. That’s funny. I could laugh. Laughing is dangerous because sometimes my laugh comes out like a cough. I do a careful half-smile instead. Half-smiles are safe. Half-smiles say: I am a person who reacts appropriately to humor, but not too much, because too much would be embarrassing. Elliot pulls the packet closer and starts writing. His handwriting is neat, the kind that looks like it belongs in a textbook. I watch his hand and then realize I’m watching his hand and then I panic that I’ve been staring, so I snap my eyes down to my notebook like it’s urgent. Okay. Conversation rehearsal. If I say: *We should write our hypothesis like: The filter with charcoal will produce clearer water than the filter without charcoal.* That sounds smart. But if I say it too confidently, will I sound like I’m trying to show off? Like I’m trying to impress Elliot? Which I am, but I’m not supposed to be obvious. If I don’t say anything, I’ll look lazy. Or worse: boring. Boring is the death of crushes. Not that a crush is even something real. It’s a thing that exists inside my head like a small animal that keeps running into walls. Natalie twirls her pen. “So who’s doing what?” Miguel says, “I can build it. Like, the structure.” Elliot says, “I can write up the procedure.” Everyone looks at me again, that moment where the air pauses and waits for my contribution, and my brain starts scanning through every possible role like I’m selecting a character in a video game. I could say: *I’ll do the data table and graphs.* That’s safe. That’s me. That’s also… not social. It’s like saying, Hello, I would like to hide inside Excel forever. But graphs are useful. Useful is good. Useful means I’m not dead weight. Useful means I have an excuse to exist at the table. “I can do… the data,” I say. “And the… like, analysis part.” It comes out choppy, like each word had to go through airport security. Elliot smiles a little. Not a full smile, but enough that I see it. “Perfect,” he says, and then, because the universe likes to test me, he adds, “You’re really good at that stuff.” My brain lights up like a scoreboard. He thinks I’m good. He has noticed me being good at something. That is… dangerous information. That is information that could make me act differently, and acting differently leads to humiliation. Don’t blush. Don’t blush. My cheeks heat anyway because my body is a traitor. I pretend to look for something in my backpack, like maybe I’m just warm from the strenuous activity of sitting. “Thanks,” I say, and it comes out too quiet, so I say it again a tiny bit louder, and now it sounds like I’m echoing myself. Great. Fantastic. I will now be known as the girl who says “thanks” twice. Natalie is already talking about cups and rubber bands. Miguel is talking about poking holes in the bottom. Elliot is drawing a diagram. I should join in. I should add something. I should be part of the group like a normal person who has friends and not just a folder of perfectly organized notes. I lean in slightly, which makes my stool wobble, which makes my brain scream *abort mission*, but I stay upright. Victory. “We should… test the same amount of water each time,” I say. “Like, same volume. So it’s fair.” That was good. That was a full sentence. My voice still did that upward thing at the end, but it was a sentence. Elliot looks at me again. “Yeah. And we should time how long it takes to filter too.” “Flow rate,” I whisper, mostly to myself, because it’s the word my brain wants. Elliot hears it anyway. “Flow rate,” he repeats, writing it down. He wrote down my word. My word is on his paper. That is ridiculous. That is nothing. That is everything. My pencil moves again in my notebook, drawing tiny arrows between layers in the filter. I add another doodle, smaller this time: four little shapes in a row. Sun, mountain, crane, spiral. A group. I should say something else. Something normal. Something that makes me seem like I’m not a trembling bundle of nerves wearing a hoodie. I could ask Elliot a question. Questions are good. Questions show interest. People like being asked things. But if I ask Elliot a question, will it sound like I’m trying to talk to him specifically? Which I am. But I can’t be obvious. Maybe I ask the whole group: “Do we want to do two prototypes?” That’s safe. That’s academic. “Do we want to do… two versions?” I say, and immediately I worry “two versions” sounds childish. Like I should have said “two models” or “two trials.” Why can’t my mouth keep up with my head? My head has the vocabulary of an adult. My mouth has the vocabulary of a startled rabbit. Elliot nods. “We should. Control and experimental. Like, without charcoal and with charcoal.” Control. Experimental. He’s speaking my language. Which makes me want to speak more, which makes me afraid to speak at all. Mr. Halverson calls out, “Ten minutes left to get your plan approved!” Ten minutes. My brain does the math on how many things can go wrong in ten minutes. A lot. I can say something weird. I can trip. I can drop water on my lap. I can accidentally say Elliot’s name too softly like I’m practicing it. I can laugh wrong. I can exist wrong. I stare at my spiral doodle. It’s honestly accurate. My thoughts are always looping. If I say this, then that will happen, then I’ll regret it forever, and then I’ll move to a new school in another state and become a person who never speaks again. But right now we need a plan. Elliot slides the packet toward me. “Can you check if this makes sense? Like, the hypothesis?” He asked me. Specifically me. Not “someone.” Me. My chest tightens and loosens at the same time, like my lungs are arguing. I read what he wrote. It’s good. It’s clear. It’s organized. I want to tell him that. I want to tell him he writes like someone who thinks carefully. I want to tell him I like the way he draws arrows. Instead I say, because my mouth is a coward, “Yeah. It’s good.” Too short. Too blunt. Add something. Add *one* useful thing. One safe suggestion. “Maybe,” I say, and my voice shakes a tiny bit so I pretend to cough after, like I’m just allergic to oxygen, “maybe we should specify ‘clearer’ as like… lower turbidity. So it’s measurable.” Elliot’s eyes brighten again. “Good point. We can use the printed text test. Like, see how many words we can read through the sample.” My brain practically collapses with relief because that was an actual contribution and no one laughed or stared or looked pitying. Nobody threw up from secondhand embarrassment. The world is still intact. Natalie says, “Okay, nerds, let’s do it.” She means it affectionately. I think. My brain tries to analyze her tone, but I force it to stop, because tone analysis is a full-time job and I’m already working overtime. Elliot glances at my notebook, at the little sketches. My stomach drops. He saw them. He saw the crane. He saw the spiral. He will ask. He will think I’m weird. He will tell everyone I draw secret symbols like I’m planning a heist. But he just says, “Those are cool.” My mouth opens. A response is required. A response must be normal. A response must not reveal that my entire nervous system is doing cartwheels. “Thanks,” I say, only once this time. And in my head, where I am fluent and brave, I add: *You’re cool too. You make me want to be a person who can talk without rehearsing every breath.* Out loud, I write *Flow rate (mL/min)* at the top of my data table, and I draw the spiral a little bigger, but less like a whirlpool now, more like a shell. Still overthinking. Still me. But maybe—just maybe—also part of a group.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of adolescent psychology and social anxiety, delivered through an authentic first-person narrative voice. The writer successfully captures the exhausting mental gymnastics of an intelligent but socially anxious eighth-grader, creating a character whose internal eloquence contrasts sharply with her external verbal struggles. The adherence to instructions is nearly flawless - the narrative is almost entirely internal monologue, focuses on the science project setting, and maintains the perspective of an intelligent girl with social anxiety throughout. The character's voice remains remarkably consistent, with her tendency to overthink every interaction, rehearse conversations, and catastrophize social situations. The prose quality is particularly strong, with memorable metaphors and similes that feel authentic to the character's age and intelligence level. Lines like "my heart is going to do that thing where it tries to escape through my throat like it's late for a bus" and "my brain turns into a fire alarm" effectively convey anxiety through age-appropriate imagery. The doodle sequence (sun, mountain, crane, spiral) serves as an elegant metaphor for how the protagonist sees herself and others. The emotional complexity is well-developed, showing the protagonist's simultaneous desire for connection and fear of embarrassment. Her analysis of potential conversation options (A, B, C) and her constant self-monitoring feel psychologically accurate. The piece avoids the trap of making social anxiety seem cute or quirky - instead, it presents it as genuinely exhausting and limiting. However, there are some areas where the writing could be tightened. Certain passages become slightly repetitive in their exploration of the protagonist's anxiety patterns, and some metaphors, while creative, occasionally feel forced. The ending, while sweet, edges toward being slightly too positive given the established severity of her social anxiety, though it stops short of being truly incongruent. The dialogue, though minimal, feels authentic to middle school interactions. The character development is subtle but present - by the end, she's made small contributions to the group and feels tentatively included, which represents realistic progress rather than dramatic transformation. The piece succeeds in creating genuine empathy for the protagonist while avoiding condescension or oversimplification of social anxiety. The writing demonstrates technical skill in maintaining voice consistency and creating engaging internal monologue without becoming tedious. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 6 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 6 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 4 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 6.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 4.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 6.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 4.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Rehearsing Rejection — Score: 87.5
Prompt:
Rehearsing Rejection Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of someone with borderline personality disorder who frequently plays out worst-case scenarios of how friends and loved ones might judge them. They construct elaborate internal dialogues, complete with imagined criticisms and their own defensive responses. The narrative takes place as they prepare to meet a close friend & recent lover, who has been somewhat distant lately, triggering their abandonment fears. Their inner monologue should reveal how they cycle between anticipating rejection, mentally rehearsing confrontations, and developing preemptive resentments as protective measures. Incorporate the *actual* events & interactions that are *not* in fact judgemental or involving rejection (in fact, the opposite), and represent how these are interpreted, how the validation & love is desperately felt & needed -- and then immediately questioned. Capture the cognitive dissonance in this struggle. Include moments where they briefly recognize the pattern but struggle to interrupt it, showing limited (and selective) self awareness, competing with the compelling nature of these imagined scenarios. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The neighbor’s TV is on again, a laugh track leaking through the wall like it’s trying to make my apartment feel less like an airlock. Someone on the show says, *“Oh, come on—”* and then the rest turns to mush. I imagine it finishing the sentence for me: *Oh, come on, you can’t seriously think they still want you.* I’m not even dressed yet. I’m standing in front of my closet like it’s a witness stand. I hold up the black shirt, the one that says effortless, and my brain immediately cross-examines it. *You’re trying too hard.* No, I’m not. It’s just a shirt. It’s basic. Normal people wear shirts. If I wear the green sweater he said he liked, that’ll look like I’m fishing. Like I’m wearing bait. The TV next door swells—someone shouts, *“I can’t believe you—”*—then it thins into static through the drywall. My brain offers to finish that sentence too. *I can’t believe you thought I wanted this to be serious. I can’t believe you’re still clinging.* Stop. Stop narrating for him. He hasn’t said any of that. He hasn’t said much at all, which is the whole problem. Which is the whole proof. I pick up my phone. His last text is from yesterday: *Running late today. Can we do 7 instead of 6? Want sushi?* A normal text. A kind text. A text with a question mark that includes me in the answer. My thumb hovers like I’m about to touch a hot stove. *Want sushi?* means *I’m trying to keep it casual because I’m backing away.* No—actually, it means he wants sushi. People want food. People eat food. It could just be— But the distance. The last week. The way his responses got shorter. The way he said he was “busy,” and I heard *bored*. I scroll up, like there’s a hidden clause in the conversation where he confesses I’m too much and he’s been drafting his exit speech. There isn’t. There’s a heart reaction he sent to the picture of my dumb latte art. There’s a “Good luck today” before my meeting. There’s a “Miss you” after we didn’t see each other for two days. “Miss you” can be a transition phrase. Like *I miss you (as an idea) but not in my real life.* Like *I miss who you were when you weren’t needing me to prove things.* My chest does that familiar thing—tightening, rising, like it’s being lifted by a hook. The neighbor’s TV chuckles through the wall. *“…you’re being ridiculous…”* it says, maybe. My brain says it. Okay. Worst-case scenario: he’s distant because he’s already halfway out the door. He’s meeting me tonight because he’s polite. Because he doesn’t want to be a villain. Because he’s going to soften the blow in public over sushi, like a coward with soy sauce. And then my mind slides right into the rehearsal. It feels almost soothing, like chewing on a sore tooth. The pain proves it’s there. The pain proves I’m not imagining it. He’ll sit down. He’ll look tired. He’ll say, “So… I’ve been thinking.” I’ll say, *Of course you have,* but out loud I’ll say, “Okay.” Calm. Adult. Reasonable. I will be reasonable while my skin peels off. He’ll say, “I don’t think this is working.” And I’ll say, “Working?” like I’m confused, like I’m not the person who’s been measuring his silences with a ruler. “What do you mean?” The defensive response forms itself, ready to be fired like a flare. He’ll say, “You’re intense.” He’ll say, “You want a lot.” He’ll say, “I can’t be your everything.” And I will say—no, I will *not* say. I will not become the stereotype I’ve seen described in articles that read like autopsies. I will say, “I’m not asking you to be everything. I’m asking you to be consistent.” I will say, “It hurts when you pull away without telling me why.” I will say, “You said you liked me. You said you felt it too.” He’ll look at me like I’m a child arguing with gravity. He’ll say, “I did like you.” Past tense. Like it expired. Like milk. And then I will hate him preemptively, because if I hate him first, it won’t hurt as much when he leaves. If I decide he’s cruel, then I don’t have to decide I’m unlovable. In my rehearsal, I’m already composing the post-breakup clarity. The text to my best friend: *Called it. He was never serious.* The private speech in the shower where I’m brave and scathing: *You don’t get to take my body and then act like my feelings are inconvenient.* I imagine slamming my apartment door with such righteousness the neighbor’s TV cuts out. My phone buzzes. I flinch like I’ve been caught stealing. It’s him. *On my way home now. Can’t wait to see you.* My brain goes blank for half a second, like it doesn’t know how to metabolize it. The words sit there, bright and plain. I feel something bloom under my ribs—relief, warmth, the desperate animal part of me unclenching. For a second I could cry just because he wants to see me. For a second I want to be good. Normal. Easy. Then the second ends. *Can’t wait to see you* is what you say when you feel guilty for being distant. It’s what you say when you’re trying to keep someone from panicking. It’s what you say when you can’t say, *I’m sorry I disappeared in my head, it wasn’t about you,* because you don’t want to deal with how that would land. Or it’s genuine. It’s genuine. It’s—why can’t I just let it be genuine? Because if it’s genuine and I believe it, then when it stops, I will fall from a higher place. The neighbor’s TV says something muffled that sounds like, *“…trust me…”* and I almost laugh. My brain spits back, *Don’t.* I type: *Me too. See you soon.* I add a heart. I stare at the heart before I send it, like it’s a confession. Like it’s a lever that could drop me into something humiliating. I send it anyway, because the hunger is stronger than the shame. There. I have given him something to reject. I dress quickly, annoyed at my hands for shaking. I pull on jeans, then take them off, then put them back on, as if the fabric is going to determine whether I get abandoned tonight. My eyes keep darting to the mirror to check my face for neediness. Can you see it? Does it sit on my forehead like a brand? *You look desperate,* I tell myself. No, I look like a person going out. I practice my “casual” face. I practice saying, “Hey,” with no quake. I practice being the kind of person he could keep. I hear my own voice in my head, rehearsing the line I swear I won’t use: *Are you pulling away from me?* That line is a tripwire. That line is me handing him a script: *Here’s where you reassure me, or here’s where you leave.* But what if I don’t ask and he’s leaving anyway? Then I will have been fooled. Then I will have wasted time being calm while my house burned down. I can feel resentment starting to form, a preemptive bruise. *If he wanted to, he would.* If he cared, he wouldn’t make me guess. If he loved me, I wouldn’t have to read texts like tea leaves. He’s not my enemy. He’s been… good. He’s been gentle. He held my face last week and said, “I like being with you.” I remember the exact pressure of his thumb at my cheekbone, like he was anchoring me to something. I remember how I felt in that moment: light, almost real. Like someone had looked at me and chosen me. And then, immediately, my brain had whispered: *He’ll regret this.* I know I do this. I know I build traps out of air and then act surprised when I’m caught. There’s that little corner of my mind that sits back with its arms crossed and says, *Pattern,* like it’s a diagnosis and not my life. It says, *Black-and-white thinking. Catastrophizing. Mind reading.* It recites the vocabulary I’ve learned like spells that are supposed to protect me. They don’t. Knowing the name of the monster doesn’t stop it from sitting on my chest. My phone buzzes again. Another flinch. *I made us a reservation. Also I grabbed that sparkling water you like for later. You still staying over?* The question punches straight through my rehearsals. Staying over. Reservation. Sparkling water. Specific. Real. The kind of details you don’t bother with if you’re planning an exit. The kind of care that makes my throat tighten because it hits the part of me that is so tired of begging. I feel myself go soft. It’s terrifying. It’s like stepping onto a lake and hearing the ice creak. *You still staying over?* could be him giving me the chance to say no so he doesn’t have to. It could be him checking if I’m going to punish him for being distant. It could be him bracing. Or it could be him wanting me there. Wanting me. Wanting the night to continue past dinner. I type: *Yes. If you still want me to.* I delete it. Too much. Too pleading. Too sharp-edged with fear. I type: *Yes :) Can’t wait.* I hate the smiley and I love it. I send it. Then I resent myself for needing it so much. For how quickly two texts turn me into a dog that’s been thrown a scrap. The neighbor’s TV swells with dialogue, a man’s voice: *“…you know I care about you…”* and I freeze, listening like it’s a message meant for me. I imagine him saying it across the sushi table, and I imagine myself not believing him. Because even if he says it, my brain will immediately ask: *For how long? In what way? Enough to stay? Enough to not get tired of me? Enough to pick me when I’m inconvenient?* I pick up my keys. I stand by the door. My heart is sprinting ahead of my body, already arriving at the restaurant, already scanning his face for micro-signs of detachment. I picture the moment he sees me: will his eyes light up or will he do that polite smile that says obligation? He will probably smile normally. He will probably hug me. He will probably smell like his soap. I will probably melt into it like I’ve been starving, because I have. And then, even in his arms, I will be listening for the part where he lets go. Maybe I won’t start a fight. Maybe I’ll be good tonight. Maybe I’ll let the evidence be what it is: reservation, sparkling water, *can’t wait to see you,* *you still staying over.* But my mind keeps a separate folder, labeled EMERGENCY, full of my rehearsed lines and pre-made anger. It’s heavy in my pocket even when I don’t touch it. It tells me it’s there to protect me. It tells me, *If you expect rejection, you can say you saw it coming.* I open the door. The neighbor’s TV laughs again, muffled and tinny, like a crowd enjoying a punchline I don’t get. I step into the hall with my chest full of love that feels like a threat, and fear that pretends it’s preparation. On my way down the stairs, I try to hold one thought steady, just one: *He is coming to see you.* My brain immediately counters: *Until he isn’t.*
Judge Evaluation:
