Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 15.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 14.0, Emotionally Complex: 13.0, Coherent: 16.0, Meandering: 8.0, Weak Dialogue: 12.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 11.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7.0, Amateurish: 6.0, Purple Prose: 8.0, Overwrought: 7.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3.0, Unearned Transformations: 4.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 15.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 15.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Iteration 3 — Avg Score: 83.0
+ Classic sci-fi: The Azra Gambit — Score: 75.0
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi (Author style: Asimov) The Azra Gambit Colonial mars is being mined by corporations who take leases on indentured labourers. The thing they are mining is Azra, a recently discovered exotic metal which accelerates radioactive decay to such a rate that it is greatly sought after for interstellar drives and weapons alike. This has created both a gold rush and an arms race as various interests vie for control and endeavour to unlock Azra's secrets. The story follows Arthur Neegan, a first generation settler and mining engineer. Upon discovering that his unassuming plot sits atop an immense Azra vein, he is subjected to a flurry of interest and scrutiny. Write the next chapter in this story, in which an armed retinue descends on Arthur's home and politely but forcefully invites him to a meeting with some unknown party off-world. The insignia look like that of the Antares diplomatic corp -- diplomatic in name only. Arthur finds himself in the centre of a political tug of war. The chapter involves a meeting with this unknown party, who makes Arthur an offer. The scene should be primarily dialogue, interspersed with vivid description & scene setting. It should sow hints of the larger intrigue, stakes & dangers. Include Asimov's trademark big-and-small-picture world building and retrofuturistic classic scifi vibe. The chapter begins with Arthur aboard the transfer vessel, wondering just what he's gotten involved in. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Arthur kept adjusting his collar. It was an honest collar—stitched polymer that simulated linen for the benefit of men who still believed cloth should feel like cloth—and it sat against his throat with the quiet insistence of a leash. The transfer vessel’s passenger compartment had been designed by someone who’d never worn a suit in a pressurized cylinder that smelled faintly of lubricant and human worry. Across from him, the window was less a window than an architectural apology: a thin oval of reinforced silica that showed Mars falling away behind them, a dun coin with a glinting seam where the nightside met day. Above it all, blackness—thick, indifferent, and crowded with points of light that were not, Arthur reminded himself, “stars” in any romantic sense, but burning spheres that could be reached, exploited, argued over, and turned into weapons. He tried, for the fifth time, to fold his hands in his lap without looking like a man waiting for sentencing. A voice came from the bulkhead speaker, smooth as hydroponic water. “Mr. Neegan. You are comfortable?” Arthur looked around for the source out of habit, though he knew the ship’s voice had no body. “As comfortable as you can be when you’ve been—” He stopped. There were better words than “abducted,” even if they were accurate. “Escorted,” the voice supplied politely. “Escorted,” Arthur said. “Right. Comfortable enough.” There had been seven of them at his door. Not seven men in a hurry, not seven thugs in mismatched armor. Seven figures in identical gray, as crisp and clean as if Martian dust had never existed. Their helmets were tucked under their arms, their faces open, and their weapons held in a way that said, *We are professionals and we will shoot you if you force us to be.* The insignia on their left shoulders had been the part that kept replaying in Arthur’s mind: a stylized starburst over a crescent, the Antares Diplomatic Corps mark. Diplomatic, in the way a hammer was a surgical instrument if you used it to remove a tumor. He cleared his throat, felt the collar press back. “Who’s asking?” he said to the speaker. “The ship? Or the people who own the ship?” There was a pause long enough to feel like a decision. “The vessel is chartered,” the voice said. “Your meeting is arranged by a party who prefers discretion.” “Of course.” Arthur tried to laugh and discovered it came out dry. “And I’m to provide what? My charming company? My expertise? My… conveniently located property?” “Your time,” the voice said. “And your cooperation.” Arthur leaned back. The seat molded itself to him with automatic solicitude. It reminded him of the mining rig’s chair—designed to reduce strain, to make a man last longer. Everything on Mars was designed that way. Even the contracts. He looked down at his hands. There was a faint dust stain in the crease of his thumb where no soap ever quite reached. He felt absurd in the suit, like a child playing at being important. The compartment door sighed. Two of the gray-uniformed escorts entered. No helmets. Close-cropped hair. Identical jawlines, either by genetic fashion or by discipline. “Mr. Neegan,” said the one on the left. His accent was off-world, the vowels too round. “We’re approaching the rendezvous. Please follow us when instructed.” Arthur nodded, because nodding was safe. He stood when they motioned, and the collar tugged again at his throat, as if it were reminding him: *You are not here by your own momentum.* They guided him down a corridor that had the sterile shine of a corporate clinic. There were no portholes here, no concessions to wonder. The lighting was even, shadowless, an engineer’s idea of perfection. At the end was an airlock. Beyond it, another vessel docked—larger, darker, its hull painted in a blue-black that swallowed the corridor’s light. A different insignia gleamed on its side: the Antares crest again, but accompanied by a ring of tiny marks like a wreath. Arthur paused, looking at it. “What’s the wreath?” he asked before he could stop himself. The escort on the right glanced at him, expression unreadable. “Commendations,” he said. “For diplomacy?” Arthur said. “For results.” They took him through. The new vessel’s interior was warmer in tone, though no less calculated. Faux-wood panels. Brass-colored trims. A style that evoked old Earth ships—ocean liners, Arthur thought, when men crossed water and pretended they were taming it. Now they crossed vacuum and pretended the same. They led him to a door without a handle. One of them pressed his palm to a sensor plate. The door slid aside soundlessly. Inside was a room that was not quite an office and not quite a lounge. A table of glossy composite stood in the center. Three chairs on one side, one on the other. A decanter and two glasses sat at the table’s edge, an invitation dressed as courtesy. Behind the table, a man stood with his hands clasped behind his back, gazing at a wall screen that displayed nothing but a slow drift of stars. He turned at Arthur’s entrance, and for a moment Arthur felt the subtle shock of seeing someone who looked *civilian*. No uniform. No insignia. A dark suit that fit him as if it had been grown there. Gray at his temples, and the kind of calm smile that suggested he had never had to negotiate from weakness in his life. “Mr. Neegan,” the man said. His voice was soft, and it carried easily. “Thank you for coming.” Arthur glanced back. The escorts had remained at the door, silent as furniture. “I didn’t have much choice,” Arthur said. The man nodded as if Arthur had made a witty observation. “Choice is a relative quantity,” he said. “Please. Sit.” Arthur sat in the lone chair opposite. The man took one of the three chairs on the far side, leaving two empty on either side of him. That, Arthur realized, was a statement: *I can bring others. I have not.* “My name is Salvius Kade,” the man said. “I represent an interstellar consortium with interests in stability.” Arthur watched him carefully. “Antares Diplomatic Corps?” Kade’s smile tightened by a millimeter. “We are affiliated.” “Diplomatic in name only,” Arthur said. Kade’s eyes held his. “Names are tools. Like metals.” At the word *metals*, Arthur felt his stomach contract. Kade gestured to the decanter. “Would you like something? It’s actual ethanol, not the synthesized variety they serve on company rigs.” Arthur stared at the decanter. The gesture was too deliberate; it was meant to say *I have resources*. It was meant to make Arthur feel small and tempted. “No,” Arthur said. “I’d like to know why I’m here.” Kade inclined his head. “Direct. Good. Mars produces men like that—compressed by necessity.” Arthur didn’t answer. On Mars, necessity had a way of becoming an excuse. Kade folded his hands on the table. His cufflinks were tiny, polished stones that caught the light. For a second Arthur imagined they might be Azra—then laughed internally at his own paranoia. If Kade had Azra on his cuffs, he could buy Mars. “I’ll be blunt,” Kade said. “Your claim has been flagged.” Arthur’s jaw tightened. “By whom?” Kade spread his fingers slightly. “By a number of interests. Corporate mining concerns, certainly. Colonial administrative offices. And, naturally, those who monitor strategic materials.” “You mean weapons,” Arthur said. Kade didn’t deny it. “Drive cores, too. The line between propulsion and armament is thinner than most civilians like to admit.” Arthur leaned forward. “Azra accelerates decay. That’s what you want me to say. That it’s dangerous. That it needs ‘monitoring.’” Kade’s gaze was steady. “It is dangerous.” “It’s also the only reason anyone looks at Mars as more than a dusty penal colony,” Arthur shot back. “We’ve been leasing human beings for decades. Now we find a miracle metal and suddenly everyone discovers ethics.” Kade’s smile returned, faintly amused. “You are perceptive, Mr. Neegan.” Arthur felt heat in his face. “Stop calling me that like you’re complimenting a trained dog. What do you want?” Kade exhaled, as if he had been waiting for the question. “I want you,” he said, “to sign an exclusivity arrangement.” Arthur blinked. “With you.” “With my consortium,” Kade corrected. “We will purchase your rights. We will compensate you generously. We will relocate you and your immediate family off-world, to a comfortable environment. You will consult on extraction logistics, safety protocols, and—most importantly—discretion.” Arthur’s mouth went dry. “Discretion.” Kade’s fingers tapped once on the table. It was the only sign of impatience he had shown. “Mr. Neegan,” he said, “Azra is not gold. Gold made men greedy. Azra makes them afraid.” Arthur swallowed. “Afraid of what? That it’ll blow up?” Kade’s eyes flicked to the wall screen—stars drifting like silent witnesses. “Afraid of imbalance,” he said. “Every interstellar polity rests on the assumption that certain thresholds cannot be crossed too quickly. A new energy density. A new weapon yield. A drive that can outrun deterrence. Azra has the potential to make treaties obsolete.” Arthur sat back slowly. The collar pressed at his throat; he resisted the urge to adjust it again. He forced himself to keep his hands still. “You’re telling me,” Arthur said carefully, “that my little plot of Martian dirt is a geopolitical lever.” “Yes,” Kade said simply. Arthur let out a slow breath. “And if I don’t sign?” Kade’s smile faded. Not into anger—Kade seemed too polished for anger—but into something like professional regret. “Then others will approach you,” Kade said. “Some will be less polite. Some will be local. Some will claim legitimacy through contracts you’ve never read. Some will be desperate enough to make an example.” Arthur’s heart thumped once, hard. He thought of the lease-holders in the neighboring canyon, men and women who’d signed away their years for oxygen and a bunk. He thought of corporate auditors who could freeze a man’s accounts with a typed memo. He thought of the gray uniforms at his door and how carefully they’d smiled. “You’re threatening me,” Arthur said. “I’m informing you,” Kade replied, “of the landscape you’ve stumbled into.” Arthur stared at Kade’s hands. They were clean, nails trimmed. Hands that did not dig. Hands that signed. “Why me?” Arthur said. “Why not just take it?” Kade paused, and Arthur sensed calculation behind the pause. Not because Kade needed time to think, but because Kade wanted Arthur to feel that what came next was important. “Because overt seizure creates ripples,” Kade said. “Ripples become waves. Waves attract attention. We prefer… smooth water.” Arthur’s laugh came out sharp. “Diplomacy.” “Stability,” Kade corrected again. “And because you are, inconveniently, a first-generation settler with certain protections under colonial charter. Your claim is legally messy to strip without making noise.” Arthur felt a grim satisfaction at that—small, but real. “So you need my signature.” “Yes.” “And in return,” Arthur said, “I get what? A pile of credits that won’t matter when the next war starts?” Kade’s eyes narrowed slightly, and for the first time Arthur saw something behind the calm: a flicker of intensity, of urgency. “In return,” Kade said, “you get to be on the side that survives the next shift.” Arthur stared at him. “The next shift,” Arthur repeated. Kade leaned forward, lowering his voice. “Mr. Neegan,” he said, “Azra isn’t merely a resource. It is a catalyst. Not just for decay in isotopes—” his eyes held Arthur’s “—but for decay in institutions. There are people who will burn worlds to keep their advantage. There are others who will burn worlds to take it.” Arthur’s collar felt tighter. The room felt smaller. “And you,” Kade continued, “are sitting on a vein large enough to tip the balance.” Arthur’s hands finally moved; he clasped them together hard to keep them from shaking. “If I sign with you, I’m choosing a side.” Kade nodded once. “Yes.” Arthur’s voice was quiet. “And if I don’t, I’m still choosing. Just without protection.” Kade’s smile returned—brief, almost gentle. “Now you understand,” he said. Arthur looked at the two empty chairs beside Kade and wondered who was meant to sit there. Allies? Enforcers? Witnesses? He imagined the signatures on forms, the clauses, the hidden riders that turned a man into a footnote. He lifted his gaze again. “Let me see the contract,” Arthur said. Kade reached into a slim case at his side and withdrew a folded sheaf of smart-paper. He slid it across the table with care, as if it were delicate. “It is comprehensive,” Kade said. “But you are an engineer. You will appreciate the structure.” Arthur took it. The paper felt heavier than it should have, as if the words themselves had weight. As he unfolded it, the wall screen behind Kade shifted. For a second, the drifting stars were replaced by an image—grainy, magnified, unmistakable: a chunk of Azra ore, its surface shimmering with an oily iridescence, like frozen lightning trapped in stone. Then the stars returned. Arthur’s eyes flicked up. Kade watched him calmly. “Consider,” Kade said, “that this meeting is the polite version.” Arthur looked down at the first page and saw, in the upper corner, a watermark he didn’t recognize—an interlocking pattern like gears meshing, or like hands clasped too tightly. He adjusted his collar once more, not because it helped, but because he needed to do something with his hands that wasn’t signing away his life. Outside, beyond layers of hull and vacuum, Mars continued to fall away—smaller, quieter, and, for the first time in Arthur Neegan’s life, not merely home but a bargaining chip spinning in the dark.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical competence and successfully captures the Asimovian style requested. The author effectively establishes the retrofuturistic atmosphere through details like "stitched polymer that simulated linen" and the corporate-dominated Mars setting. The world-building feels authentic to classic sci-fi, with the political implications of Azra mining creating genuine tension. The characterization of Arthur is well-executed - he feels like a believable everyman caught in circumstances beyond his control. His internal monologue and physical reactions (adjusting his collar, clasping his hands) effectively convey his anxiety without being heavy-handed. Kade is appropriately menacing in his polished civility, representing corporate power with subtle threat. The dialogue serves the story well, revealing character and advancing plot naturally. Kade's measured responses and Arthur's increasingly direct questions create good tension. The conversation feels authentic to the power dynamic - Arthur trying to maintain dignity while recognizing his powerlessness. The prose quality is generally high, with evocative imagery like Mars as "a dun coin with a glinting seam" and effective metaphors throughout. The pacing builds appropriately toward the contract revelation, maintaining reader engagement. However, the piece has some weaknesses. Certain descriptions veer toward purple prose ("burning spheres that could be reached, exploited, argued over"), and some metaphors feel overwrought. The ending, while dramatically appropriate, doesn't offer much surprise - the trajectory toward Arthur being cornered into signing feels inevitable from early on. The political intrigue is well-established but remains somewhat surface-level. While hints are dropped about larger conflicts, the stakes feel more told than shown. The piece succeeds as a chapter but doesn't transcend its functional role to become particularly memorable or emotionally complex. The technical execution is solid throughout, with consistent voice and natural sentence flow. The author demonstrates good control over the material and successfully fulfills the prompt requirements. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 14 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 14 Emotionally Complex: 12 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 8 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 10 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 8 Overwrought: 7 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 15 Overall Impression: 15
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 14.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 14.0, Emotionally Complex: 12.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 5.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 8.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 10.0, Amateurish: 4.0, Purple Prose: 8.0, Overwrought: 7.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 15.0, Overall Impression: 15.0
+ Contemporary romance: Darkroom Revelations — Score: 84.8
Prompt:
Darkroom Revelations Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of Dani, a 25-year-old assertive art student known for her bold style and take-charge attitude in relationships. For the past semester, she's been quietly fascinated by Elliot (he/him), a 19-year-old boy in her experimental photography class. Dani has been intrigued by his unconventional masculinity: killer thrift-shop-nu-goth style, soft demeanour and quiet intellect. When they're paired for a final project requiring late nights in the darkroom, Elliot tentatively shares that he's been questioning his gender identity and expression. Set during one of these intimate darkroom sessions where the red light creates a confessional atmosphere. Explore Dani's complex attraction—her usual assertiveness complicated by her desire to protect Elliot's vulnerability, her excitement at witnessing his self-discovery, and her confusion about what this means for her own identity as someone typically attracted to more defined gender presentations. The narrative should capture the tender awkwardness of their conversations, Dani's internal struggle between taking charge and wanting to give Elliot agency, and the unexpected chemistry that develops as both find themselves in uncharted territory. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The darkroom door clicks shut behind us with a finality that always feels a little theatrical, like we’ve stepped off the campus and into a smaller world with its own rules. Red light washes everything into the same bruise-colored palette. Skin, metal, paper—no one looks quite real in here. It’s probably why people confess things in darkrooms. It’s hard to hold on to a performance when you can’t even see your own face properly. Elliot sets our tray down with careful hands, like he’s handling something alive. Black nail polish, chipped at the tips. A ring on his index finger that looks like it came from a thrift-store jewelry dish with the other weird little relics. His shirt is black, obviously, but it’s not the aggressive kind of black you see on guys who want to be intimidating. It’s soft, worn, drapey. He’s all shadows and quiet edges—nu-goth on a budget, but with intention. I’m supposed to be the one with the intention. I’m Dani. Twenty-five, second round of college because I took the scenic route, and I don’t do subtle. I’m the one who says what we’re doing next, who leans in first, who picks the restaurant and tells the waiter the order. In relationships I’ve always been the steering wheel, the push, the momentum. Sometimes it’s a flaw. Sometimes it’s the only thing that makes me feel like I exist. Elliot is nineteen and somehow feels older and younger at once, like he’s still soft around the edges but already made peace with the idea that the world won’t. In class he barely talks unless the professor calls on him, and then he says something that makes everyone go quiet—not because it’s loud, but because it’s precise. He doesn’t posture. He doesn’t try to dominate the room. He just… observes. I’ve been watching him all semester like it’s my own private project. We’re paired for the final, which means late nights printing and developing until our fingertips smell like chemicals and our brains start to float. I told myself it was convenient, that I could steer us to a strong outcome, but that’s not the whole truth. I wanted the proximity. I wanted a reason to be in his orbit without having to admit I’d chosen it. He slides a sheet of photo paper into the enlarger frame, eyes flicking between the negative and the focus knob. His lashes look darker in this light. Everything about him is more pronounced and more fragile, like a drawing done in charcoal. “You want me to time this one?” I ask, leaning against the counter. I could be closer. I could stand behind him, take his hands, show him. It would be so easy. That’s how I move through the world: hand on the small of someone’s back, a guiding pressure that says, this way. But I don’t. He nods, and his voice is soft. “Yeah. If you don’t mind.” “I don’t mind,” I say. I try to keep my tone normal, casual. I don’t want to sound like I’m granting him something. He exhales and the sound gets swallowed by the hum of the ventilation. The air is warm with the faint vinegar sting of stop bath. Somewhere outside this room, my phone buzzes in my pocket—once, twice—muffled against my thigh. Reflex tries to yank my attention toward it, a small tether back to whatever else I’m supposed to be doing, whoever else might want a piece of me tonight. I press my leg subtly into the counter, pinning the phone in place. Not now. Elliot adjusts the easel, shoulders hunching a little as if he’s trying to make himself smaller. He’s not small. He’s lanky, all narrow lines, but there’s a presence to him that doesn’t come from taking up space. It comes from being impossible to ignore once you’ve noticed him. We run a test strip, count seconds under the enlarger, slide the paper into the developer tray. I watch the image rise slowly out of blankness. That part always feels like magic no matter how many times I do it. The moment something becomes visible. Elliot watches too, knuckles pale against the tray edge. “It’s coming up dark,” he murmurs. “We can dodge the shadows,” I say automatically. “Or bump the exposure down. It’s fine.” “It’s not the print.” He swallows. His eyes stay on the paper, but I can tell he’s not seeing it anymore. “Can I tell you something?” My chest tightens, like my body knows before my mind does that this is a pivot. I straighten, wipe my hands on my apron. “Yeah,” I say, and then, because I can’t help myself, I add, “Of course.” He keeps staring at the image. The red light turns his face into something carved from warmth and doubt. “I’ve been… thinking a lot,” he starts, then stops. He laughs once, under his breath, without humor. “That’s a stupid way to say it.” “It’s not,” I say. I keep my voice low, the way you do in museums and at bedsides. “Take your time.” That’s new for me—those words. Take your time. I’m always dragging people forward. With Elliot, I find myself sitting back, hands open, like I’m trying not to spook a deer. He takes another breath. “I’ve been questioning my gender,” he says, the words careful, like he’s placing them on the counter between us. “Not, like… I don’t know what I am. More like… I don’t know if what I’m doing fits me.” My brain does a quick inventory of everything I know how to do in conversations like this. Offer reassurance. Ask questions. Crack a joke. Take control. None of it feels right. He’s not asking me to drive; he’s letting me sit in the passenger seat while he points at the map. I nod slowly. “Okay.” His gaze flicks to me, quick and searching, like he’s braced for me to flinch. I don’t. Not because I’m some perfect ally—I can hear my own pulse, loud as the fan—but because the honesty in his voice is startlingly intimate. Like he just handed me something breakable and trusted me not to drop it. “I like… some of the ways I look,” he continues. “But sometimes it feels like I’m wearing a costume that everyone else thinks is the real me. And I can’t tell if I’m doing the costume because I like it, or because it’s safer than… other options.” I think of his thrifted clothes, his eyeliner, the deliberate softness. I think of all the guys I’ve dated who performed masculinity like a defense mechanism—loud, sharp, territorial. Elliot’s masculinity has always read different to me. Not absent, not fake. Unconventional. Like he’s building it from scratch instead of inheriting it. “You don’t have to decide tonight,” I say. He lets out a shaky breath. “I know. I just—” He fidgets with the corner of the apron tied around his waist. “I don’t really talk to anyone about it. And you’re… you.” I almost laugh because of course I’m “me.” The girl who walks into a room and rearranges it around her. The girl who flirts like it’s a sport. The girl who likes men who look like men and women who look like women, or at least that’s what I’ve always told myself, like it’s a clean, labeled shelf in my head. I realize, with a jolt, that part of my fascination with Elliot has been exactly this: he makes the shelf wobble. “What does that mean?” I ask, softer than I intended. He shrugs, eyes dropping again. “You seem… sure of yourself.” Sure. Right. I’m sure in the way a bulldozer is sure—forward motion, power, no pause for ambiguity. But this—this is all ambiguity. This is someone standing in the doorway of themselves, not sure which room is theirs. “I’m sure about some things,” I admit. The words feel like taking off armor. “Not everything.” Elliot’s mouth twitches, like he might smile but doesn’t want to be presumptuous. “Yeah. Same.” The print finishes developing. I slide it into the stop bath, then the fixer, hands steady because my body knows the ritual even when my mind is spinning. I want to tell him he’s beautiful. Not in the way you say to be nice. In the way that feels like it comes from a place you can’t control. But “beautiful” is a loaded word, and I don’t know where it would land in him—affirming or suffocating, seen or categorized. So I say, “Thanks for telling me.” He looks at me again, really looks, like he’s checking whether I mean it. “I didn’t want to make it weird,” he says. “It’s not weird,” I reply, then pause. Honesty matters in here. The red light demands it. “I mean… it might be awkward sometimes. But awkward isn’t bad.” That gets a small, real smile out of him. It makes something in my chest loosen, then tighten again because now I’m aware of the chemistry like a physical thing—warmth and pull and the strange intimacy of being trusted. My phone buzzes again, insistent this time, but I ignore it. The outside world can wait. Whoever it is will survive without me. Elliot is here, in front of me, and he just opened a door. He leans back against the counter, arms folded loosely. “Can I ask you something?” “Yeah,” I say, and I can feel myself wanting to say, ask me anything, but I keep it simple. He hesitates. “Does it… change how you see me? Like—” His cheeks darken under the red light, a shadow of a blush. “Like, if I’m not… if I don’t end up being what people think I am.” There it is. The question underneath the question: If I change, will you leave? Will you stop wanting to look at me? I’m used to wanting people in a way that’s straightforward. I like defined edges. I like knowing what I’m reaching for. Elliot is all in-between spaces, and somehow that’s what I’m reaching for too, without knowing what it makes me. My attraction to him feels both familiar and disorienting. Familiar because I’ve wanted people before, intensely. Disorienting because I can’t file him neatly under “boy I like” without feeling like I’m doing violence to the complexity he just trusted me with. I step closer, slow enough that he has time to react. I stop a foot away. Close, but not trapping. My hands stay at my sides even though everything in me is wired to take charge, to close the distance, to decide what happens next. “I see you,” I say, and my voice shakes a little, which is humiliating and also, weirdly, a relief. “Like… I don’t think I ever saw you as a checklist of masculine things. I saw you as Elliot. And that’s not dependent on you staying the same.” He blinks. His throat bobs. “And,” I add, because I can’t pretend I’m not affected, “I’m not going to lie and say it doesn’t make me think about my own stuff. Like, what I’m attracted to. What I assume. But that’s mine to deal with. Not yours.” He exhales, long and slow, like he’s been holding his breath for months. “Okay,” he whispers. The print sits in the fixer, the image stabilized now, no longer susceptible to light. I think about that—how the paper can’t be exposed until it’s ready, until the chemicals have done their work. How rushing ruins it. I want to reach out and touch his hand. I want to do a lot of things. I also want him to have the room to be nineteen and questioning and not have my twenty-five-year-old confidence steamroll him into being whatever makes my attraction easiest. So I ask, “Do you want to talk about what you’ve been thinking? Or do you want to just… work for a while?” He looks down at his hands, then back up at me. There’s gratitude in his eyes, and something else—curiosity, maybe, or the beginning of desire that doesn’t know what shape it’s allowed to take yet. “Maybe both?” he says, tentative. I nod. “Both is good.” We move back to the enlarger, shoulder to shoulder but not touching. Not yet. The red light makes a small universe around us where things can be unfinished without being wrong. Where people can be in process. Where I can practice not grabbing the steering wheel. Elliot adjusts the focus, and I start counting out exposure time. Our voices are low, and between the numbers, the pauses fill with everything we’re not saying. Outside, my phone keeps buzzing, a distant insect I refuse to swat. In here, the only thing that matters is what slowly appears when you give it time in the dark.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical craft and emotional intelligence in handling a delicate subject matter. The author successfully creates an intimate, atmospheric setting using the darkroom as both literal space and metaphor for revelation and development. The first-person narration from Dani's perspective is consistently maintained and believable, capturing her internal conflict between her natural assertiveness and her desire to give Elliot agency in his vulnerable moment. The characterization is particularly strong. Dani feels authentic as a 25-year-old who typically takes charge but finds herself in unfamiliar territory, both emotionally and in terms of attraction. Her self-awareness about her usual patterns ("I'm always dragging people forward") and her conscious effort to restrain herself feels genuine rather than forced. Elliot, though seen through Dani's eyes, emerges as a distinct character with his own agency and complexity. The dialogue is naturalistic and serves the story well, particularly Elliot's tentative confession and Dani's measured responses. The conversation feels authentic to the characters' ages and relationship dynamic. The author avoids melodrama in favor of realistic awkwardness and genuine emotion. The prose is generally elegant without being overwrought. Metaphors like the photo development process paralleling personal revelation are well-integrated rather than heavy-handed. The sensory details of the darkroom—the red light, chemical smells, buzzing phone—create effective atmosphere without overwhelming the emotional core. The piece handles the gender identity theme with sensitivity and nuance, avoiding both tokenism and oversimplification. Dani's confusion about her own attraction and identity feels honest rather than performative. The ending strikes an appropriate note of tentative possibility rather than false resolution. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the prose becomes slightly self-conscious, and a few instances where internal monologue edges toward being overly analytical. However, these don't significantly detract from the overall effectiveness. The piece succeeds in creating genuine emotional complexity and engagement while maintaining coherent narrative structure and authentic character voices throughout. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17

+ Contemporary romance / drama: Stolen Moments in Roma — Score: 83.4
Prompt:
Contemporary Romance / Drama: Stolen Moments in Roma. Write a series of interconnected short scenes and dialogues that span a single day in modern-day Rome, in narrative form. This will form the beginning of a larger story. Alessandra, a fiery, independent Roman woman who works as a motorcycle courier, nearly collides with Ben, a somewhat clumsy, overly polite British academic on sabbatical, who is engrossed in a guidebook near the Trevi Fountain. The initial encounter is a clash of cultures and personalities – Alessandra is all sharp wit and rapid-fire Italian, while Ben is flustered apologies and awkward attempts at speaking the language. However, as they sort out the near-miss, a spark of unexpected humor and connection emerges. Alessandra, it quickly becomes clear, is a whirlwind of energy and mischief. She's a self-admitted troublemaker with a secret penchant for kleptomania, a detail she doesn't explicitly reveal, but which manifests in subtle, daring acts throughout the day. She impulsively decides to take Ben on a wild, unsanctioned tour of Rome, dragging him in some specific instances far outside his comfort zone. Ben, despite his initial apprehension and inherent politeness, finds himself utterly captivated by Alessandra's unapologetic spirit and zest for life. He is drawn into her orbit, a willing participant in increasingly outlandish situations, a quiet rebellion brewing beneath his scholarly exterior. The narrative should primarily consist of short, vivid scenes and dialogue exchanges, revealing their contrasting personalities and backgrounds, and the growing, ambiguous tension between them. Ben is captivated by Alessandra's energy and the thrill of breaking free from his routine. There's a clear sense that Alessandra is toying with Ben, pushing his boundaries and enjoying his reactions, but her own feelings remain somewhat enigmatic. The day should be a rollercoaster of exhilarating, slightly dangerous, and humorous moments, leaving Ben completely disoriented but utterly smitten. Explore the underlying tension & chemistry between them, culminating in some payoff as they part ways (or not -- your choice). Include this detail: Write in narrative prose, using immersive storytelling. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Ben had been standing in the Trevi’s spill of sound for ten minutes—coins clinking, water thundering, tour guides herding—when he decided the map in his guidebook was, in fact, lying to him. He tilted the book closer to his face, brow furrowed, one finger tracing a dotted line as if the ink might rearrange itself out of pity. A shadow cut across the page. A motorbike’s snarl ripped the air. Ben looked up at precisely the wrong moment. The scooter—black, compact, ridden like an extension of the rider’s body—skated around a cluster of tourists and came for him with terrifying certainty. Ben stepped back, heel catching on uneven cobblestone. His guidebook flapped. He threw out a hand as if he could physically stop an engine. The front tire stopped a breath from his shoe. The rider lifted her visor. Dark hair, pulled into a messy knot. Cheekbones sharp enough to slice bread. Eyes that took in his entire existence in one sweep and found it, apparently, hilarious. “Ma sei matto?” she snapped. “Vuoi morire qui? Davanti alla fontana?” Ben’s mouth opened and nothing civilized came out. “I— I’m so— I’m sorry— I didn’t—” She killed the engine with a twist and swung one leg off, boots landing hard. A courier bag hung across her torso, scuffed and stickered. She pointed at his book like it had personally offended her. “You’re reading that,” she said in accented English, disbelief dripping. “Here.” He blinked. “I was trying to locate—” “Trevi Fountain?” She spread her arms. “You found it. Congratulations.” Heat crawled up Ben’s neck. He managed, with effort, to produce an Italian sentence. “Mi… dispiace. Non volevo… intralciare.” Her eyes widened slightly, then she laughed—short, sharp. “Intralciare,” she repeated, tasting it. “Madonna. You sound like my nonna’s television.” “I’ve been practicing,” Ben said. “Clearly with limited success.” She leaned in, close enough that he smelled gasoline and something citrusy, and eyed him as if weighing whether he was worth her time. Then she reached over, plucked the guidebook right out of his hands, and flipped it open. “This is criminal,” she announced. “Look at this. They tell you to go to Piazza Navona at noon. At noon you will melt.” Ben’s hands hovered, uncertain whether to retrieve his property or accept its kidnapping. “If you could just—” She shut the book with a smack. “You’re British, yes?” “Yes.” “I knew it.” She tossed the guidebook back at him. “You have the face of apologizing even when someone steals your wallet.” Ben caught it awkwardly. “No one has stolen my—” Her smile flicked, like a match struck and gone. “Good. Keep it that way.” She nodded at his shoes—sensible, polished. “You’re dressed like you’re going to a funeral.” “It’s a— it’s a sabbatical,” Ben said, which explained nothing but felt important. “From King’s College.” “Ah,” she said, as if that clarified why he looked lost in Rome like a misplaced museum exhibit. “And you are here to… study ruins?” “I’m a classicist,” Ben admitted. “Mostly texts. Latin.” She rolled her eyes toward the fountain’s sculpted marble gods. “Rome doesn’t need another man reading dead words. Rome needs—” She paused, gaze returning to him with sudden interest. “You need… a day without your book.” “I’m not sure that’s—” She swung back onto her scooter, thumbed the starter, and grinned through the visor. “Get on.” Ben stared. “Absolutely not.” She revved the engine. “Sì.” “I don’t even know your name.” She pointed at herself. “Alessandra.” Then she pointed at him. “You.” “Ben,” he said, then immediately: “Benji— no, Ben. Just Ben.” “Bene, Ben.” Alessandra patted the seat behind her with impatient confidence. “If you don’t get on, I leave, and you spend your day sweating with your funeral shoes and your sad little map.” “I’m not sad,” Ben protested, but his feet had already shifted toward the scooter like traitors. “You are sad,” Alessandra said, matter-of-fact. “It’s okay. We fix.” He hesitated, then did what he would later insist was a purely rational decision. He climbed on, hands hovering in the air. “Hold,” Alessandra ordered. “Where— where should I—?” She looked over her shoulder, eyebrow arched. “Do you want to die, Professore?” Ben swallowed and gripped her jacket, careful, as if touching a live wire. The scooter shot forward. Trevi’s roar fell behind them. Rome opened like a film reel: sunlit stone, laundry lines, scooters swarming like fish, the smell of espresso and hot pavement. Ben’s lungs locked; his mind tried to catalog danger like a footnote. Alessandra weaved through traffic with a dancer’s arrogance. “You are always this— this…” Ben searched for a word that wouldn’t sound like an insult. “Crazy,” Alessandra supplied cheerfully. “Yes.” They stopped abruptly outside a tiny café where men in suits downed espresso like medicine. Alessandra killed the engine and hopped off, tugging Ben after her. “Coffee,” she said. “I’ve already had—” “Not in Rome,” she cut in. “In Rome you have coffee like you breathe.” Inside, the barista greeted her with a grin and a rapid burst of Italian. Alessandra answered with equal speed. Ben caught fragments: *solita*, *veloce*, *dai*. Two espressos appeared. Alessandra slid one toward Ben. “Drink.” Ben took a cautious sip and felt it punch his bloodstream awake. “That’s… very strong.” Alessandra watched him over her cup, eyes bright. “Now you are less dead.” As they left, Alessandra’s hand drifted to the counter where a jar of sugar packets sat. Her fingers moved with casual grace. When Ben blinked, she was already outside. He followed, and only when she swung her leg over the scooter did he notice a white packet peeking from her glove cuff like a small secret. Ben’s gaze caught it. Alessandra’s eyes met his for a half-second. She smiled as if daring him to speak. He opened his mouth, then closed it. “Shall we— go?” “Bravo,” she said softly, approving. “You learn fast.” Their next stop wasn’t a monument. It was a narrow street where a delivery van blocked half the way and a market stall overflowed with leather belts and sunglasses. Alessandra parked, pulled off her helmet, and grabbed her courier bag. “Work,” she said. “You come.” “I’ll only slow you down,” Ben offered, half-hopeful. She glanced at him. “Yes. That is why it’s fun.” They threaded through alleyways. Alessandra moved like she owned every stone, greeting shopkeepers, darting around tourists, balancing her phone between shoulder and ear. Ben followed, trying to keep his dignity as his funeral shoes slipped on worn marble. At one doorway, Alessandra stopped and pressed an envelope into a man’s hand. A signature, a grin, and she was off again. Ben, catching up, asked, “Do you always… deliver so quickly?” “I am paid to be fast,” she said. “And to not die.” Ben exhaled. “Ambitious.” Alessandra laughed and suddenly spun to face him, walking backward, eyes locked on his. “And you, Professore. What are you paid for? To read books and tell students they are wrong?” “That’s an unfair summary.” “But accurate?” Ben tried not to smile. Failed. “Sometimes.” She stopped him at a street corner and leaned close. “Then today you are not paid. Today you are… stolen.” Ben’s heart did something annoyingly poetic. “Stolen?” She shrugged, innocent in a way that didn’t suit her. “Temporarily.” They slipped into a church because Alessandra declared it “cooler and quieter,” and the air inside was a sudden balm. Ben’s breath slowed. The light was soft, dust floating in gold. Alessandra sat in a back pew, swinging her boot lightly as if bored by holiness. Ben sat beside her, hands folded, unsure of the rules. “This place is beautiful,” he whispered. Alessandra glanced at the altar, then at him. “You like old things,” she said. Not unkind. “I like— stories,” Ben corrected. She leaned back. “All Rome is stories. Some are true. Some are invented. Some—” She tapped her chest. “—are stolen.” Ben’s gaze flicked to her hands. Her fingers played with something small and metallic. A keychain. A tiny plastic Colosseum, the kind sold in tourist stalls by the dozen. Ben stared. “Is that—?” Alessandra held it up between thumb and forefinger, letting it catch the light. “Souvenir.” “Did you— purchase it?” Her smile was slow. “No.” Ben’s pulse spiked with the absurdity of it. “Alessandra.” “What?” She sounded genuinely curious. “It was lonely.” “You can’t just take things.” She leaned closer, her shoulder brushing his. “You can’t just take a day with a stranger and ride a scooter through traffic like you have nine lives, but here you are.” Ben swallowed. The church smelled of wax and stone and something faintly floral—her shampoo, perhaps, when she leaned in. “I’m not like you,” he said, quietly. “I know,” Alessandra replied, eyes softening for a fraction. “That’s why I picked you.” Outside, Rome had shifted. The sky, which had been a bright, indifferent blue, now bruised with clouds. A gust of wind pushed heat away, carrying the sharp scent of rain. Alessandra lifted her face, as if tasting it. “Ah.” “What?” Ben asked. She pointed. “Storm.” Ben looked up. “It’s not—” The first drop hit his forehead like a warning. Then the downpour arrived, sudden and theatrical, drumming on stone and awnings and the glossy backs of scooters. People shrieked and ran, laughter mixing with complaint. Alessandra grabbed Ben’s wrist—firm, warm—and yanked him forward. “Come!” They sprinted across the slick street, dodging puddles, Ben’s shoes immediately surrendering. Alessandra moved with glee, dragging him like a prize. They dove under the awning of a gelato shop just as the rain thickened into a curtain. The shop’s sign flickered. The air smelled of sugar and wet asphalt. Ben stood panting, hair plastered to his forehead, guidebook clutched against his chest like a wounded bird. Alessandra shook rain from her jacket and laughed, unbothered. Drops slid down her jaw. Her eyes were bright, alive. “You look like a sad cat,” she announced. “I beg your pardon,” Ben said, breathless, which only made her laugh harder. Inside the gelato shop, the man behind the counter watched them with weary amusement, as if Rome delivered soaked foreigners to him daily. Alessandra leaned in, speaking rapid Italian. “Due coni. Uno pistacchio e nocciola. E per lui—” She glanced at Ben. “What do you want, Professore?” Ben hesitated, aware of the absurd intimacy of choosing flavors with a woman who had almost killed him and then kidnapped his day. “Lemon,” he said, then attempted: “Limone.” Alessandra’s mouth twitched. “Va bene. Limone. Very… British. Sour.” Ben found himself smiling again. “It’s refreshing.” They took their gelato and stood under the awning, watching the rain turn the street into a moving mirror. A couple pressed close under a shared umbrella. A child stomped in a puddle. The city looked momentarily washed clean. Ben licked melting lemon and said, softly, “You do this often? Collect strangers?” Alessandra’s eyes stayed on the rain. “No.” Ben waited. She shifted her weight, shoulder brushing his. Her hand—still gloved—tapped the edge of his guidebook. “You hide behind this.” “It’s familiar,” Ben admitted. “And boring,” she said, but without cruelty. Then, quieter: “Maybe you need boring sometimes. It keeps you safe.” Ben glanced at her, at the rain slicking her hair, at the restless energy in her posture even when standing still. “Do you ever want safe?” Alessandra’s smile didn’t reach her eyes. “Safe is… not my talent.” A silence settled between them, charged and uncertain, filled with the hiss of rain and the distant honk of a horn. Ben’s voice came out lower than he intended. “You took that keychain.” Alessandra looked at him, a challenge sparking. “Yes.” “And the sugar packet.” She blinked, then laughed once, delighted. “You saw.” “I did.” “And?” She tilted her head. “You will call the police, Professore?” Ben should have been outraged. He should have lectured her. He should have stepped away from the heat of her presence. Instead, he heard himself say, “No.” Alessandra’s gaze sharpened, studying him. “Why?” Ben’s throat tightened. He searched for the honest answer, the one that didn’t make him sound pathetic. “Because it’s… small. And because you look like someone who steals for the feeling, not the thing.” Alessandra’s lips parted slightly, as if she hadn’t expected to be seen so clearly. The rain intensified, hammering the awning. The street blurred. Alessandra reached into her jacket pocket and pulled something out. She held it between them. A small coin, warm from her body heat. Not stolen, Ben realized—simply hers. A one-euro piece, plain and legal. She pressed it into his palm with two fingers, closing his hand around it. “For Trevi,” she said. “You make a wish.” Ben stared at his closed fist. “I thought you didn’t like guidebooks.” “This is not guidebook.” Alessandra leaned in, close enough that Ben stopped breathing. Her voice dropped. “This is superstition. It is Roman.” Ben’s heart thudded against his ribs. “And what should I wish for?” Alessandra’s gaze flicked to his mouth, then back to his eyes, unreadable. “If I tell you, it doesn’t work.” He swallowed. “Will I see you again?” A beat—so quick he almost missed it—where her expression faltered, something softer pressing against mischief. Then she stepped back, putting the distance back between them like a decision. “Maybe,” she said lightly. “If Rome wants.” Ben’s fingers tightened around the coin. “That’s not an answer.” Alessandra lifted her helmet from where it hung at her side and slid it on. The visor clicked down, hiding the dangerous honesty of her face. She pointed at him through the clear plastic. “Go back to your fountain when the rain stops. Throw the coin. Wish for something brave.” “And you?” Ben asked, suddenly urgent. Alessandra swung a leg over her scooter, rain beading on the seat. The engine coughed to life, impatient. “I have deliveries,” she called over the sound. “And trouble to make.” Ben took a step forward without thinking, stopping at the edge of the awning. “Alessandra—” She looked back once, visor reflecting the wet street, the gelato shop lights, his own startled face. With two fingers, she tapped her glove cuff where the sugar packet still hid, like a signature. Then she revved the engine and shot into the rain, vanishing between cars and umbrellas as if Rome itself had swallowed her. Ben stood under the awning, lemon gelato melting down his wrist, coin warm in his fist, heart entirely out of place. When the rain finally eased to a softer patter, he didn’t open his guidebook. He turned toward Trevi with wet shoes and a stolen day behind him, and for the first time since arriving in Rome, he walked without a map.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution and atmospheric writing, successfully capturing the essence of a contemporary Roman romance through vivid sensory details and engaging character dynamics. The author effectively establishes the contrasting personalities of Alessandra and Ben through their initial collision scene, using sharp dialogue and behavioral cues rather than exposition. The characterization is particularly well-handled. Alessandra emerges as a compelling figure - impulsive, mischievous, and magnetically confident, with her kleptomania subtly woven into the narrative through small, telling details like the sugar packet and keychain. Ben's transformation from bumbling academic to willing participant feels organic, driven by genuine attraction to Alessandra's energy rather than forced plot mechanics. The cultural clash between his British politeness and her Roman directness creates authentic tension and humor. The prose quality is consistently high, with evocative imagery that brings Rome to life through sensory details - the "spill of sound" at Trevi, the smell of gasoline and citrus, the rain turning streets into "moving mirrors." The writing maintains an appropriate contemporary voice while avoiding both overly literary pretension and casual flatness. The dialogue feels natural and serves multiple functions - revealing character, advancing plot, and building romantic tension. Alessandra's mix of Italian and accented English, Ben's formal awkwardness, and their gradual warming to each other all ring true. The author skillfully uses subtext, particularly in the final scenes where unspoken attraction simmers beneath surface conversation. The structure works well, moving through distinct scenes that build momentum while allowing for character development. The rain sequence provides effective dramatic punctuation, and the ending strikes an appropriate note of romantic possibility without forced resolution. However, some elements feel slightly predictable - the "uptight foreigner loosened up by free-spirited local" trope, while well-executed, doesn't break entirely new ground. The kleptomania subplot, while intriguing, could have been developed more fully to add deeper complexity to Alessandra's character. The pacing occasionally slows during transitional moments, though this doesn't significantly impact overall engagement. The emotional complexity is well-handled, particularly in showing Ben's internal conflict between safety and adventure, and Alessandra's hints of vulnerability beneath her confident exterior. The piece successfully builds romantic tension without rushing toward premature intimacy or declarations. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 4.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Cozy sci-fi: The Last Outpost — Score: 82.0
Prompt:
Cozy sci-fi The Last Outpost Nettle (or Nets to her friends) bartends at The Last Outpost -- a lazy hub for miners and merchants in an asteroid belt on the Andromeda outer rim. Escaping from her past life, Nets found a home here at the Outpost. They have, thus far, tolerated Net's flaws which she tries to keep in equilibrium with her assortment of talents. Her evenings involve chatting with patrons, negotiating the drama, intrigue, problems & love lives of the diverse crowd that filter through the Outpost. Tonight is no different, at least, until a frazzled looking stranger, tentacled dreads askew, quietly plops down at the bar: "Vega whisky, neat. Better make that a double." Write a chapter in this story. Establish conflict for narrative interest. Don't resolve the conflict within this chapter. Aim for about 60% dialogue. First person, present tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The wobble comes first. It always does when the station’s artificial gravity flinches—just a fractional stutter through the deck plates that you feel in your knees more than your bones. Glasses chime softly against their own reflections on the polished bar. Foam domes up and then collapses. Liquids shiver like they’re deciding whether they want to be solid instead. I keep my hands steady anyway. You learn, working a bar in an asteroid belt: don’t fight the physics, anticipate its mood. “You’re watching it again,” Jory says from the service well, wiping down a stack of cups with a rag that’s seen better centuries. He jerks his chin at the tremoring tumbler I’m lining up. “It’s not a pet, Nets.” “It’s not,” I say. “If it were a pet I could train it.” “That is wildly optimistic.” I slide a glass into place and tap the dispenser. A ribbon of amber pours—then wobbles, the stream twitching sideways as gravity hiccups. I catch the glass before it drifts a millimeter. To anyone else it’s nothing. To me it’s a tell. “Maintenance still pretending they fixed the grav nodes?” I ask. Jory snorts. “Maintenance is pretending they’re a real job.” “You’re the one who likes them,” I say. “I like their gossip.” He leans in. “Speaking of. You hear the miners on Dock Two? Swear they saw a customs skiff out past the belt.” I keep my face neutral. “Customs doesn’t come out here.” “Exactly. Which means it wasn’t customs.” “Then it wasn’t,” I say, and push the glass toward a waiting patron. “Lena, your spritz.” Lena—freighter pilot, perpetual smirk—hooks the drink with two fingers before the next micro-fluctuation can make it skate. “Your spritz, huh? Last week it was ‘your usual.’ You practicing being formal?” “I’m practicing not getting sued,” I tell her. She takes a sip, eyes narrowing pleasantly. “You can’t get sued in Andromeda’s outer rim.” “Watch me,” I say. From the corner booth, two miners argue over a hand of magnet-cards, the little strips clinging to the table between shifts in gravity. The regulars roll with it—hips braced, elbows anchored. The Outpost has a rhythm: drinks, deals, confessions, a little flirting, a little fighting, and the constant low-frequency thrum of rock and metal pretending it’s home. My home. “Hey, Nets,” calls Pera from the far end, her translator pendant blinking as it catches up with her clicks. “Tell Jory if he waters down my glowbrew again, I will—” “It wasn’t watered,” Jory calls back, offended. “It was… aerated.” Pera lifts two delicate, clawed hands in a gesture that means something between exasperation and a promise. “Aerate your own blood.” I’m smiling before I can stop myself, and then the station does another tiny lurch and the smile evaporates. The wobble in the liquids changes. It’s not random. It’s patterned—like someone tapping a code through the gravity regulators. Jory notices my hands still. “What?” “Nothing,” I lie. The door hisses and cycles, letting in a gust of colder air and a stranger with tentacled dreads that look like they’ve been slept in, fought with, and maybe chewed by a maintenance bot. They pause just inside as if the room’s noise is a wave they need to step into. Their eyes flick over the crowd, over the exits, over the ceiling. Then they come to my bar and sit like their joints forgot how. “Vega whisky, neat,” they say quietly. Their voice is rough, scraped raw by stress or vacuum exposure. “Better make that a double.” I don’t ask for payment first. You can tell when someone is one bad moment from becoming a problem. “Double Vega, neat,” I repeat, reaching for the bottle. “You sure? Vega’ll peel paint.” “Good,” they say. Their tentacles twitch, and one coils tighter around a small case at their side. “Maybe it’ll peel off the day.” I pour. The gravity hiccups again, and the whisky’s surface quivers in concentric rings. The stranger’s gaze snaps to the glass. Then to my face. “Your grav is… doing that on purpose?” My fingers tighten around the bottle. “Our grav does what it wants. You new?” They hesitate, then give a single nod. “Passing through.” “Everyone’s passing through,” I say, sliding the double toward them. “Some just do it slower.” They lift the glass, but before they drink they angle it toward the lights, watching the liquid tremble. Like they’re measuring something. Like they’re listening. I don’t like it. They finally drink, a long swallow that makes their throat work. They exhale as if they’ve been holding breath for days. “Name?” I ask, casual. Their eyes flick up. “Does it matter?” “It matters to me,” I say. “I’m the one serving you poison.” A beat. “Kest.” “Like the bird,” I say. “Like the knife,” Kest replies. Behind them, Lena swivels on her stool, interest sharpening. Jory’s hands slow on the rag. The room does that subtle shift when new tension walks in—people pretending not to look while cataloging every detail. I lean in just enough that my voice stays between us. “What are you running from, Kest?” Kest’s tentacles tighten again around the case. “Nothing.” “That’s not true,” I say. “People who are running from nothing don’t order Vega whisky like it’s medicine.” Kest stares at the glass. “If I tell you, you’ll kick me out.” “Try me.” Another gravity stutter ripples through the bar. Ice clinks. A miner swears as his drink slops over the rim. Kest’s eyes track the wobble again. “They can find me through that.” Cold threads through my ribs. I keep my face calm because that’s what bartenders do. “Who is ‘they’?” Kest leans forward, voice dropping. “A survey ship. Official on paper. Not official in practice.” “That’s vague.” “It has a tether on me,” Kest says, and taps two fingers against their temple as if knocking on the inside of their skull. “Not a tracker you can peel off. Something… woven. They use station systems to ping it. Gravity, comms, anything with a pulse.” Jory clears his throat too loudly, pretending to be busy. I ignore him. “If you’ve got a tether, why come here?” Kest’s mouth twists. “Because I saw your name on the manifest.” My heart does a small, stupid flip. I keep my hands moving—wipe, straighten, pour—so nobody sees. “My name isn’t on manifests,” I say. Kest’s eyes hold mine. “Nettle. Bartender. The Last Outpost. Paid in credits and silence.” The room feels suddenly too bright. Too many reflective surfaces. Too many places for cameras to hide. Lena’s voice drifts over, light and sharp. “Nets, you collecting strays now? Should I be jealous?” “Drink your spritz,” I tell her without looking. Kest doesn’t blink. “You don’t recognize me,” they say, and it’s not a question. “I see a lot of faces,” I reply. “Mm.” Kest takes another swallow. “I used to see yours on a wall.” The bottle in my hand nearly slips when gravity stutters again. I catch it, a fraction too fast. Jory’s eyes dart to my hands, then away. “A wall where?” I ask. “A station,” Kest says. “Different rim. Different name. Same kind of place that smiles while it eats you.” I hate how close that gets to truth. I hate that my skin knows it. “Okay,” I say, forcing breath. “Say my name is on your little list. What do you want?” Kest looks down at the case. Their tentacled dreads tremble like seaweed in a current. “I need a place to hide for one cycle. That’s it. One cycle where the tether can’t be pinged.” “You think the Outpost can do that?” I keep my voice dry. “We can’t even keep our beer cold.” Kest’s laugh is soundless. “You can. You specifically. Your… talents.” I feel Jory’s attention like heat on my shoulder. The patrons are listening now, pretending not to. Even Pera’s translator pendant goes still, like it’s leaning in. “My talents are pouring drinks,” I say. Kest’s eyes flick to the wobbling whisky. “No,” they say softly. “Your talents are balance.” The word hits wrong—like a key fitting a lock it shouldn’t know about. “Finish your drink,” I say, sharp. “And stop talking about me like you know me.” Kest sets the glass down with exaggerated care as the surface ripples again. “They’re close,” they whisper. “I can feel the ping building. Like pressure behind my eyes.” I glance toward the door, toward the ceiling vents, toward the small cameras bolted in the corners. “If you’re being hunted, you brought it here.” Kest’s shoulders slump. “I didn’t have a choice.” “People always say that,” I mutter. From a booth, one of the miners calls, too loud, “Hey Nets! Another round over here!” “Hold on,” I call back automatically, and the normalcy of it feels like a thin blanket over a fire. Kest’s hand goes to the case latches. “If they get me,” they say, “they’ll ask you where I went. And if you lie—” “I’m good at lying,” I say. Kest’s gaze hardens. “If you lie, they’ll check your systems. Your credits. Your history. Whatever name you’re hiding under.” The blanket burns away. I set my palms on the bar, grounding myself against the next gravity flutter. “You don’t get to threaten me.” “I’m not threatening you.” Kest’s voice cracks on the edge of desperation. “I’m warning you. Because I don’t want them to find you, too.” “Why would they care about me?” I ask, and the question comes out too fast. Kest’s tentacles curl tighter, a defensive halo. “Because you already slipped their net once.” The bar noise dims in my ears, replaced by the hum of the station and the strange, coded wobble of liquid in glass. From somewhere deep in the Outpost, a low chime sounds—one I’ve never heard before. It’s not the door. Not the emergency klaxon. It’s a soft, polite alert, like the station clearing its throat. Jory’s face goes pale. He looks up at the ceiling as if he can see through it. “Nets,” he says quietly, “that’s a docking request.” Lena’s chair scrapes as she stands. “We’re not expecting anyone,” she says, the humor gone. The gravity stutters again, stronger this time. On the bar, Kest’s whisky trembles so hard it nearly leaps the rim. Kest closes their eyes, jaw clenched. “That’s them,” they whisper. “That’s the ping.” I stare at the wobbling liquid, at the tiny ripples radiating outward like something is tapping on the underside of my life. Then the intercom crackles, and the Outpost’s calm, automated voice fills the room. “Unscheduled vessel requesting immediate berth. Authorization: provisional. Please stand by.” Every face turns toward the ceiling. Kest opens their eyes and looks at me like I’m the only door left. “What did you do?” I ask them. Kest’s answer is barely audible over the hum. “I came to the only place they wouldn’t expect me to run,” they say. “To you.”
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical craft and atmospheric world-building within the "cozy sci-fi" framework. The author successfully establishes the setting of The Last Outpost as a lived-in space station bar, complete with malfunctioning gravity and a diverse cast of regulars. The first-person present tense narration from Nets' perspective is consistently maintained throughout. The dialogue feels natural and serves multiple purposes - revealing character, advancing plot, and building tension. Conversations flow organically between bar banter and more serious revelations. The author achieves the requested 60% dialogue ratio while maintaining narrative momentum. Nets' voice as bartender comes through clearly in her observations and interactions. The central conflict emerges gradually and effectively - Kest's arrival brings danger that threatens both the newcomer and Nets' carefully constructed new life. The mystery of Nets' past and her apparent connection to Kest creates compelling tension. The gravity fluctuations serve as both atmospheric detail and plot device, suggesting the approaching threat. Character development is nuanced, particularly for Nets, who demonstrates competence, wariness, and hidden depths. Her bartending skills and ability to read people feel authentic. Kest is appropriately desperate and mysterious without being one-dimensional. The supporting cast (Jory, Lena, Pera) feels lived-in and contributes to the cozy atmosphere. The prose strikes an effective balance between descriptive detail and forward momentum. Imagery like "tentacled dreads that look like they've been slept in, fought with, and maybe chewed by a maintenance bot" is vivid without being overwrought. The author uses sensory details effectively, particularly the recurring motif of liquid trembling in glasses. The pacing builds tension steadily toward the cliffhanger ending with the unscheduled vessel's arrival. The conflict remains unresolved as requested, with multiple threads (Kest's pursuers, Nets' hidden past, the nature of the "tether") left open for future development. Some minor weaknesses include occasional exposition that feels slightly forced, and a few moments where the dialogue becomes overly cryptic. The world-building, while effective, relies on familiar sci-fi tropes without significant innovation. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8.0, Amateurish: 4.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Young adult drama: Gone South — Score: 86.2
Prompt:
Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The first thing I notice is the air. It’s thick. It sits on my skin like someone laid a wet towel over my shoulders and forgot about it. Back home the heat is honest—dry, mean, and straightforward. This is different. This is heat with secrets. Second thing: the sound. Everything in New Orleans feels loud even when it isn’t. There’s music leaking out of doorways, car horns, somebody yelling like they’re arguing with the universe, and somewhere a snare drum is practicing the same five beats on repeat. The city breathes like a living thing. Third thing: my phone. 12%. I stare at the top corner like I can will the number to stop falling. Like if I don’t blink, it won’t drain itself just by existing. I’ve got no charger. I’ve got no plan beyond *don’t go back.* My mom’s last text—before I turned off my notifications because I couldn’t take the buzzing—sits like a bruise in my messages. I don’t open it. If I do, I might crack. I’m standing on a sidewalk that smells like frying oil and old rain and something sweet I can’t name. The guy who picked me up outside Jackson dropped me here like he was throwing out a bag of trash. Not even mean about it. Just… done. “Downtown,” he’d said, like it was a magical solution. Like “downtown” was a bed, and a job, and a therapist, and a new life all wrapped in one. My backpack digs into my shoulders. It’s mostly clothes, a hoodie, the cash I stole from my own dresser like a cliché, and a bottle of water that’s already warm. I take a breath and do the thing my brain does when it’s trying not to panic: inventory. I am sixteen. I am trans. I am alone. I am in New Orleans. I have $86 in wrinkled bills, a phone with 12% battery, and no one here who knows my deadname. That last part is the only thing that feels like a blessing. I start walking because standing still feels like waiting to be caught. People pass me in groups. Couples. Tourists with stupid beads already around their necks even though it’s not Mardi Gras. A woman with glitter on her cheekbones like it’s a normal Tuesday. Nobody looks at me too long. Which should make me feel safer but somehow makes me feel invisible in the worst way—like I could disappear and the city wouldn’t even hiccup. At the corner there’s a convenience store with a big window and a flickering neon sign. *OPEN* but the *E* is dead, so it’s *OP N* which feels accurate for my life right now. Inside, it’s cold enough to raise goosebumps on my arms. I hover near a wall of chargers and cables like a moth to a porch light. For a second I consider shoplifting one. My hands actually twitch. Then I picture getting caught. A cop. Someone calling my mom. A school counselor saying “concerning behavioural patterns” like he’s narrating a documentary about delinquent teens. I shove my hands in my hoodie pocket. I buy the cheapest thing I can—a bottle of water—and stand at the counter too long because the outlet behind the lottery tickets looks like salvation. “Can I—” I start, and my voice comes out smaller than I want. “Can I plug my phone in for like, ten minutes?” The cashier, an older man with tired eyes, looks me up and down. I expect suspicion. I expect judgment. I expect *No.* Instead he says, “Over there. Don’t block the door.” I almost say thank you three times. I end up saying it once, like I’m trying to be normal. I crouch by the outlet like a gremlin and plug my phone into… nothing. Because I don’t have a charger. Right. I’m an idiot. I swallow the hot sting behind my eyes and stand up fast, like if I move quickly enough no one will notice. My face feels like it’s on fire. I head for the door, water in hand, humiliation in my mouth. “Hey,” a voice says behind me. I turn. The person leaning against the chip rack is about my age, maybe a little older. Hair shaved on the sides and a mess of curls on top. A faded Saints cap pushed back. Their eyes are sharp in a way that makes me think they’ve learned to see threats early. They hold up a phone charger like it’s a magic wand. “You need this?” My throat tightens. “I… yeah. Mine— I don’t have one.” “Obviously.” They push off the rack and walk over, not in a friendly-golden-retriever way, more like a street cat deciding whether you’re dangerous. “You got an iPhone?” I nod. They toss me the cable. “Don’t run off with it.” “I won’t,” I say immediately, too fast. “I swear.” They watch me plug it in, watch my screen light up like it’s a sunrise. Battery: still 12%, but now there’s a tiny lightning bolt, a promise. Relief hits so hard my knees feel weak. I set my phone on the little ledge by the window and keep a hand on it like it might sprout legs. The other kid—teen—whatever—leans next to me, close enough that I smell sunscreen and sweat. “You new in town?” “Yeah.” I hesitate, then add, because honesty feels safer than making up a story I can’t keep straight: “I got here last night.” They make a sound that’s almost a laugh but not happy. “Rough.” “You could say that.” They tilt their head. “Name?” My brain tries to decide if this is dangerous. Names are power. Names are how people file you away. Names are how they find you. But I’m also so tired of hiding that it’s like my insides are itching. “Tay,” I say. Not my full name, not yet. Just something that could still be me even if everything falls apart. They nod like that’s acceptable. “I’m Rio.” Of course they are. Of course they have a name like a river and a knife. Rio glances at my phone. “Battery dying?” “Yeah. Twelve percent,” I say, like that number is a personal failure. “Dang.” Rio’s eyes flick to my backpack. “You got somewhere to go?” The question is casual but the air around it is not. This is where people get preyed on. This is where I become a statistic. I’ve heard enough true crime podcasts to know that. I shrug, trying to look like I’m not a kid about to cry in a convenience store. “I’m figuring it out.” Rio snorts. “Same.” Something in my chest loosens, just a fraction. “You… you live here?” Rio’s mouth twists. “I exist here.” That’s not an answer, which is an answer. My phone creeps up to 14%. Tiny victories. I open my maps app and immediately regret it because it’s like staring at a maze drawn by a drunk. Streets curve and intersect and double back. Names like *Chartres* and *Tchoupitoulas* that my Tennessee tongue doesn’t know what to do with. I close it before it can drain my battery more. I open my notes app instead, like writing something down will make it a plan. - Find library - Find shelter? - Don’t die - Don’t go back Rio watches me type. “You running?” I freeze. My fingers hover. “Not from the cops,” Rio adds quickly, like they know what that question can sound like. “Just… running.” My stomach flips. The truth is a heavy thing. I’m carrying enough heavy stuff already. But Rio is standing here offering me a charger like it’s no big deal. Like kindness is normal. “I left,” I say finally. “My family… it wasn’t safe.” Rio’s eyes narrow. “Yeah?” I take a breath. “I came out. It went bad.” I don’t specify *trans* because saying it out loud to a stranger feels like walking into traffic. But Rio’s gaze shifts, taking in my face, my hoodie, the way I’m holding myself like I’m bracing for impact. “Ah,” they say softly, like they understand more than I’ve said. “Okay.” The cashier yells, “No loitering if you ain’t buying!” Rio pushes off the wall. “Come on.
