Astrid walked ahead of me with the confidence of a person who’d never had to ask permission to exist in a place. Her boots didn’t crunch the frost the way mine did; she seemed to step around the noisy patches, as if the ground had already told her where it liked to be touched. I kept my hands in my jacket pockets and tried not to think about how far the village lights were, small and steady behind the treeline, or how my parents would assume I was asleep because that was what teenage girls did when they were “adjusting.” “Don’t drag your feet,” Astrid said without looking back. “It makes you sound like you’re coming to take something. You’re not. You’re coming to sit.” “You make it sound like the mound cares,” I whispered. “It does,” she said, matter-of-fact, the way she might have said, *it’s cold, put your hat on.* “And so do the ones under it.” The mound rose low but deliberate in the clearing, a hump of ancient earth ringed with stones that looked too placed to be natural. In daylight it was just a strange feature kids biked past. At midnight, with the mist crawling and the spruce trees standing like a wall, it had an opinion about being seen. Astrid stopped at the first stone. She squatted, pulled a mitten off with her teeth, and laid her palm on it. “No stepping over the ring,” she said. “Not until you’re done. If you have to leave, you go the way you came.” “I thought you said it wasn’t real,” I said, immediately hating myself for it. It sounded like accusing her of lying, which wasn’t quite what I meant. In Stockholm, if you did something stupid, you did it with irony. In this place, the air itself seemed to prefer sincerity. Astrid’s eyes flicked to me, pale in the moonlight. “I never said it wasn’t real. I said you could do it without being… pious.” She tugged her mitten back on. “Grandma called it *útiseta*. Sitting out. She said you can do it for knowledge, but it comes with a cost. Like everything. We’re not praying. We’re listening.” I followed her around the ring, careful not to step between the stones. My stomach kept trying to convince me I’d already done something wrong. We’d prepared in her room after dinner, with the radio low and her mother’s television murmuring downstairs. Astrid had set her schoolbag on the bed like it was a ritual kit. Out came a stub of candle, a box of matches with a moose on it, a thermos of coffee that smelled like burnt comfort, and—most unnerving—an old knife with a chipped wooden handle. “It’s not for cutting,” she’d said when I stared. “It’s for marking. You can use your nail if you want, but Grandma said iron makes you… sharper. Like the boundary listens.” “What boundary?” Astrid had rolled her eyes in a way that made her suddenly thirteen again instead of some forest witch. “Between what you think and what you know.” Then she’d made me take off my necklace. A cheap silver chain with a tiny heart my best friend in Stockholm had bought me at Åhléns. I’d wanted to keep it on out of spite, but Astrid’s hand had hovered near it like she could feel it snagging on the air. “No metal on your throat,” she said. “It’s a leash if something wants to pull.” “Something,” I repeated, trying to keep my voice light. “Like, what, a ghost?” Astrid had shrugged and looked at the window as if checking if the night was listening. “Grandma didn’t say ghost. She said *någon*. Someone. Sometimes it’s only your own thoughts that come back different.” Now, standing at the mound, those preparations replayed with a different weight. The candle stub was in Astrid’s pocket. The knife was too, I could see the outline against her jacket when she moved. My necklace was sitting on my bedside table at home, and I could feel the bare skin at my throat as if it were newly exposed. Astrid stepped onto the mound. The mist curled around her ankles. I hesitated at the edge, the urge to laugh rising sharp in my chest, a last attempt at defense. “This is insane,” I said quietly. “We’re going to sit on dirt and give ourselves hypothermia and then you’ll tell everyone I freaked out.” Astrid turned, and in the moonlight her expression wasn’t mocking. It was almost… tender, which was worse. “You don’t have to do it,” she said. “But don’t make jokes here. That’s the one thing Grandma said that sounded like she meant it personally.” I swallowed. The cold made it feel like my throat was full of needles. “Fine.” I stepped up onto the mound. The ground was springy, covered with short, pale grass and patches of lichen that looked like dried seafoam. The mist was thicker here, and it made the clearing feel smaller, as if the trees had leaned in. The moon was high and thin, a sliver that didn’t give enough light to be reassuring. Astrid led me to the top, where the mound flattened slightly. She crouched and brushed away a patch of frost with her glove until dark earth showed. “You sit here,” she said, patting the spot. “Facing north. I sit behind you, facing south.” “Why?” I asked. “Because you’re the one asking,” she said. “And I’m… keeping the door from swinging too wide.” I wanted to ask what that meant, but the way she said it—casual, like it was a common-sense precaution—made the question lodge in my teeth. She pulled the candle out and pressed it into the earth between us, wedging it so it stood upright. She struck a match. The sulfur smell cut through the cold and the damp, and for a second the light made the mist look alive, twisting in little eddies. “You don’t have to stare at the candle,” she said. “You stare past it. Like when you try to see your reflection in a dark window.” I sat down where she’d indicated. The earth was cold through my jeans almost immediately. I tucked my hands under my thighs to keep them warm, then remembered Astrid’s earlier warning about metal and wondered if keys counted. My house key was in my pocket. My fingers flexed around it, then let go. Astrid sat behind me. I could feel her presence like a line drawn along my spine. “Rules,” she said quietly. “No talking unless you have to. If you hear your name, don’t answer. If you see someone you know, don’t look at their face. If you feel like you’re falling asleep, pinch yourself. You can’t drift. It’s like—” She paused, searching for an image that wasn’t a grandmother’s warning. “It’s like being on the edge of a lake in spring. The ice looks solid. It’s not.” My mouth went dry. “Why are we doing this again?” “Because you want to know things,” Astrid said, as if it were obvious. “You wanted to know why Malin stopped talking to you in gym. You wanted to know what Jonas said about you behind the bus stop. You wanted to know if your dad really chose this place or if your mom made him.” I flinched. Those weren’t secrets so much as small humiliations, but hearing them lined up like that made them sound like a list of debts. “And if I don’t want to know anymore?” I whispered. Astrid’s voice came from behind me, close to my ear. “Then you sit anyway, and you learn what it feels like when you don’t get to choose.” She didn’t say it cruelly. That was the worst part. The candle flame steadied. The match had died, and the only sound was the faint hiss of the wick and, farther away, the soft ticking of branches in the cold. Somewhere an owl called, a hollow note that seemed to travel through the mist and come back altered. I tried to do what Astrid had told me. I stared past the candle, past the thin flame, into the darker patch of air beyond. My eyes watered from the cold and from not blinking. The mist at the edge of my vision seemed to shift, thicker on one side, then the other, as if something was moving through it. *It’s just fog,* I told myself. *It’s just your eyes.* In Stockholm, the night was full of distant sounds—cars, voices, the hum of the city. Here, silence had texture. It pressed in around my ears. It made every tiny noise inside my own body loud: my breath, my heart, the small crackle of my jacket when I moved. Time stretched. Minutes became heavy. My legs went numb where they touched the ground. I couldn’t tell if Astrid was breathing behind me. I thought of my room at home—at *this* home, the one with the pine-paneled walls and the smell of woodsmoke that never quite left your hair. I thought of the heart necklace on my bedside table, a small piece of Stockholm waiting for my throat like a promise. The candle flame flickered suddenly, bending sideways as if someone had exhaled near it. I froze. There was no wind. The spruce trees were still. The mist didn’t stream or lift. The flame straightened, then flickered again, a quick nervous dance. Behind me, Astrid’s hand touched my shoulder, light but firm. “Don’t look,” she murmured. “Just listen.” My scalp prickled. The instinct to turn around was so strong it made my neck ache. I forced myself to stare forward, into the dim. The mist at the edge of the mound thickened, glowing faintly where the moon caught it. For a moment it looked like a figure standing just beyond the ring of stones—tall, narrow, a suggestion of shoulders. My mind grabbed at it greedily, eager to make it into something recognizable. A man. A woman. Someone from the village. Someone in a coat. Then it shifted, and it was only a thicker knot of fog. A sound came then, faint and low. It might have been the trees settling, or the distant river moving under ice. It might have been nothing more than the blood in my ears. It also might have been a voice. It wasn’t clear enough to be words, but it rose and fell with the shape of speech. I felt my mouth open slightly, my body leaning forward without my permission, as if my whole spine wanted to catch it. Astrid’s fingers tightened on my shoulder. Her nails pressed through my jacket, sharp enough to hurt. “Don’t,” she whispered, urgent now. “If it says your name, you don’t give it yours back.” I swallowed hard, the sound loud in my own head. The murmur continued. It seemed to come from the mound itself, from beneath the earth under my legs, or from the mist in front of me. I couldn’t locate it, and that made my stomach turn. I tried to think of rational things: cold air moving through branches, auditory hallucinations from fear, the way your brain fills silence with patterns. I tried to picture Astrid’s room, the radio, the moose on the matchbox. I tried to anchor myself in teenage stupidity, in the idea that this was just another midnight game. But the candle flame leaned again, away from the mound, as if something had come close from the front. The mist brightened at the edge, and for a second the outline returned—clearer this time, closer. A head shape. An arm? My eyes burned with the need to focus, to force it into certainty. From somewhere in that whiteness, a sound like a sigh, or a word half-formed, brushed the air. It was so close it felt like breath on my face. My heart slammed against my ribs. The key in my pocket dug into my thigh as my leg tensed. The urge to answer—to say *What?* or *Who’s there?*—rose up like a reflex. And then, unmistakably, I heard it. A whisper that might have been my name. It wasn’t loud. It wasn’t dramatic. It was the kind of sound you could blame on anything if you wanted to. The kind of sound you could carry for years and still argue with yourself about. I sat very still on the ancient earth, my hands trapped under my thighs, my throat bare, and I did not answer. Behind me Astrid breathed in, sharp and quiet, like she’d been holding it for a long time. Her hand stayed on my shoulder, anchoring me, or keeping me from turning, or keeping something else from stepping through. The mist swirled at the edge of the stones. The candle flame trembled. The murmur sank back into the earth. For a moment, nothing happened at all. And that, more than anything, made me understand how dangerous it was to treat this like entertainment—because the silence felt like a decision being made.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical execution and atmospheric control while successfully fulfilling the prompt's complex requirements. The author establishes an authentic folk horror atmosphere through careful attention to setting, character dynamics, and the gradual escalation of supernatural ambiguity. The narrative voice is particularly well-crafted, maintaining the transparency of adult recollection while preserving the immediacy of teenage experience. Linnea's voice feels genuinely adolescent without being condescending - her observations about Stockholm versus rural Sweden, her defensive irony, and her growing unease all ring true. The characterization of Astrid is especially nuanced, presenting her as simultaneously a typical teenager and something more unsettling, with her matter-of-fact delivery of occult instructions creating effective cognitive dissonance. The prose quality is consistently high, with evocative imagery that serves the story rather than overwhelming it. Descriptions like "mist clung to the edges of the burial mound, glowing under moonlight like someone had spilled milk into the heather" are vivid without being overwrought. The author demonstrates restraint in building tension, allowing small details to accumulate rather than forcing dramatic moments. The piece excels at maintaining the crucial ambiguity between supernatural and psychological explanations. The flickering candle, the figure in the mist, and the whispered name could all have rational explanations, yet the accumulation creates genuine unease. The author resists the temptation to provide definitive answers, which strengthens the folk horror atmosphere. The ritual preparation sequences effectively blend teenage rebellion with authentic-feeling folkloric elements. The specific details about metal removal, directional positioning, and behavioral restrictions feel researched rather than invented, lending credibility to the supernatural framework. The pacing is well-controlled, with the lengthy buildup justified by the payoff. The ending strikes an appropriate note of unresolved tension without feeling incomplete. The final line about understanding the danger of treating ancient practices as entertainment effectively ties back to the thematic concerns established in the prompt. Minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the prose becomes slightly self-conscious, and some metaphors that feel slightly forced. The piece also runs somewhat long for its content, though this serves the atmospheric buildup. The dialogue, while limited, feels natural and serves character development effectively. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 6 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 6.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Physical-spatial: Therapeutic Boundaries — Score: 88.2
Prompt:
**"Therapeutic Boundaries"** Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a former professional athlete undergoing mandatory physical therapy after a career-destroying injury, harboring resentment toward recovery itself. Their physiotherapist is not only unnervingly attractive but also a former training partner from their competitive days who has successfully transitioned to a new career while the protagonist's identity remains shattered. We'll lean into the sexual tension of the scene by having her be attracted to him, but both of them attempting to maintain mental distance while being in physical contact as he shows her stretches & movements & manipulates her body, navigating the thresholds of pain. This scene MUST maintain complete physical coherence—every movement, stretch, and manipulation must be anatomically precise and spatially consistent. Paint an exceptionally vivid sensory picture through detailed attention to pain thresholds, involuntary responses to touch. Capture the suppressed, flaring tension of physical proximity, touch, and the controlled infliction of uncomfortable movements. Physical clarity is essential — readers must understand exactly what is happening with the body during each therapeutic technique. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Lavender has no business in a room like this. It shouldn’t be able to soften fluorescent lights, or make polished linoleum feel less like a skating rink. It shouldn’t be able to creep into my sinuses and press a memory—hotel lobbies, spa brochures, someone else’s life—over the sharp, clean bite of sanitizer. But it does. The diffuser on the counter ticks softly, exhaling a faint floral sweetness that doesn’t belong with the paper on the plinth and the anatomy posters and the stainless tray laid out like I’m about to be fixed. Fixed. As if I’m a strap that snapped and could be buckled again. I sit on the edge of the treatment table with my shoes lined up under it like I’m a kid at school. My injured leg—right—sticks out farther than the left because I still don’t trust bending it without thinking. The scar is hidden under fabric, but my body remembers where it is; it buzzes there, not pain exactly, more like the echo of pain, a permanent expectation. The door clicks and he walks in. Of course it’s him. Of course the universe would choose this small cruelty: mandatory sessions, assigned provider, and the only physiotherapist with an opening in the approved network happens to be the man who used to run drills beside me, who used to sweat through the same sets, who used to laugh when I pretended I wasn’t exhausted. Now he wears navy scrubs and a lanyard, hair trimmed, posture relaxed in that infuriating way of someone who has settled into a second skin instead of losing his first. He’s unnervingly attractive in a way I try not to see. The same wide shoulders, the same forearms that used to catch medicine balls and now will—apparently—hold my ankle. His eyes flick to the intake form in his hand, then to my face, then away again, professional and careful. Like eye contact is a loaded exercise. “Hey,” he says. His voice is lower than I remember, or maybe I’m hearing it differently because I’m not competing beside him anymore. I’m… this. “Hey,” I answer, as if we’re running into each other at a coffee shop. As if my career didn’t end with a sound I still hear in the quiet. He washes his hands at the sink, fingers interlaced, thumbs scrubbing, the routine precise. Water runs, shuts off. Paper towel. Lavender under it all. He turns, and for half a second his gaze lands on my right knee like it’s a name. “We’ll take it easy today,” he says, and the fact that he says it like he believes it makes something bitter rise in my throat. “I read the surgical report. ACL reconstruction, meniscus repair. You’ve had… a time.” He doesn’t say ruined. He doesn’t say finished. He doesn’t say what everyone else says with their eyes. “Mandatory,” I remind him, because I need to anchor myself to annoyance instead of fear. “So. Do your worst.” A flicker—humor, maybe, or recognition—crosses his mouth and then he smooths it away. “I’ll do what’s appropriate,” he says, and the words land with unexpected weight. Appropriate. Boundaries. He pulls a rolling stool near the table, but he doesn’t sit yet. “Lie back,” he instructs, gesturing to the plinth. “On your back. Scoot down so your knees are near the edge.” I shift, hands braced behind me. The table paper crackles under my thighs. I lower myself, spine meeting the padded surface, then slide down until my knees hover close to the edge as he said. My head rests flat; the ceiling tiles are a grid I can count if I need to escape. He steps closer, and the air changes—the warmth of another body near mine, the faint scent of his detergent under the clinic smells. He positions himself on my right side, hip aligned with my knee. He finally sits on the stool, knees bent, feet planted to stabilize. Everything deliberate. “I’m going to assess range first,” he says. “Let me know what you feel. Sharp, dull, pulling, pinching.” “I feel like leaving,” I say. His mouth tightens at one corner. “Noted.” He places his left hand under my right heel, palm cradling it so my ankle rests against the base of his thumb. His right hand slides to the front of my shin just below the knee, fingers spread, not pressing the joint itself. The contact is clinical, but my skin reacts anyway—tiny hairs lifting as if my nerves are eager and furious all at once. “Relax your leg,” he says gently. I try. I do. The problem is my body’s definition of relax has changed. Relax now means braced for impact. He begins to flex my knee: guiding my heel toward my buttock in a slow arc. The movement is smooth. The joint resists at first, like a hinge with new screws. I feel the pull along the front of the knee where the graft lives, a tightness that feels like thick fabric being stretched. My quadriceps twitch involuntarily, trying to help, trying to protect. “Let it be heavy,” he murmurs, and his voice is closer than I like, close enough that I can feel sound more than hear it. His fingers on my shin adjust, countering my reflex, keeping the motion controlled. My heel slides along the table paper, the crackle loud in the quiet room. He pauses at the first barrier, holding the knee in flexion. I’m aware of his hands in a way that has nothing to do with ligament mechanics: the warmth of his palm under my heel, the steady pressure of his other hand anchoring my tibia. He’s looking at my knee, not my face. Professional distance like a wall. “What’s that?” he asks. “Pulling,” I manage. “Front. Deep.” “Okay.” He holds for a breath, then gently increases the flexion a few degrees—small, precise. The pain sharpens like someone turning a dial. It’s not a stab, more a concentrated burning under the kneecap, and my breath catches despite myself. My toes curl inside my sock. He stops immediately. “That’s your limit today,” he says, as if he’s already memorized the line between useful discomfort and harm. He eases my leg back down, reversing the arc, supporting the limb so it doesn’t drop. Resentment flares hot and senseless. Not at him, not exactly. At the fact that my limit can be found so easily now. “Let’s check extension,” he says, and slides a small bolster under my right ankle so my heel is propped and my knee hovers slightly off the table. Gravity encourages the knee to straighten. It feels like the back of my knee is being asked to trust empty space. He crouches closer, eyes level with my joint, and with two fingers he palpates gently around the kneecap, then along the tibial tuberosity where the surgical tunnel is. Light touches, but they send signals through me like sparks—my body mapping itself against his hands. My pulse, traitorous, is too loud. “You’re guarding,” he notes quietly. “Because you’re touching me,” I snap, then regret it the moment it leaves my mouth because it’s true in more ways than one. He stills. For a second his gaze flicks up to my face, and I see something there—recognition of the tension, not just muscular. He doesn’t comment on it. He just nods once, as if filing it under constraints. “Take a slow breath,” he says. “In through your nose. Out through your mouth.” Lavender rides the inhale. I hate it for being pleasant. As I exhale, my hamstring loosens a fraction. My knee sinks closer to full extension, the back of it stretching. There’s a thin, tight ache behind the joint, like a rope drawn taut. He places his palm above my knee—not on the kneecap, above it on the lower quadriceps—and applies gentle downward pressure, not forcing, just guiding. With his other hand, he supports under my heel to control the angle. The pressure is firm, and my body responds immediately: my quad jumps, a protective reflex. Pain blooms in the back of the knee, a bright line that makes my jaw clench. “Easy,” he says, and reduces the pressure instantly. His hands don’t leave; they just soften. “That was too much. Tell me before it spikes.” “I did,” I say through my teeth, because I didn’t. I didn’t want to give him that power. He waits, patient in a way that makes me want to throw something. “Try again,” he says. “But you’re in charge. I’ll follow.” I swallow. My throat feels tight. “Okay.” He resets: heel supported, palm above the knee. This time he barely presses, letting gravity do most of it. The stretch is uncomfortable but tolerable, like holding a door closed against a wind. My breathing evens, unwillingly synced to his count. “Good,” he murmurs, and the word hits my skin like heat. He rolls the bolster away and stands. “We’ll do a hip and hamstring sequence,” he says. “It’ll help unload the knee.” “Sure,” I say, because arguing would be admitting I care. He moves to the foot of the table. “Slide down a little more,” he instructs. I scoot until my hips are closer to the edge, my legs extended. He positions himself at my right side again, facing my feet. “I’m going to do a straight-leg raise stretch,” he explains. “Keep your knee as straight as you can. Tell me when you feel the stretch.” He lifts my right leg by placing one hand under my heel again, the other under my calf near the Achilles, avoiding pressure on the knee. My leg rises, hip flexing. The motion is controlled; my pelvis wants to tilt, so he places his free hand on my left hip crest briefly—flat palm, anchoring my pelvis to keep the stretch in the hamstring rather than my lower back. That touch—on bone, through fabric—makes my stomach tighten. “Don’t lift your hip,” he says calmly. “I’m not,” I lie, and he just keeps his hand there, steady, proof. As my leg reaches about sixty degrees, the back of my thigh begins to complain: a deep pulling that runs from sit bone to behind the knee. The knee itself feels tight, reluctant to stay straight. My foot flexes reflexively, toes drawing back toward my shin. “There,” I say, voice thinner than I want. He holds the position, micro-adjusting by rotating my leg slightly inward from the hip, aligning the stretch more laterally. The sensation shifts, finding a sharper band along the outer hamstring. My fingers curl around the edge of the table. The pain is clean, honest. It doesn’t feel like failure; it feels like physics. “Stay with it,” he says, quiet. He’s closer now, his forearm near my calf, his breath a faint movement against my skin when he speaks. I can’t look at his face without acknowledging the electricity in my own body, so I stare at the ceiling grid and count tiles. Eight. Nine. Ten. The stretch intensifies as the seconds pass. My hamstring quivers, trying to escape. Sweat beads at my hairline, not from exertion but from endurance. “You’re doing well,” he says, and I hate that my chest warms at the praise. “Don’t,” I say. He pauses. “Don’t what?” “Don’t talk like you’re… coaching me,” I say, and the words are rawer than intended. Coaching is for athletes. For people who have somewhere to go back to. His hands don’t move, but his voice shifts, softer. “I’m not coaching,” he says. “I’m guiding. Different job.” Different life, my mind supplies. Different identity. He slowly lowers my leg, releasing the stretch with care so it doesn’t snap back. The relief is immediate and almost nauseating. My hamstring throbs, alive. He steps back, giving me air. For a moment there’s only the lavender and the hum of the lights and the paper under me. “Last thing,” he says. “Gentle patellar mobilizations. It’ll feel weird.” “I’m already there,” I mutter. He moves to my right side again and sits. He bends my knee slightly by placing a rolled towel under it, so the joint is relaxed. Then, with both thumbs, he contacts the edges of my kneecap—one thumb on the medial border, the other on the lateral—while his fingers support behind my knee. His touch is surprisingly intimate for something so small: skin on skin, pressure precise. He glides the patella medially, a subtle shift over the femoral groove. It feels like something inside me is sliding under a lid. Not painful, but unsettling, like realizing a part of you is movable in ways you never noticed. Then he glides it laterally, superiorly, inferiorly—each direction measured. The tissue around it is tender; I flinch when he goes inferior, toward the scarred area. “Too much?” he asks. “No,” I say quickly, because if I say yes then I’m admitting weakness, and if I admit weakness then what am I? His thumbs pause. “Your body says yes,” he replies, not unkindly. Heat crawls up my neck. I can feel my pulse under the skin where he’s touching, and I’m suddenly furious at my own involuntary honesty—at how my knee flinches, how my breath changes, how my skin registers him even when my mind insists on distance. He finishes the mobilizations and removes his hands. The absence is immediate, like stepping away from a heater in winter. He stands and steps toward the counter to jot notes. His back is to me, giving me privacy I don’t deserve. I sit up slowly, swinging my legs over the edge with care. My right knee feels simultaneously looser and more aware, like it’s been reminded it exists. He turns back, clipboard held against his chest. “Same time next week,” he says. “Mandatory,” I remind him again, but it lands weaker now. My voice betrays me with something like tiredness. He nods, gaze steady but contained. “I’ll see you then.” As I slide off the table, my right foot finding the floor, pain whispers up my leg in familiar patterns. Resentment rises with it—not just at the injury, but at recovery itself, at the way it demands I participate in my own dismantling and rebuilding. And underneath that resentment, quieter and more dangerous, is the memory of his hands: controlled, confident, careful at the edge of pain. The lavender follows me out into the hall, clinging to my clothes like a lie—like softness is possible in a room built for repair.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates exceptional technical craft and emotional sophistication. The author successfully navigates the complex prompt requirements, delivering a narrative that maintains anatomical precision while exploring the psychological terrain of a shattered athletic identity confronting both physical rehabilitation and unresolved attraction. The first-person voice is consistently authentic throughout, capturing the protagonist's bitter resentment and vulnerability without melodrama. The opening with lavender immediately establishes sensory grounding and emotional displacement—the protagonist's discomfort with anything soft or healing in this clinical space. The voice maintains its edge while revealing deeper layers of pain and longing. The physical therapy sequences are remarkably well-executed, demonstrating clear understanding of rehabilitation techniques. Each movement—knee flexion assessment, straight-leg raises, patellar mobilizations—is described with anatomical accuracy and spatial coherence. The author successfully translates technical procedures into visceral, emotionally charged experiences without sacrificing medical authenticity. The sexual tension is handled with sophisticated restraint. Rather than explicit sexuality, the piece explores the charged intimacy of therapeutic touch—professional boundaries strained by history and attraction. The protagonist's awareness of pulse, breath, and involuntary responses feels genuine rather than manufactured. Character development is nuanced, particularly in how both figures navigate their shared past. The physiotherapist's professional competence contrasts with the protagonist's identity crisis, yet neither character is reduced to simple archetypes. Their dialogue is sparse but weighted, carrying subtext about transformation, loss, and the different paths their lives have taken. The prose demonstrates strong control, with sensory details that serve both atmosphere and character development. The recurring lavender motif effectively represents the protagonist's resistance to healing and softness. Metaphors feel earned rather than decorative—the body "mapping itself against his hands" and pain described as "bright lines" and "concentrated burning." The piece maintains emotional complexity without resolution, which feels appropriate for a single therapy session. The protagonist's resentment toward recovery itself is psychologically authentic—many athletes struggle with rehabilitation not just physically but as a process that forces them to confront their changed identity. Minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the prose approaches purple territory, though it generally maintains restraint. Some descriptions of pain and sensation, while vivid, occasionally border on overwrought. The piece also relies heavily on internal monologue, though this serves the first-person perspective well. The ending strikes an appropriate note—no false transformation or sudden breakthrough, but a subtle acknowledgment of the complexity ahead. The final image of lavender "clinging to my clothes like a lie—like softness is possible in a room built for repair" effectively captures the protagonist's ongoing resistance while hinting at possibility. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 6 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 6.0, Overwrought: 5.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Historical fiction: High Seas and Low Vices — Score: 84.8
Prompt:
High Seas and Low Vices: British Naval Officer in the Opium Trade Character: Lieutenant James Merrick, a high-ranking officer in the British Royal Navy stationed in Canton, China in the 1830s. Once promising and decorated, now struggling with a severe opium addiction he hides from his superiors. Synopsis: Write a chapter following Lieutenant Merrick during a single day as he shirks his official naval duties in what has become a daily need to satiate the dragon. Told primarily in dialogue with the characters he interacts with. Focus on brief slices of his journey through the shadowy underworld of Canton: interactions with acquaintances, negotiations with local dealers, schemes and unsavoury jobs taken to fund his habit. Writing Task: Use rich sensory details to describe a day in the life of James Merrick. Write for a real sense of time & place while avoiding cliche. First person, past tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The morning bell on the *HMS* **Calliope** struck with the same clean, metallic confidence it always had, as if it could ring order into a world that no longer listened. I lay on my back in my narrow cot and watched the beams above me wobble with each small swell of the Pearl River. My tongue felt too large for my mouth. My skin had the dry itch of salt that never quite washed off. A knuckle rapped the bulkhead. “Merrick.” It was Harding’s voice—Master’s Mate, earnest as a ledger. “Sir? Captain wants you on deck. There’s a boat due from the factories.” I cleared my throat and tasted yesterday’s smoke, bitter and sweet at once. “Tell the Captain I’m… indisposed.” There was a pause long enough for him to decide whether to believe me. “Indisposed,” Harding repeated, careful. “Shall I send the surgeon?” “No.” Too sharp. I softened it. “No, thank you. Give me—give me a quarter hour. I’ll be up.” Harding’s boots withdrew. The ship creaked and sighed around me. Somewhere above, men called to one another, a rope rasped through a block, and river air slid in through a hatch seam carrying Canton’s morning—woodsmoke, boiled rice, fish offal, and the faint sourness of the shore. I dressed as if dressing might restore me. Shirt. Waistcoat. The blue coat with its gold lace that still looked like a promise when I caught it in the looking-glass. I fastened the buttons with hands that would not quite keep still. I told myself it was the river’s motion. I told myself a great many things. On deck the light was already hard. Junks slid by like black insects, their tan sails patched and stained. Beyond them, the factories sat in their row—foreign brick and plaster, flags drooping in the humidity like tired tongues. A sampan bumped alongside with a hollow thud. Chinese voices carried over the water in bright, clipped bursts. It all sounded like someone else’s life. Harding met me at the gangway. He looked past me at my collar, my eyes. “You’re pale, sir.” “I’ve been worse.” I forced a smile that made my face feel borrowed. “What did the Captain want?” Harding’s gaze flicked toward the quarterdeck. “Mr. Dent’s clerk brought papers. There’s a dispute with the Hoppo men. Captain says he needs you ashore by noon—make it plain we won’t be—” he swallowed and chose his words, “—harassed.” Harassed. A neat word for being squeezed in a city built on squeeze. “Ashore by noon,” I repeated, as if I were noting it. “Very good.” Harding hesitated. “Sir… there are whispers. The purser says—” “Tell the purser to mind his own accounts.” The words came out quiet, but they had an edge that made Harding stiffen. I clapped his shoulder with more familiarity than I felt. “Noon.” I went back down before he could answer. In my cabin I opened my sea chest, lifted the folded shirts, and took out what I had left: a pair of silver cufflinks my mother had sent when I made lieutenant, and a small Spanish coin I’d carried since Gibraltar because I liked the weight of it. The cufflinks winked in the dim light like guilty eyes. By the time I stepped into the ship’s boat, the river had grown louder. Heat rose off the water in a breath that smelled of mud. The oars dipped with a rhythm meant to be calming. It wasn’t. The coxswain, a square-faced fellow named Barnes, kept his eyes forward. “Factories, sir?” “Not yet.” I kept my voice even. “Land me by the old hong—where the godowns crowd the lane. I’ve business.” Barnes glanced back, just a fraction. “Aye, sir.” The city came at us in layers: first the stone steps, slick with algae; then the press of bodies—coolies carrying shoulder poles that bowed under baskets, women with infants slung like bundles, men in long gowns squatting beside baskets of eels that twitched in slow, dying loops. Canton smelled like a thousand kitchens and a thousand drains. It was the world’s stomach. As I climbed out, a boy appeared at my elbow, thin as a reed and quicker than a thought. “Fan-qui officer,” he said in sing-song English, “I show, I carry, I find.” “I need neither.” My stomach tightened; the boy’s presence was too much like a mirror. “Go.” He stayed, matching my pace. “You go Flower Street. You go ‘sleep house’. You go smoke. I know.” I stopped so suddenly he nearly ran into me. “What did you say?” He looked up without fear, only calculation. “I know where you go. You give one dollar, I no talk.” There it was: Canton’s honest commerce. I leaned down until my nose caught the sour-sweet on his breath—fermented fruit, maybe rice wine. “Listen,” I said softly. “If you follow me again, I’ll have Barnes put you in the river and see if you float.” His eyes narrowed a little. Not cowed—measuring. Then he vanished into the crowd as if he’d never been. I walked fast, letting the city swallow me. The lanes narrowed. Foreign faces thinned. The air grew stiller, thicker. Somewhere a gong sounded, and a man called prices that meant nothing to me. My coat clung to my back. Under my tongue, my saliva turned metallic. By the time I reached the alley that led to the place I’d sworn off yesterday, the scent hit as it always did, unmistakable and wrong: rotting mangoes. Not just overripe—collapsed, pulped, the sugars turned to vinegar and decay. The smell seeped into the stone, into the damp wooden lintels, into the very breath. A woman squatted by a basket of the fruit, stirring the mess with a stick as if she could make it useful again. Flies lifted and settled in lazy clouds. At the door—a plank set into a frame too small for comfort—a man waited with his arms folded. He was Cantonese, lean, with a scar like a pale worm at the corner of his mouth. He wore clean cotton, which meant he either had pride or money. “Lieutenant Merrick,” he said in English that had learned its manners from merchants. “You late.” “Open the door, Liang.” Liang’s eyes went to my cuffs, my lace. “You bring silver?” I held up the cufflinks in my palm. “This.” He did not reach for them. “Silver better.” “This is silver.” “Not same.” Liang’s smile showed the scar pulling. “English man silver have story. Story trouble.” “Everything has a story.” I kept my voice level by force. “Do you want it or not?” Liang’s nostrils flared, as if he smelled the rot and found it pleasing. “You smoke now. You pay later.” “I don’t do later.” Because later was when the shaking returned, when the day unstitched. “Take them.” He took the cufflinks between finger and thumb as though they might stain him. “You go inside,” he said, and pushed the plank aside. The room beyond was low-ceilinged, the air brown with old smoke. Lamps burned with a weak, oily flame, turning faces into masks. Men lay on narrow platforms like bodies set out for burial, their mouths slack, eyes half-closed. The sound was a low murmur of breath and an occasional cough that came from deep inside the ribs. A boy—older than the one outside, younger than he ought to be doing this—brought a pipe and a small tray. The opium was a glossy black bead on the end of a needle. “You have good today?” I asked Liang, though I would have taken bad. Liang shrugged. “All good. From Patna,” he said, as if naming a vineyard. I sat. The wood was warm from other men’s bones. My hands steadied the way they always did when the pipe was near, as if the dragon’s leash ran through my fingers. Liang crouched beside me. “You angry,” he observed. “I’m not angry.” “You angry because you pay with pretty thing. You angry because ship man watch.” I looked at him. In the lamplight his pupils were huge, black pools. “What do you want, Liang?” He leaned closer. The mango-rot clung to him, sweet and sick. “You want smoke. I want favour. You high officer. You can walk places. You can make paper stamp. You can look other way.” I laughed once, without humour. “You speak as if I’m a customs house.” Liang’s smile didn’t change. “You are custom. You are house. Today you bring me paper—pass for two crates. My men move through river. No Hoppo trouble.” “That’s smuggling.” The word landed with a dead weight. The navy in my blood sat up and looked at me, disgusted. Liang’s gaze slid to my hands, to the tremor that had started again now that talking had put distance between me and the pipe. “You are already in trouble,” he said simply. “I help you. You help me.” “Two crates,” I said, buying time with my voice while my body begged. “And if I refuse?” Liang’s eyes flicked toward the door. “Little boy outside know your face. Many boys. Many mouth. Your Captain hear. Your life end. You go home with shame.” The ship in my mind—clean decks, white-painted gun carriages, orders ringing crisp—tilted and began to slide away. “Give me the pipe,” I said. Liang nodded to the boy. The boy heated the bead over the lamp until it bubbled, then worked it into the bowl with practiced care. The smell rose—dark, resinous, like burnt sugar and old wood. My mouth watered with dread and longing. “You sign paper,” Liang said, as if we were discussing tea. He produced a folded sheet, already inked, and a small brush. My hand hovered over it. “What is it?” I asked. “Pass,” he said. “Chop. One chop.” “I don’t have authority for—” “You have seal?” Liang asked. “Navy seal. Or merchant seal. You have friend.” My mind raced through names: Dent’s clerk, eager and bribable; a supercargo who owed me for a night’s protection in Macao; even Harding, god help me, who would do anything if he thought it for the ship’s honour. The pipe waited. The room breathed. The mango-rot pressed at the cracks in the wall like a living thing. “I can get you a chop,” I said at last, hating myself for how quickly the words came. “Not today.” Liang’s expression tightened for the first time. “Today,” he said. “You smoke today. You pay today.” “I don’t have it.” Liang lifted a hand, and the boy took the pipe away as smoothly as if he were removing a plate. My throat closed. A cold sweat broke along my spine. Liang watched me with a craftsman’s patience. “You have job,” he said. “Small. Easy. You do now. You bring money back. Then you smoke until you smile.” “What job?” He nodded toward the back, where a curtain hung, greasy with fingertips. “Foreign man come. Drunk. He owe me. You go talk. You wear coat. You make him remember.” “I’m not your bully.” Liang’s scar twitched. “You are hungry man,” he said. “Hungry do many thing.” For a moment I saw myself from above: Lieutenant James Merrick, His Majesty’s Navy, sitting in a Canton den that stank of mango rot, bargaining his commission for a mouthful of smoke. I stood. My knees threatened to fold. “Who is the man?” Liang motioned, and the boy lifted the curtain. A European voice slurred from behind it, loud with gin and grievance. “—told you, you yellow bastard, I’ll pay when I damned well—” It was familiar. Too familiar. “Mr. Hargreaves?” I said before I could stop myself. The merchant stumbled into view, his waistcoat stained, his face flushed. He blinked at me, and for a second his expression cleared into recognition. “Merrick?” he said, incredulous. Then he laughed, a harsh bark. “Christ. They’ve sent the Navy to collect my debts now?” Liang’s eyes gleamed. “You know him,” he said. Hargreaves swayed, spreading his hands. “Lieutenant, old fellow—this is a misunderstanding. These fellows—” “It’s not a misunderstanding,” Liang said mildly. “He drink. He owe. You make him pay.” Hargreaves leaned close to me, his breath sharp with spirits. His voice dropped. “What are you doing here?” I heard Harding’s morning voice—*There are whispers.* I saw the Captain’s eyes, cool and appraising. I smelled the river, the tar, the clean ambition I used to have. “I’m doing my duty,” I lied, and the lie tasted like the mango rot outside. Hargreaves’ gaze slid past me to the pipe on the tray. Understanding landed on his face like a slap. “Oh,” he said, very softly. “Oh, you poor bastard.” Liang cleared his throat, impatient. “Money,” he said. Hargreaves straightened with effort. “How much?” Liang named a sum that made Hargreaves’ eyebrows leap. “You’re mad,” Hargreaves said. “I haven’t that on me.” Liang looked at me. “Then you take watch,” he said. “Gold watch. Ring. You take. He pay later.” Hargreaves glanced down at his own hands as if seeing the rings for the first time. “Merrick—” My fingers closed around his wrist. The skin was hot and damp. He flinched, and I felt something break in me that had been holding for years. “Give it,” I said, my voice flat. He searched my face, perhaps for a trace of the man who’d once quoted regulations at him over brandy, who’d once laughed without needing to earn it. Whatever he saw made him comply. He pulled off the ring, fumbling, then unclasped the watch chain and dropped the weight of it into my palm. The gold was warm from his body. Heavy. Real. Liang took it with a satisfied nod. “Good,” he said, and with a gesture the boy brought the pipe back as if it were a reward for obedience. I sank onto the platform again. The room narrowed to the lamp flame and the bowl of the pipe. The opium bubbled, then settled, glossy as a beetle’s wing. I drew the smoke in slowly, careful not to cough, letting it coat my mouth and throat. For a moment nothing changed. Then the edges softened. The ache behind my eyes eased. The river’s constant motion inside my bones stilled. Even the mango-rot seemed less hostile, merely a fact of the world. Liang’s voice came from far away. “You bring chop today,” he said, as if reminding me to post a letter. Hargreaves stood unsteadily near the curtain, watching me with a mixture of pity and disgust he did not bother to hide. “By noon,” Harding’s voice echoed in my head, absurd and distant—*Captain wants you ashore by noon.* I exhaled. The smoke left my lungs like a confession I could not quite make. “I’ll bring it,” I heard myself say. Outside, Canton continued its commerce—the calls, the footsteps, the splash of oars. Time moved on with or without me. Inside, on the narrow wooden platform, the day became only the next breath, and then the next, and then the sweet, treacherous space between them.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical craft and atmospheric writing, successfully creating an immersive portrait of a naval officer's descent into opium addiction in 1830s Canton. The author effectively captures the historical setting through sensory details like "woodsmoke, boiled rice, fish offal" and the "mango-rot" that permeates the opium den, creating a visceral sense of place. The characterization of Lieutenant Merrick is nuanced and believable. His internal conflict between his naval identity and his addiction is well-rendered through subtle details like his trembling hands and the way he tells himself "a great many things." The progression from morning denial to afternoon capitulation feels psychologically authentic, avoiding melodrama while maintaining emotional weight. The dialogue serves multiple functions effectively - revealing character relationships, advancing plot, and building tension. Exchanges with Harding show Merrick's deteriorating position, while the conversation with Liang demonstrates the predatory nature of addiction and how it compromises moral boundaries. The dialogue feels period-appropriate without being stilted. The prose style is generally elegant, with strong imagery and metaphorical language that enhances rather than overwhelms the narrative. Phrases like "the dragon's leash ran through my fingers" and "the ship in my mind...tilted and began to slide away" effectively convey Merrick's psychological state. The writing maintains consistent voice throughout, balancing literary sophistication with accessibility. The story structure follows a clear arc from morning duties through the descent into the opium den, culminating in Merrick's moral compromise. The pacing builds tension effectively, and the ending feels earned rather than forced. The piece avoids both unearned redemption and gratuitous darkness, instead presenting a realistic portrait of addiction's grip. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the prose edges toward being overwrought, and certain metaphors could be more original. However, these are relatively minor issues in an otherwise accomplished piece that successfully fulfills the prompt's requirements while delivering genuine emotional impact. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 5.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Humour: Sisyphus Gives Advice — Score: 88.8
Prompt:
Sisyphus Gives Advice Write a comedic scene in the style of Terry Pratchett featuring Sisyphus, who has started an advice column while continuing his eternal boulder-pushing. Rather than being bitter about his punishment, Sisyphus has developed a comfortably zen emotional intelligence and wisdom from his centuries of repetitive labor. Not in the cliche ways you might expect -- he's actually very grounded, warm & connected with the everyday human plight. He dictates responses to "Crow," his feathered familiar who serves as both scribe and mail carrier. The piece should include Sisyphus thoughtfully answering several advice-seekers' letters about everyday problems (relationship troubles, work-life balance, dealing with difficult people, life purpose doubts) while periodically returning to his boulder-pushing duties. His advice should be surprisingly insightful and practical. The humor should emerge naturally from the messages he receives, from mundane to risque. Sisyphus should genuinely enjoy helping others, finding meaning in this new pursuit while maintaining his boulder routine. The humour should be *understated and not forced*. Contrary to expectation, almost none of his advice involves boulder rolling metaphors (though he does sneak *one* subtle in there), nor a treatise on stoicism. We are also going against the obvious fish-out-of-water trope; in fact, he's surprisingly a natural at this. In all of this , it's important to *show, don't tell*. The format should be largely epistolary, with the occasional interjection for scene setting. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The boulder waited where it always waited: at the bottom of the hill, like a large, patient obligation. Sisyphus set his palms against it, leaned in, and began the day’s conversation with gravity. The stone moved with the familiar reluctance of something that had never been asked to change its mind. Above, the hill rose in that particular way hills have when they’ve been told they are part of the story. “Morning,” said Crow, hopping onto the boulder with the air of someone arriving at a desk. He shook out his wings and produced, from somewhere that shouldn’t have had room, a bundle of letters tied with a bit of string. Also a charcoal nub. Also, for reasons known only to crows, a small brass thimble. Sisyphus nodded. “Let’s see who needs a hand today.” Crow cocked his head. “Caw.” “That’s what I said.” Sisyphus pushed. The boulder rolled. Crow, balanced on top, rode along like a particularly judgemental paperweight. They’d started the column three weeks ago, after a traveller’s prayer had drifted down into the underworld addressed To Whom It May Concern, and had, through a series of bureaucratic misunderstandings and an obliging bird, ended up on Sisyphus’s hill. The first reply had been dictated between breaths. The second had been better. By the fifth, Crow had taken to drawing a little emblem at the top of each response: a neat circle, a line beneath it, and, if he was feeling artistic, two small marks that might have been eyes or might have been crumbs. Crow untied the string with the delicate spite of a creature that resented having feet shaped like commas. Sisyphus cleared his throat. “Dear Sisyphus,” he began, because people always started that way, as if naming someone made them realer. “I think my partner is bored with me. We don’t fight. We don’t even disagree. It’s like living with a polite stranger who shares my bed and says ‘thank you’ when I pass the salt. I tried wearing new perfume. He said it smelled ‘nice.’ What do I do? — ‘Dull in Delphi.’” Crow scratched at the charcoal. “Caw?” he offered, which meant, in Crow’s language, *you could suggest perfume in the shape of a dagger.* Sisyphus smiled without looking up from the slope. “Tell her—” Crow ruffled his feathers. “It might be a him.” “Tell them,” Sisyphus corrected, and the boulder creaked as if approving inclusive pronouns. “Tell them to stop trying to produce feelings by rearranging the surface of the world. Perfume is fine. Salt is fine. But boredom is usually hunger that doesn’t know what it’s hungry for.” Crow began to write, his beak making a scratch-scratch like small feet on dry leaves. “Ask your partner one specific question,” Sisyphus said. “Not ‘are you happy,’ because people panic at that and start inventorying their whole life. Ask: ‘What was the best part of your day yesterday?’ Then listen to the answer all the way to the end, even if it’s about a sandwich. People want to be seen in the little things before they can talk about the big ones.” The boulder rolled over a patch of gravel. Sisyphus adjusted his shoulder. “Then tell them what the best part of *your* day was. Make it small, true, and not a hint. Not ‘the best part was when you finally came home.’ Say: ‘The best part was when I saw that ridiculous dog in the market and it looked like it was judging olives.’ Let it be ordinary. Let it be shared. Polite strangers don’t trade the small truths.” Crow paused, then added a neat line beneath the last sentence, as if underlining *ordinary*. “And,” Sisyphus added after a moment, “if you haven’t laughed together in a while, don’t wait for a joke. Put on a pot of something, sit at the table, and tell each other the most embarrassing thing you did this week. You go first. Tenderness is often just taking turns being unarmed.” Crow wrote. Then, as an afterthought, drew a tiny olive with a face. They pushed in companionable silence for a time, until the hill’s angle turned the conversation into shorter phrases. When they reached the first flat ledge—there were a few, like commas in a long sentence—Crow pecked at the next envelope. “This one smells like onions,” Crow observed. “Read it.” Crow held it up. “Dear Column Person. My supervisor says we need to be ‘a family’ at work, but then she schedules meetings at sunrise and sends messages at midnight. I feel guilty when I don’t answer, and exhausted when I do. Is it disloyal to want to be… not a family? — ‘Sleepless in Sparta.’” Sisyphus snorted softly. “Families,” he said, “are wonderful. Families also contain people who borrow your cloak and return it with holes.” Crow wrote quickly. He enjoyed writing the parts that were slightly sharp. “Tell them,” Sisyphus dictated, “that you are happy to be part of a team. Teams have boundaries. Teams have rules. Families… have unspoken expectations and an aunt who will corner you about your hair.” Crow’s eyes gleamed. He added the aunt without being asked. “Pick a time,” Sisyphus continued, “when you are calm and not already resentful. Tell your supervisor: ‘I do my best work when I’m rested. I will read messages between these hours.’ Then follow through. The first few times will feel like you’re doing something wrong. That’s the guilt talking, because guilt is just fear wearing a respectable robe.” He shifted the boulder again. “If you can, put it in writing. People respect paper more than they respect promises, which is an odd thing about humans, considering how often paper is set on fire.” Crow paused, as if considering whether to write *odd* or *deeply silly*. He wrote both, then scratched out *deeply* because it looked like a worm. “And if she insists on ‘family,’” Sisyphus added, “smile and say: ‘Then we should discuss inheritance.’” Crow’s caw came out like a cough. He wrote it down anyway. By the time they’d reached the second ledge, the boulder had acquired a dusting of grey. Crow had acquired a certain smugness. The next letter had been opened and resealed with something that had once been honey. “Dear Sisyphus,” Sisyphus read, because Crow’s handwriting for other people’s handwriting was worse. “I have a neighbour who is always… there. Always commenting. Always asking. Always standing too close to the doorway like a human lint trap. I’ve tried being polite. I’ve tried being rude. Nothing works. How do you deal with someone who drains you just by existing near you? — ‘Worn Thin.’” Crow’s eyes narrowed. “Caw,” he said, meaning, *you could suggest a moat.* “No,” Sisyphus said thoughtfully. “A moat is a lot of maintenance.” He pushed again, steady and slow. “Tell them: you’re not responsible for another person’s hunger for attention. Politeness doesn’t mean unlimited access. You can be kind and still have a closed door.” Crow wrote with the grave concentration of a priest copying out a sacred text about closed doors. “Choose a phrase,” Sisyphus said, “and use it every time. Something simple. ‘I can’t talk right now, I have things to do.’ Then—this is important—do the things. Don’t stand there explaining. Don’t give reasons the neighbour can pick at like a scab. Just repeat the phrase, smile, and step away.” Crow added: *Smile like a wall.* “If they ask why,” Sisyphus continued, “say: ‘I need my time.’ And if they accuse you of being unfriendly, don’t argue about your character. Argue about the situation. ‘I like you fine. I still need space.’” He glanced at Crow. “Also, consider giving them something small and finite. ‘I have five minutes.’ Set a timer. When it goes off, leave. People who drain you rely on your sense of endlessness.” Crow wrote *endlessness* and, for a moment, looked up at the hill. The boulder rolled on. At the third ledge, Crow produced an envelope that looked as if it had been through a minor war. One corner was dark with smudge, and most of the ink had bled into a grey fog. Sisyphus squinted. “Oh dear.” Crow leaned over his shoulder, as if his beak could interpret ambiguity. Sisyphus held the letter to the light, which in the underworld was mostly theoretical. “Dear… S…y—” he began. “I am… in a… position… with my… er… *boss?* Or possibly *boar?* There is… a… ‘tavern’… or ‘garden’… and then—” He frowned. “It says: ‘He keeps… putting his…’ and then it’s just… a smear.” Crow made a noise that could have been laughter if crows didn’t insist on making everything sound like a small tragedy. Sisyphus tried again. “There is also ‘my… husband’ crossed out and replaced with ‘my… *hustler*’?” Crow scratched his head. “Caw,” he suggested, meaning, *perhaps do not assume it is livestock.* Sisyphus breathed in through his nose, the way one does when trying not to become part of the joke. “All right,” he said carefully. “We have a letter that is either about workplace harassment, marital misunderstandings, or an overly familiar pig.” Crow nodded solemnly. Sisyphus dictated, slowly, so Crow could make the words as clear as the original was not. “To the writer of the Smudged Letter: I can’t read all of your question, but I can read enough to know you feel uncomfortable, pressured, and unsure if you’re allowed to object.” Crow wrote, the charcoal firm. “You are allowed,” Sisyphus continued. “If someone is touching you, speaking to you, or asking you for things you don’t want—whether they are your boss, your husband, your hustler, or a boar in a garden—you do not need a perfect argument. You only need a clear ‘no.’” Crow’s head tilted at *boar in a garden* as if he approved of including all plausible parties. “If it is your boss,” Sisyphus went on, “write down what happened and when. Tell someone you trust. Look for allies, because people like that count on isolation. If it is your partner, tell them plainly what you don’t like, and watch what they do next. Apologies are easy. Change is rarer.” He paused, then added, “If it is, somehow, a boar: stop feeding it. That’s how most boars start thinking they’re part of the household.” Crow wrote the boar line with particular relish. The boulder reached a steeper section. Sisyphus’ breath shortened. Crow fell silent, leaning forward as if to help by being very intent about it. When they reached the top—because it always had a top, even if the day didn’t reward it—Sisyphus stopped. He rested his forehead against the stone. The underworld air was cool, like a cellar. Crow hopped down and offered the next letter with the kind of respect one gives to someone who has just done something both pointless and difficult. “This one,” Crow said, “has no perfume, onions, or smudge. Just despair.” “Ah,” Sisyphus said. “The classic scent.” He unfolded it. “Dear Sisyphus. I don’t know what I’m for. Everyone else seems to have a calling. I have a job, friends, obligations, and sometimes joy, but it feels like I’m missing the thing that makes it all… cohere. I’m tired of searching. What if there is nothing? — ‘Unmoored.’” Sisyphus read it twice. The boulder, behind him, was very quiet, as if listening. He dictated, softly. “There are people who find a single purpose and build their whole life around it. There are people who find many small purposes and stitch them together. Neither is a failure.” Crow wrote more slowly, as if aware that the words had weight. “Start with what’s already true,” Sisyphus said. “When do you forget to check the time? When do you feel a little more like yourself after doing something? Make a list of those moments. Not grand achievements. Ordinary ones. Helping a friend move a table. Fixing something that’s been broken for too long. Making someone laugh in a way that makes their shoulders drop.” He glanced down the hill, where the path curved like a thought you couldn’t stop having. “Purpose is often less like a lightning strike and more like a trail you notice because you keep walking it. If you wait to feel certain, you may spend your life waiting. Do one small thing that feels aligned, and then another. Let coherence be something you practice.” Crow wrote *practice* and underlined it. Sisyphus added, almost as an aside, “Also, don’t confuse ‘nothing feels meaningful’ with ‘I need rest.’ Many crises of purpose are simply exhaustion wearing a philosopher’s hat.” Crow made a quiet, appreciative sound. Sisyphus folded the letter. He placed his hands on the boulder again. “All right,” he said. Crow tucked the finished replies under his wing, already thinking about who would be pleased, who would be indignant, and who would claim they’d always known that about the boar. Sisyphus leaned in. The stone moved. For a moment—just a moment—he glanced at the neat stack of outgoing letters and the long, patient hill, and he smiled as if at two chores that had unexpectedly turned out to be the same kind of thing. Halfway down, Crow said, “Caw.” “Yes?” “Someone sent a thimble.” Sisyphus looked at the small brass thimble in Crow’s claws. He considered. “Write back,” he said. “Tell them thank you. And ask what it’s for.” Crow dipped his beak, already composing. The boulder rolled. The day continued. And somewhere above the underworld, someone would unfold a reply and feel, if only for a few breaths, that they weren’t pushing alone. On the last line, Crow added the emblem: a circle, a line, and—because he was in a charitable mood—two eyes that looked, quite unmistakably, like they were smiling.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates exceptional craft in executing a complex creative brief. The author successfully captures Terry Pratchett's distinctive voice through understated humor, philosophical observations wrapped in mundane details, and a gentle absurdist sensibility. The characterization of Sisyphus is particularly strong - he emerges as genuinely wise and grounded without falling into cliché, and his relationship with Crow provides natural comedic moments through their dynamic. The epistolary format works effectively, with each advice letter feeling authentic and the responses demonstrating real insight. The author skillfully avoids the obvious pitfalls mentioned in the prompt - there are no heavy-handed boulder metaphors, no fish-out-of-water comedy, and no forced philosophical treatises. Instead, the humor emerges organically from situations like the smudged letter that could involve "workplace harassment, marital misunderstandings, or an overly familiar pig." The prose style successfully emulates Pratchett's approach with observations like "guilt is just fear wearing a respectable robe" and "People respect paper more than they respect promises, which is an odd thing about humans, considering how often paper is set on fire." These feel authentically Pratchettesque without being derivative. The piece maintains excellent pacing, weaving between the physical act of boulder-pushing and the advice-giving seamlessly. The advice itself is genuinely practical and insightful, particularly the response about workplace boundaries and the final letter about finding purpose. The author shows rather than tells throughout, letting character emerge through action and dialogue. The ending strikes the right note - neither overly sentimental nor cynically detached, but finding meaning in the connection between helping others and the eternal task. The final image of the smiling emblem provides closure without being saccharine. Minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the Pratchett pastiche becomes slightly self-conscious, and some descriptions that edge toward being overly precious. However, these are minimal compared to the overall achievement of the piece. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Coming of age: Lost & Found in Osaka — Score: 77.2
Prompt:
Lost & Found in Osaka Slice of Life / Coming-of-Age: First Connection. Write one scene within a larger story set in Osaka, Japan. A shy, introverted teenager & synthesizer nerd, is browsing the electronics district of Den Den Town. She is drawn to the sound of an electric guitar. A girl, slightly older and radiating confidence, is busking near the entrance to a crowded arcade, playing a blistering rendition of a classic anime theme. The scene takes us through their initial awkward interaction, transitioning into a surprisingly easy conversation. The busker, intrigued by the teenager's quiet intensity and knowledge of music, suggests they grab some sushi at a nearby kaitenzushi (conveyor belt sushi) restaurant. Write primarily in dialogue, capturing the distinct voices of the two characters: the teenager's hesitant and -- initially -- awkward speech, and the busker's more outgoing and playful tone. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The guitar cut through Den Den Town like a bright thread, weaving between the call-and-response of shopkeepers and the electronic chirps leaking from open doors. A blistering melody—too fast to be background noise, too familiar to ignore—pulled her feet forward before she could talk herself out of it. By the entrance to a crowded arcade, a girl stood with an electric guitar and a small amp, fingers flying. She played like she was chasing something and catching it every bar—an old anime theme, the kind that made the air feel like a title card. A handful of people lingered. Some filmed. A kid bounced in place. The teenager stayed back, half-hidden by a gachapon machine and her own backpack strap clenched too tight. The busker hit the final run—clean, bright, impossible—then cut the last chord sharp. For half a second, the street noise rushed back in to fill the gap. “Okay,” the busker announced, grinning at her little audience. “If you’re gonna stare, at least clap.” People laughed and did. Coins clinked into her open case. The teenager’s hands came together late, awkwardly. One clap too loud. Then she stopped, cheeks heating, and stared at her shoes like they’d betrayed her. The busker bent to adjust something on her pedalboard—barely a board, more like a scuffed plank with stickers. She glanced up mid-twist and caught the teenager watching. Not just watching—listening, like she was taking notes with her whole body. The busker’s eyes narrowed, amused. “You. Hoodie. You actually know that song, don’t you?” The teenager’s throat tightened. Her fingers went straight to the strap again. “I—um. Y-yes.” She swallowed. “I mean. I know it.” “Thought so.” The busker stood, swinging the guitar higher on her hip. “Most people only know the chorus, and they still sing it wrong.” “I don’t sing it,” the teenager blurted. A beat. The busker laughed. “Fair. Singing is optional.” The teenager tried to fix her face into something neutral and failed. “Your… your picking pattern in the second verse? You did the, uh…” She waved her hand vaguely, like she could sketch sound in the air. “You did the gallop but you shifted the accent.” The busker blinked, then grinned wider, like she’d been handed a toy. “Oh. You’re *that* kind of listener.” “I didn’t mean—” The teenager looked left, right, like an escape route might appear between a maid café flyer and a stack of used consoles. “Sorry. I shouldn’t—” “No, no.” The busker leaned forward, conspiratorial. “Don’t apologize. That was adorable. And correct. I shifted it so the melody pops. Otherwise it’s just—” She strummed a quick, sloppy version and made a face. “Arcade noise.” The teenager’s mouth twitched. Almost a smile. Almost. The busker pointed at her. “There it is. You liked that. I saw it.” “I—” The teenager’s ears warmed. “It was… funny.” “Name?” the busker asked, as if they’d already been talking for an hour. The teenager hesitated. “…Mio,” she said finally. It came out small, like she was afraid the street would steal it. “Mio.” The busker repeated it like tasting it. “Cute. I’m Reina.” “Mio,” the teenager said again, just to make sure she’d actually said it. Then, quieter: “Reina.” Reina lifted her chin at the teenager’s backpack. “You look like you’re on a mission.” “I’m—” Mio glanced toward the side street lined with electronics shops, neon signs layered like circuit boards. “I was looking for… parts.” “For what?” Mio’s fingers fidgeted at the zipper pull. “Synthesizer. I mean, for a synthesizer. I build… little ones. Not, like, big professional, um…” She took a breath. “I’m a nerd.” Reina’s eyebrows shot up. “Sick.” Mio blinked. “Sick?” “Good,” Reina said, as if that solved it. “What kind? Like… those silver boxes that go beep?” Mio’s shoulders loosened a millimeter. “Sometimes. Mostly DIY. VCOs, filters, envelopes. I’m… trying to get a stable pitch, but the temperature drift is—” She stopped herself, cheeks flushing. “Sorry.” Reina didn’t look bored. If anything, she looked delighted. “Temperature drift,” Reina repeated slowly. “That sounds like a poetic way to say your instrument is moody.” “It is moody,” Mio admitted. “Like… it has feelings about being tuned.” Reina laughed again, loud enough that two people near the arcade entrance glanced over. “Okay, you’re funny. Quiet funny.” Mio’s hands tightened again. “I’m not trying to be.” “That’s the best kind.” Reina slung her pick between her fingers and nodded at Mio. “So, synth nerd. What did you think of my tone? Don’t lie.” Mio swallowed. Honesty was safer than guessing what someone wanted. “It’s… bright,” she said carefully. “But not harsh. Your amp EQ is cut around… maybe 3k? And you have… compression, but not too much. Your sustain is—” Reina held up a hand, laughing. “Wait, wait. You can hear all that?” Mio nodded, looking down. “It’s… loud. And I like… listening.” Reina crouched by her amp, turned a knob, then pointed at it. “Look. I *did* cut around there. How—” Mio shrugged, tiny. “I just… know.” Reina straightened, then tapped her temple with the pick. “You’re dangerous. You could ruin me. Make me self-conscious.” “I don’t want to,” Mio said quickly. “I’m kidding.” Reina’s voice softened a notch. “It’s cool. Most people don’t… care about that stuff.” Mio’s eyes flicked up. “I care.” Reina met that look—quiet intensity, like a held note that refused to fade. “Yeah,” Reina said, gentler. “I can tell.” A pause stretched between them, filled by the arcade’s muffled explosions and the distant chant of a store promo. Mio shifted her weight. “Are you… here every day?” “Most weekends,” Reina said. “Sometimes weekdays if my part-time shift ends early. This spot is good. People come out of the arcade and they’re already hyped, so they throw coins at anything fast.” Mio nodded. “It works.” Reina tilted her head. “You playing anything?” Mio shook her head so quickly it almost hurt. “No. I—no.” “What, you build synths and don’t play?” “I do,” Mio said. Then, panicking at the implication: “At home. Alone. Like… I record and—” “Ah,” Reina said, not teasing. “Studio goblin.” Mio almost laughed again. She pressed her lips together hard, like laughter was something she had to keep from spilling. Reina watched her struggle and looked pleased, like she’d found a button and couldn’t resist pressing it. “So, Mio the studio goblin,” Reina said, “what were you doing in Den Den Town? Looking for—what did you call it—VCO?” “Voltage-controlled oscillator,” Mio said automatically, then winced. “Sorry.” Reina waved it off. “No, teach me. I’m curious.” Mio blinked at the word *teach* as if it didn’t belong in the same sentence as her name. “I’m not… good at explaining.” “I’m good at listening,” Reina said, and then added with a grin, “Sometimes.” Mio’s grip on her strap loosened again. She risked another glance at Reina’s guitar. “The song,” Mio said, to anchor herself. “It’s from… ‘Galaxy Knights’?” Reina’s mouth fell open in mock offense. “Excuse you. *Starblade Sentai.*” Mio’s eyes widened. “Right—right, sorry.
