The centrifuge made from a cordless drill and 3D-printed tube holders. The laminar flow hood cobbled together from a box fan and HEPA filters scavenged from a hospital wing. The gel electrophoresis rig built from a baking dish, copper wire, and an old phone charger that sometimes arced if humidity was high. A shrine to stolen time. “You got the contract?” Kade asked. Marrow reached into their coat and pulled out a wad of paper wrapped in oilcloth: the fuel chit, the ammo count, a handwritten note with the pickup location. And the canister. They set it on the bench gently, like it could bruise. “The Primer’s real,” Marrow said. “Sealed. Two milliliters.” Kade’s mouth went dry. Two milliliters of stability. “And the beans?” he asked. Marrow’s eyes flicked to the foam rack of PCR tubes. “Need it fast. Tide’s pushing salt up the river. Last harvest was bitter. Kids won’t eat.” “Everyone’s kids won’t eat if you bring a corporate trait into our seed stock,” Kade said, sharper than he meant. The built-in obsolescence was a curse in the soil, a ghost in every field. One wrong cassette, one Helix & Crown “lock” left intact, and the settlement would be chained to a trait they couldn’t maintain. Marrow swallowed. “These aren’t corporate. That’s what the buyer says. They’ve got—” they hesitated, as if the words tasted like rust “—legacy lines. Pre-lock. They want you to splice from that into the beans. They’ll pay for clean work.” Clean work. In a world where even the rats had learned to avoid the old dumpsters because the leachate made their fur fall out. Kade looked at the canister again. His hands twitched, wanting to grab it and hide it in his coat. He forced himself to breathe. “Where’s the donor material?” he asked. Marrow pulled a second item from their pocket: a small vacuum-sealed pouch with a single dried leaf inside, crumbling at the edges. A label in faded print: *H&C—SALTGUARD v3*. Under that, stamped in red: **NOT FOR PROPAGATION.** Kade stared. “This is corporate.” “They swear it’s from before the locks,” Marrow said quickly. “From a research greenhouse. They say they’ve grown it twice.” “Everyone says things,” Kade said. The last person who’d brought him “pre-lock” maize had nearly killed their own field. The plants had sprouted, grown tall, and then collapsed at tasseling like someone had cut their knees. Helix & Crown had engineered the trait to self-delete; the plant spent its last energy building something it couldn’t pass on. It was profit as biology. He turned the pouch over in his gloved hands. The leaf’s veins were visible even through the plastic, a delicate map of potential. “What’s the pickup?” he asked. Marrow unfolded the note. “Tomorrow night. Old water treatment plant. You deliver seed, they deliver the rest.” “The rest?” Kade asked. Marrow’s gaze dropped. “There’s… another payment. They didn’t want it on paper.” Kade waited. “They want you to patch someone,” Marrow whispered. The room seemed to tighten around them, as if the plastic sheeting outside had sucked in. Kade felt his scars itch. “Medicine,” Marrow said, voice thin. “One of theirs got sick. They heard you… did something to yourself.” Kade’s mind flashed to his fever, his peeling skin, the taste of pennies in his mouth. The upside—fast healing, cold endurance—came with a constant low ache in his bones and an immune system that sometimes flared at nothing, making his throat swell until he couldn’t breathe without wheezing. He’d learned to keep an epinephrine pen nearby, homemade and unreliable. “Who is ‘theirs’?” Kade asked. Marrow didn’t answer directly. “They’ve got security. They’ve got a generator. They’ve got a freezer.” A freezer. Kade imagined stable enzymes, intact primers, plasmids kept cold and honest. He also imagined a gun barrel pointed at his head while someone demanded miracles. “You didn’t tell me this,” he said. Marrow’s shoulders hunched. “They didn’t tell me until an hour ago. Kade, we need the kerosene. We need the bullets. The winter… you know.” Kade did know. The settlement’s stove ate fuel like a starving mouth. Their hunters rationed shots. Children cried at night from cold more than hunger now. He set the pouch down and turned back to the rice cooker. The multimeter display had gone dark when he cut power. The tubes sat cooling, half-amplified, the polymerase pausing mid-stride like a worker with no wages. “I can’t just splice corporate traits into beans,” he said. “Not without confirming there’s no lock.” Marrow’s hands clenched. “Then confirm it.” “With what?” Kade snapped, then forced himself to soften. “I can run PCR on the suspected lock regions, yes. But my primers are homemade and my reagents are—” he gestured at the Helix canisters, at the patched world “—thin.” Marrow pushed the Crown Primer canister toward him. “Use this.” Kade’s throat tightened. That was the hook, plain and shining. The Primer wasn’t just payment; it was leverage. Use it on their job, or never. He reached for it and felt the cool, intact seal under his thumb. For a moment he let himself imagine a clean amplification curve, a bright band on a gel, certainty instead of guesswork. Then he looked at the dried leaf again. *NOT FOR PROPAGATION.* Helix & Crown had printed that because they could. Because the law had once backed it with guns and courts and men in suits. Now the law was hunger and whoever had the most bullets. Kade slid the canister back, not taking it yet. “If I do this,” he said, “I deliver seed that breeds true. No dead-end traits. No one-generation gimmicks.” Marrow nodded too fast. “That’s what they want.” “And I don’t patch anyone without consent,” Kade added. “If they want medicine, they bring the patient to me. Here. Under my rules.” Marrow’s eyes widened. “They won’t—” “Then no deal,” Kade said, surprising himself with the steadiness of it. The last year had taught him that courage was sometimes just choosing which fear you could live with. “Tell them that.” Marrow swallowed, then nodded slowly. “Tomorrow night,” they said. “Water plant. They’ll be expecting… something.” “They’ll get test results first,” Kade said. He picked up the dried leaf and carried it to the makeshift hood, turning on the box fan so it rattled and whined. He sprayed the interior with ethanol from a Helix canister, the mist catching the light like brief, clean snow. He set the leaf on a sterilized petri dish—an upside-down jar lid—and took up a scalpel sharpened on a stone. As he cut, he thought about built-in obsolescence as a philosophy. Not just in DNA, but in everything: appliances that failed after warranty, phones that slowed with updates, people pushed to exhaustion because replacement was cheaper than care. The corporations had made life itself into a subscription. When the world cracked, all those planned failures bloomed at once. Kade ground the leaf tissue in a mortar with a pinch of salt and detergent, breaking cells open like tiny promises. He pipetted the slurry—his pipette was a repurposed insulin syringe with marks scratched into the barrel—into a microtube. He added alcohol and watched DNA precipitate in pale threads, ghostly and fragile. He hooked it with a bent paperclip and transferred it into buffer. Fast, careful, like defusing a bomb that could starve a hundred people. He set up reactions: one to amplify the salt-tolerance cassette, one to check for known Helix & Crown lock motifs. The primers he’d designed from memory and half-corrupted files, sequences he’d once studied academically now turned into tools for survival. He added a precious drop of polymerase from his dwindling stock—old, temperamental. He did not open the Crown Primer canister yet. He placed the tubes in the rice cooker and powered the inverter. The multimeter flickered back to life. The thermometer climbed. Ninety-four. Outside, the wind worried at the plastic again, impatient. Somewhere beyond the settlement walls, the black market moved like blood through the ruins, carrying things that should have been dead. Kade watched the temperature hold steady and felt his own altered blood thicken under his skin, quick to seal, quick to scar. He wondered, not for the first time, if he’d saved himself or just postponed a different kind of collapse. When the cycle timer—an egg timer duct-taped to the bench—ticked, he whispered the steps anyway, as if saying them could keep the world’s broken machinery aligned. Denature. Anneal. Extend. Tomorrow night at the water plant, someone would want seed that lived and a body that could be rewritten. Tonight, all he had was a rice cooker, empty corporate canisters, and DNA that wanted to forget itself after one generation. He leaned in close to the cooker lid, listening to the faint boil and hum, and told the future, quietly and fiercely, to hold together just a little longer.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates strong technical craft and worldbuilding within the biopunk genre. The author successfully creates a convincing post-apocalyptic setting where corporate genetic engineering with built-in obsolescence has led to societal collapse. The central premise is well-executed, with Kade working as a biohacker using salvaged equipment to create viable crops from degrading genetic material. The worldbuilding excels through specific, technical details that feel authentic. The rice cooker thermal cycler, hand-crank generator setup, and improvised lab equipment create a believable jury-rigged laboratory. The author demonstrates solid understanding of PCR processes and molecular biology, integrating technical terminology naturally without overwhelming lay readers. The concept of "Generation Guaranteed" corporate seeds with engineered obsolescence is both plausible and thematically resonant. Kade emerges as a well-developed protagonist with clear motivation and believable expertise. His background as a former grad student turned settlement biohacker feels earned, and his self-experimentation with CRISPR modifications adds compelling personal stakes. The physical toll and unexpected benefits of his genetic modifications are well-integrated into his character, creating both vulnerability and advantage. The prose maintains consistent voice throughout, balancing technical precision with literary quality. Sentences like "The wind worried at the plastic sheeting" and "dust carried more than dirt now. Dust carried old world mistakes" demonstrate elegant, evocative writing. The author avoids purple prose while maintaining atmospheric description. The black market contract provides effective plot structure, introducing external pressure and moral complexity. The revelation that the job involves both seed creation and human genetic modification raises stakes appropriately. Marrow serves as an adequate intermediary character, though somewhat underdeveloped. However, the piece has some structural weaknesses. The pacing becomes somewhat uneven in the middle section, with extensive technical exposition that, while accurate, occasionally slows narrative momentum. The dialogue, while functional, lacks distinctive character voice - Marrow and Kade speak in similar registers. The ending feels somewhat incomplete, more like a chapter opening than a complete narrative arc. While this matches the prompt's request for a "chapter," it leaves key plot threads unresolved in ways that feel unsatisfying rather than intriguingly open-ended. The piece occasionally tells rather than shows, particularly in explaining the corporate backstory and Kade's self-modification. Some emotional beats could be more deeply explored - Kade's internal conflict about the dangerous contract could use more psychological depth. Despite these issues, the piece succeeds in creating an immersive, believable world with strong thematic coherence. The integration of hard science with post-apocalyptic survival creates compelling tension, and the writing demonstrates sophisticated understanding of both genre conventions and scientific principles.
